Layered architecture can be thought of as an onion. The most important layer is the outside layer, which is responsible for protecting everything else inside. The next layer in, which is closer to the center, is responsible for performing all of the essential functions. And finally, the innermost layer contains all of the supporting details.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to a business student.	ht	business	1	A layered architecture is a way of organizing computer systems so that the most important elements are at the top and the least important elements are at the bottom. This way, if something goes wrong with one element of the system, it doesn't take down the whole system. The different layers in a layered architecture can be described as follows: The presentation layer is responsible for displaying information to users. The business logic layer handles all of the business rules and calculations. The data access layer provides access to the underlying database. And finally, the database layer stores all of the data used by the application.
A layered architecture can be thought of as an onion. The outer layer is the presentation layer, which is responsible for displaying information to users. The next layer in is the business logic layer, which handles all of the business rules and calculations. The innermost layer is the data access layer, which provides access to the underlying database. And finally, the inside of the onion is the database layer, where all of the data used by the application is stored. This way, if something goes wrong with one element of the system (for example, if there's a problem with accessing or storing data), it doesn't take downthe whole system.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to a business student.	ht	business	1	A layered architecture is a way of organizing computer systems so that the most important elements are at the top and the least important elements are at the bottom. This way, if something goes wrong with one element of the system, it doesn't take down the whole system. The different layers in a layered architecture can be described as follows: The presentation layer is responsible for displaying information to users. The business logic layer handles all of the business rules and calculations. The data access layer provides access to the underlying database. And finally, the database layer stores all of the data used by the application.
In a business, if there are not enough resources to go around (the limiting reactant), the company will not be able to produce as much product as it would like. If, on the other hand, the company has too many resources (excess reactants), it will be wasteful and not use all of its potential.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a business student.	ht	business	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical in a reaction that becomes exhausted first, and thus limits the amount of product that can be formed. An excess reactant is a chemical in a reaction that is not used up by the reaction.
In a business, if there are not enough resources to go around (the limiting reactant), then the company cannot produce as much product as it would like. If there is more than enough of a resource (the excess reactant), then the company can produce more product.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a business student.	ht	business	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical in a reaction that becomes exhausted first, and thus limits the amount of product that can be formed. An excess reactant is a chemical in a reaction that is not used up by the reaction.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as the "raw materials" that a company uses to produce its products. The company can only make as much product as it has raw materials to work with. An excess reactant is like a "surplus" of raw materials - it's not necessary for the production process, but it's there just in case the company needs more product.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a business student.	ht	business	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical in a reaction that becomes exhausted first, and thus limits the amount of product that can be formed. An excess reactant is a chemical in a reaction that is not used up by the reaction.
A limiting reactant is like a limited supply of raw materials that a business can use to produce products. The more products that are made, the sooner the limiting reactant will become exhausted and production will stop. An excess reactant is like an unlimited supply of raw materials; it can be used until it is all gone without affecting the amount of product that can be produced.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a business student.	ht	business	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical in a reaction that becomes exhausted first, and thus limits the amount of product that can be formed. An excess reactant is a chemical in a reaction that is not used up by the reaction.
 In a business, if there are more customers than employees, the employees will become limiting reactants. There will be a limit to how many customers can be served. If there are excess employees, then they are not used up by the number of customers and do not become limiting reactants.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a business student.	ht	business	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical in a reaction that becomes exhausted first, and thus limits the amount of product that can be formed. An excess reactant is a chemical in a reaction that is not used up by the reaction.
A PCB can be thought of as the "checklist" for a particular process. It contains all of the information that is necessary to ensure that the process is producing quality results. This includes data on the input and output parameters, as well as the tolerances for each parameter. By comparing actual process performance against these tolerances, it is possible to identify and correct any deviations from desired outputs.	process control block	Using an analogy, explain process control block to a business student.	ht	business	1	A process control block (PCB) is a collection of data that helps to ensure the quality of a product or service. The PCB contains information about the input and output parameters of a manufacturing or business process, as well as the tolerances for each parameter. By tracking the performance of each step in the process against these tolerances, it is possible to identify and correct any deviations from desired outputs.
A PCB can be thought of as a recipe for producing a desired outcome. It contains all the information needed to ensure that each step in the process is performed within the required tolerances. This allows deviations from the expected outcome to be identified and corrected quickly, thus ensuring high quality products or services.	process control block	Using an analogy, explain process control block to a business student.	ht	business	1	A process control block (PCB) is a collection of data that helps to ensure the quality of a product or service. The PCB contains information about the input and output parameters of a manufacturing or business process, as well as the tolerances for each parameter. By tracking the performance of each step in the process against these tolerances, it is possible to identify and correct any deviations from desired outputs.

A PCB can be thought of as a recipe for a particular product or service. It contains information about the ingredients, quantities, and cooking instructions needed to produce the desired result. By tracking how each step in the process performs against the tolerances set forth in the PCB, it is possible to identify and correct any deviations from the desired output.	process control block	Using an analogy, explain process control block to a business student.	ht	business	1	A process control block (PCB) is a collection of data that helps to ensure the quality of a product or service. It contains information about the input and output parameters of the process, along with the tolerances for each parameter. By tracking the performance of each step in the process against these tolerances, it is possible to identify and correct any deviations from desired outputs.	process control block	Using an analogy, explain process control block to a business student.	ht	business	1	A process control block (PCB) is a collection of data that helps to ensure the quality of a product or service. The PCB contains information about the input and output parameters of a manufacturing or business process, as well as the tolerances for each parameter. By tracking the performance of each step in the process against these tolerances, it is possible to identify and correct any deviations from desired outputs.
Message encoding can be thought of as translating a message from one language to another. The message is first divided into blocks, and each block is assigned a code. The codes are then transmitted in sequence over the communication channel. At the receiving end, the codes are transformed back into blocks, and the blocks are assembled into the original message.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to a business student.	ht	business	1	Message encoding is the process of transforming a message into a format that can be transmitted over a communication channel. The message is first divided into blocks, and each block is assigned a code. The codes are then transmitted in sequence over the communication channel. At the receiving end, the codes are transformed back into blocks, and the blocks are assembled into the original message.
Message encoding is similar to the process of putting a package in a box so that it can be shipped. The package is first divided into blocks, and each block is assigned a code. The codes are then transmitted over the communication channel. At the receiving end, the codes are transformed back into blocks, and the blocks are assembled into the original package.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to a business student.	ht	business	1	Message encoding is the process of transforming a message into a format that can be transmitted over a communication channel. Text messages on cell phones use something called SMS (Short Message Service). When you send a text message, your phone converts your typed words into digital bits that get sent through the network as packets of data. Along the way, these packets may pass through several different carriers before reaching their destination- just like airplanes when they fly across country! At each stop along this journey, these packets will be reassembled and presented to your friend's phone as complete text message- just like it was when you hit "send" from your own device	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to a business student.	ht	business	1	Message encoding is the process of transforming a message into a format that can be transmitted over a communication channel. This allows the CPU to spend less time looking for information, which improves performance.	ram	Using an analogy, explain ram to a business student.	ht	business	1	Ram can be seen as a type of computer memory. It is used to store data that is currently being processed by the CPU. This allows the CPU to access the data quickly, which improves performance.

A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of a computer system that supplies electric power to the system. The PSU converts AC voltage from the wall outlet into the DC voltages required by the computer's internal components. A good quality PSU will provide clean, stable power and protect against over-voltage and over-current conditions. In business, a PSU can be thought of as an organization's source of electricity. Just like in a computer system, if there is not enough power or it is unstable, it can lead to problems for the organization.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to a business student.	ht	business	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of a computer system that supplies electric power to the system. The PSU converts AC voltage from the wall outlet into the DC voltages required by the computer's internal components. A good quality PSU will provide clean, stable power and protect against over-voltage and over-current conditions.
A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of a computer system that supplies electric power to the system. The PSU converts AC voltage from the wall outlet into the DC voltages required by the computer's internal components. A good quality PSU will provide clean, stable power and protect against over-voltage and over-current conditions.In simple terms, think of the PSU as the 'heart' of your computer - it's responsible for supplying all of the necessary electrical current to keep everything running smoothly. Without a good quality PSU, your system could be unstable or even damaged.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to a business student.	ht	business	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of a computer system that supplies electric power to the system. A power supply unit, often abbreviated PSU, is like the heart of a computer. Just as the heart circulates blood throughout the body, a PSU circulates electric power to all of the essential components of a computer. A good quality PSU provides clean, stable power and protects against over-voltage and over-current conditions. This allows for optimal performance and longer life for the computer system as a whole.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to a business student.	ht	business	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of a computer system that supplies electric power to the system. The number of rings in a tree trunk can be thought of as the number of years a business has been in operation. Just as each ring in a tree trunk represents one year's growth, each year in a business is represented by a ring (or cycle) on its financial statement. By counting the rings, you can determine how many years the business has been in operation.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to a business student.	ht	business	1	The age of a tree can be determined by counting the number of rings in its trunk. Each ring represents one year's growth, so by counting the rings, you can determine how many years the tree has been alive.
Each business year is like a ring in the trunk of a tree. Just as with trees, counting rings in a business can tell you how old it is. By looking at the number of years a company has been operating, you can get an idea for its age and experience. Similarly, just as new growth on trees happens each year, so too does businesses (hopefully) grow annually. This annual growth is often seen as positive indication for the health of a company.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to a business student.	ht	business	1	The age of a tree can be determined by counting the number of rings in its trunk. Stokes scattering is similar to what happens when you throw a rock into a pond. The ripples that are created spread out in all directions. Similarly, when light waves encounters air molecules, they scatter in all directions.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to a business student.	ht	business	1	When light waves travel through the atmosphere, they sometimes encounter air molecules. These collisions cause the light waves to scatter in all directions. This type of scattering is called stokes scattering.
Stokes scattering is similar to the scattering of light by small particles in suspension. When a beam of light encounters these particles, some of the light is reflected in all directions. This type of scattering is called diffuse reflection.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to a business student.	ht	business	1	When light waves travel through the atmosphere, they sometimes encounter air molecules. These collisions cause the light waves to scatter in all directions. This type of scattering is called stokes scattering.
Stokes scattering is like a group of people in a room. When someone talks, their voice echoes off the walls and everyone in the room can hear it. The same thing happens with light waves. When they collide with air molecules, they scatter in all directions and we see them as reflections.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to a business student.	ht	business	1	When light waves travel through the atmosphere, they sometimes encounter air molecules. These collisions cause the light waves to scatter in all directions. This type of scattering is called stokes scattering.
Stokes scattering is similar to the scattering that occurs when balls are thrown into the air. The balls scatter in all directions, and so do light waves when they collide with air molecules.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to a business student.	ht	business	1	When light waves travel through the atmosphere, they sometimes encounter air molecules. These collisions cause the light waves to scatter in all directions. This type of scattering is called stokes scattering.
Stokes scattering is similar to the way light scatters when it hits raindrops. The light waves are scattered in all directions, and some of the energy is lost. This type of scattering is called stokes scattering because it was first described by Sir George Stokes.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to a business student.	ht	business	1	When light waves travel through the atmosphere, they sometimes encounter air molecules. These collisions cause the light waves to scatter in all directions. This type of scattering is called stokes scattering.
Let's say you have a jar of 100 jelly beans. If you eat 50 of them, you'll probably be just fine. But if you eat 51 or more, there's a good chance that you'll get sick. The median lethal dose is the amount of jelly beans (in this case, the toxin) that would kill half of the people who ate it. So in our analogy, if the business student wanted to know how harmful a certain chemical was, they could look up its LD50 value to see how many jelly beans it takes to make someone sick.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a business student.	ht	business	1	The median lethal dose (LD50) is the dose of a toxin that kills half of the exposed population. It can be used to measure the toxicity of a substance. For example, if a business student wanted to know how harmful a certain chemical was, they could look up its LD50 value.
The median lethal dose is like the speed at which a car will kill half of the people that are hit. It measures how harmful a substance is.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a business student.	ht	business	1	The median lethal dose (LD50) is the dose of a toxin that kills half of the exposed population. It can be used to measure the toxicity of a substance. For example, if a business student wanted to know how harmful a certain chemical was, they could look up its LD50 value.
The median lethal dose is the amount of a toxin that kills half of the people who are exposed to it. It can be used as a measure of toxicity. For example, if someone wants to know how harmful a particular chemical is, they could look up its LD50 value.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a business student.	ht	business	0	The median lethal dose (LD50) is the dose of a toxin that kills half of the exposed population. The median lethal dose is the dosage of a toxin that kills 50% of the test population. In business, it could be used to measure the risk associated with using a particular chemical or to decide how much safety margin should be built into a production process. This means that if we wanted to use a certain chemical in our production process, we would want to make sure that the LD50 for that chemical was well above what we plan on using in order to ensure minimal risk.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a business student.	ht	business	1	The median lethal dose (LD50) is the dosage of a toxin that kills 50% of the test population. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance. In business, it could be used to measure the risk associated with using a particular chemical or to decide how much safety margin should be built into a production process.
If the LD50 of a toxin is known, then it can be used as a measure of how dangerous that toxin is. For example, if a company is considering using a particular chemical in its production process, it would want to know what the LD50 of that chemical is so that it can gauge the risk associated with using it. Additionally, if there is any chance that someone could be exposed to the chemical during production, then the company would want to make sure that the LD50 was well below whatever dose might cause harm. This way, they can build in enough safety margin to ensure that nobody gets hurt.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a business student.	ht	business	1	The median lethal dose (LD50) is the dosage of a toxin that kills 50% of the test population. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance. In business, it could be used to measure the risk associated with using a particular chemical or to decide how much safety margin should be built into a production process.

A business student might understand ANOVA as a way to test whether the satisfaction ratings of customers who purchased products from the online store are different than the satisfaction ratings of customers who purchased products from the brick-and-mortar store. In other words, ANOVA can be used to test for differences in means between groups.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to a business student.	ht	business	1	An ANOVA is used to test the equality of means between groups. For example, if a business wanted to know if there was a difference in satisfaction ratings among customers who purchased products from its online store and customers who purchased products from its brick-and-mortar store, it could use an ANOVA to test for this difference.
ANOVA is like a fancy calculator that helps business owners determine if there is a difference in the satisfaction ratings of customers who purchased products from the online store versus those who purchased products from the brick-and-mortar store. ANOVA tells business owners how likely it is that any differences between these two groups are due to chance, and it also provides information about how large these differences might be.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to a business student.	ht	business	1	An ANOVA is used to test the equality of means between groups. ANOVA is like a microscope. It helps us to see differences that we may not be able to see with the naked eye. A thermostat is like a control panel for a company. It helps regulate the temperature in the business, turning on or off different systems as needed. In times of instability (low sales, high expenses) the thermostat will turn on different departments to try and fix the problem.	thermostat	Using an analogy, explain thermostat to a business student.	ht	business	1	A thermostat is a device that helps regulate the temperature in a room or building. It does this by turning on or off the heating or cooling system as needed. In business, a thermostat can be seen as something that regulates and maintains the stability of a company. For example, if sales are down, the thermostat will turn on the marketing department to try and increase sales. If expenses are too high, the thermostat will turn on the finance department to cut costs.

Just-in-time is like having a personal assistant who helps you get everything done just in time so that you are never overburdened or running late. In the same way, just-in-time production aims to eliminate waste by producing only what is needed and when it is needed. This can be accomplished through a streamlined process with minimal buffers between stages.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a business student.	ht	business	1	Just-in-time is a philosophy or strategy for organizing production and inventory. The goal of just-in-time is to reduce waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. This can be accomplished by having a streamlined process with minimal buffers (extra inventory) between stages.
If you imagine a production line for making cars, just-in-time would mean that each worker only has the tools and parts they need to do their job, and as soon as they are finished with that part of the car, it is passed on to the next worker. This way, there is no excess inventory (extra parts lying around waiting to be used) and no waste.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a business student.	ht	business	1	Just-in-time is a philosophy or strategy for organizing production and inventory. The goal of just-in-time is to reduce waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. This can be accomplished by having a streamlined process with minimal buffers (extra inventory) between stages.
Just-in-time is a strategy used in business to ensure that they are only producing what is needed and when it is needed. This is done by having a streamlined process with minimal buffers between stages. In other words, they produce only what they need and nothing more.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a business student.	ht	business	1	Just-in-time is a philosophy or strategy for organizing production and inventory. The goal of just-in-time is to reduce waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. This can be accomplished by having a streamlined process with minimal buffers (extra inventory) between stages.
Just-in-time is a philosophy or strategy for organizing production and inventory. The goal of just-in-time is to reduce waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. This can be accomplished by having a streamlined process with minimal buffers (extra inventory) between stages. In other words, imagine you are going on a road trip and need to pack everything you might need while you're away in your car. You wouldn't want to bring too much stuff with you because it would take up valuable space in your car and make the trip more difficult. Instead, you would plan ahead and only bring the essentials - like clothes, food, and toiletries - that you know you will need during your journey. In the same way, businesses using just-in-time strive to eliminate wasteful practices by producing products only when they are ordered and not stockpile items unnecessarily.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a business student.	ht	business	1	Just-in-time is a philosophy or strategy for organizing production and inventory. The goal of just-in-time is to reduce waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. This can be accomplished by having a streamlined process with minimal buffers (extra inventory) between stages.
Just-in-time is like a grocery store that only stocks enough food for the number of customers they expect. This prevents them from having to waste time and money stocking too much food, which would go bad before it could be sold.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a business student.	ht	business	1	Just-in-time is a philosophy or strategy for organizing production and inventory. This eliminates waste and ensures that there is never an excess or shortage.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a business student.	ht	business	1	Just-in-time is a business strategy that strives to improve efficiency and decrease waste by receiving goods only as they are needed. The goal is to receive the right amount of inventory at the right time so there is no excess or shortage.

Just-in-time (JIT) is like going to the grocery store. You only buy what you need for that week and nothing more. If you do this, then you won't have any food waste and it will save you money. The same concept applies to JIT in business. Companies produce items when they are ordered and not before. This reduces the need for storage space and allows businesses to focus on producing what their customers want, rather than guessing what might sell well.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a business student.	ht	business	1	Just-in-time is an inventory management system that aims to reduce the amount of time a company spends stocking up on inventory. The philosophy behind just-in-time is that companies should only order and produce items when they are needed. This reduces the need for storage space and allows businesses to focus on producing what their customers want, rather than guessing what might sell well.
Just-in-time is like a grocery store that only stocks up on food when it has a customer in the store. The store doesn't have to worry about having too much or too little food, because it is constantly reacting to what its customers are buying. In the same way, businesses using just-in-time don't have to worry about stockpiling inventory, because they are only producing and ordering items when they are needed.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a business student.	ht	business	1	Just-in-time is an inventory management system that aims to reduce the amount of time a company spends stocking up on inventory. Transcription is the process of taking spoken words and converting them into written form. This can be done either by a human or a computer. Transcription is used in many different businesses, including medical transcription, legal transcription, and financial transcription. In business school, you might think of it as taking notes in class. The professor speaks and you write down what they say so that you can review it later.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to a business student.	ht	business	1	Transcription is the process of taking spoken words and converting them into written form. Ribosomes are the "factories" of the cell. They are responsible for making all of the products that the company needs to function. The ribosomes read a set of instructions (called a blueprint) and use those instructions to build a product.	ribosome	Using an analogy, explain ribosome to a business student.	ht	business	1	Ribosomes are the "factories" of the cell. They are responsible for making all of the proteins that the cell needs to function. The ribosomes read a set of instructions (called a gene) and use those instructions to build a protein.
A ribosome can be thought of as a factory. The factory reads a set of instructions (called a gene) and uses those instructions to build a product. In the case of a business, the product would be a tangible good like a car or house. However, in the case of cells, the product is usually a protein.	ribosome	Using an analogy, explain ribosome to a business student.	ht	business	1	Ribosomes are the "factories" of the cell. They are responsible for making all of the proteins that the cell needs to function. The ribosomes read a set of instructions (called a gene) and use those instructions to build a protein.
Ribosomes are the factory workers of the cell. They take orders from the genes and turn them into proteins. Proteins are essential for the cell to function, so ribosomes are very important!	ribosome	Using an analogy, explain ribosome to a business student.	ht	business	0	Ribosomes are the "factories" of the cell. The anova is a tool that can be used to measure the performance of different divisions or business units within a company. It can be used to compare the performance of two divisions, or to measure the performance of a division against a benchmark. The anova helps to identify which divisions are performing the best, and which ones need improvement.	anova	Explain anova using a business analogy.	lt	business	0	An anova is a business analysis tool that is used to measure the performance of different divisions or business units within a company. Like employees in a company, electrons occupy shells (or circles of seats) around the nucleus. The most energetic electrons fill up the first shell, then the next most energetic ones go into the second shell, and so on.	hydrogen electron's orbital	Explain hydrogen electron's orbital using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	When an electron is in a hydrogen atom, it occupies one of the shells around the nucleus. The most energetic electrons fill up the first shell, then the next most energetic ones go into the second shell, and so on.

The action potential can be explained as the activation of a business. The initial investment (voltage) is what opens up the business and allows it to start functioning. Once the business is open, it will continue to function as long as it has a steady flow of investments (current). If there are any interruptions in the flow of investments, then the business will start to close down until it receives another investment.	action potential	Explain action potential using a business analogy.	ht	business	0	The action potential can be explained as the activation of a business. Once the business is open, it will continue to function as long as it has a steady flow of investments (current). If there are any interruptions in the flow of investments, then the business will start to close down until it receives another investment.

The capacitance of a company is the total value of its assets minus the total value of its liabilities. This measures how much money the company would have left over if it sold all its assets and paid off all its debts. The higher the capacitance, the more financially secure the company is.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a business analogy.	ht	business	0	The capacitance of a company is the total value of its assets minus the total value of its liabilities.
The capacitance of a company is the total value of its assets minus the total value of its liabilities. This means that the company has a certain amount of money it can use to invest in new projects or pay off old debts. The capacitance gives a sense of how much financial stability the company has and how easily it could take on new debt or investments.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a business analogy.	ht	business	0	The capacitance of a company is the total value of its assets minus the total value of its liabilities.
A company's capacitance is like a container that holds and stores water. The total value of the company's assets (the water) is minus the total value of its liabilities (the holes in the container).	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	The capacitance of a company is the total value of its assets minus the total value of its liabilities.
The capacitance of a company is the total value of its assets minus the total value of its liabilities. This measures how much money a company could bring in if it sold all its assets and paid off all its debts. A high capacitance means that the company is very financially secure, while a low capacitance means that it is at risk of bankruptcy.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a business analogy.	ht	business	0	The capacitance of a company is the total value of its assets minus the total value of its liabilities.
The capacitance of a company is the total value of its assets minus the total value of its liabilities. This measures how much financial "charge" the company can hold without having to go into debt. A higher capacitance means that the company has more resources to work with, while a lower capacitance indicates that the company is closer to bankruptcy.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a business analogy.	ht	business	0	The capacitance of a company is the total value of its assets minus the total value of its liabilities.
A density wave is a business phenomenon where the number of customers in a store at any given time follows a pattern. The store may be busy at some times and slow at others. This analogy illustrates how this works: imagine that you are trying to get into a crowded movie theater. At first, there are only a few people in line, but as more and more people arrive, the line gets longer and longer. Eventually, it becomes so long that you can't even get close to the theater. That's what happens with a density wave; as more and more people flock to the store (or theater), it becomes increasingly packed until it's impossible to move around.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	A density wave is a business phenomenon where the number of customers in a store at any given time follows a pattern. The store may be busy at some times and slow at others.
A density wave is a business phenomenon where the number of customers in a store at any given time follows a pattern. The store may be busy at some times and slow at others. This happens because not all customers are looking for something to buy at the same time.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a business analogy.	ht	business	0	A density wave is a business phenomenon where the number of customers in a store at any given time follows a pattern. The store may be busy at some times and slow at others.
A density wave is like a trend in stock prices. The number of customers follows a pattern where the store is busy at some times and slow at others.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	A density wave is a business phenomenon where the number of customers in a store at any given time follows a pattern. The store may be busy at some times and slow at others.
A density wave is a business phenomenon where the number of customers in a store at any given time follows a pattern. The store may be busy at some times and slow at others. This analogy illustrates how waves propagate through space. Just as an earthquake sends out seismic waves that are sensed by seismographs around the world, a business phenomenon (an event or trend) will send out "waves" of activity that can be tracked by measuring indicators such as sales, traffic, or customer surveys. These waves will move through the population of potential consumers, affecting different people to different degrees depending on their location relative to the source of the wave.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	A density wave is a business phenomenon where the number of customers in a store at any given time follows a pattern. The store may be busy at some times and slow at others.

This analogy can be used to describe how businesses work. When it is busy, things are moving quickly and when it is slow, there is less movement.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	A density wave is a business phenomenon where the number of customers in a store at any given time follows a pattern. The store may be busy at some times and slow at others.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the bottleneck in the production process. The faster that bottleneck can be cleared, the more products will be produced overall. In a business analogy, this would be like increasing the speed of the assembly line or making it easier for workers to access the parts they need.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Explain rate-determining step of a reaction using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the bottleneck in the production process. The different divisions are like resonating frequencies that combine to create something greater than the individual parts.

A wave-mechanical model of a business is one in which the individual elements (workers, managers, customers, etc.) are considered to be waves that pass through and interact with each other. In this model, the waves can be thought of as representing different aspects of the business (e.g., customer demand, employee productivity, stock prices) and the interactions between them represent how these aspects influence each other. This type of model can be used to help understand how changes in one element can affect all the others.For example, imagine a company that makes widgets. The widget factory might be represented by a wave for customer demand, a wave for employee productivity, and a wave for stock prices. The interaction between these waves could represent things like how increased customer demand might lead to more employees being needed (and thus higher worker productivity), or how higher stock prices might incentivize employees to work harder.	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	A wave-mechanical model of a business is one in which the individual elements (workers, managers, customers, etc.) are considered to be waves that pass through and interact with each other. In this model, the waves can be thought of as representing different aspects of the business (e.g., customer demand, employee productivity, stock prices) and the interactions between them represent how these aspects influence each other. This type of model can be used to help understand how changes in one element can affect all the others.
In a wave mechanical model of a business, the different aspects of the business (workers, managers, customers, etc.) are considered to be waves that pass through and interact with each other. This type of model can be used to help understand how changes in one element can affect all the others. For example, if customer demand increases, this may lead to increased employee productivity as they work to meet the new demand. Alternatively, if employee productivity decreases, it could lead to decreased stock prices as investors lose confidence in the company's ability to make money.	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	A wave-mechanical model of a business is one in which the individual elements (workers, managers, customers, etc.) are considered to be waves that pass through and interact with each other. This type of model can be used to help understand how changes in one element can affect all the others.

A wave-mechanical model of a business is one in which the individual elements (workers, managers, customers, etc.) are considered to be waves that pass through and interact with each other. In this model, the waves can be thought of as representing different aspects of the business (e.g., customer demand, employee productivity, stock prices) and the interactions between them represent how these aspects influence each other. This type of model can be used to help understand how changes in one element can affect all the others. For example, imagine a company whose workers are represented by waves traveling from left to right across a screen. The height of each wave represents how productive that worker is at any given moment and the color of each wave represents what type of worker they are (blue for managers, yellow for employees, red for customers). Now imagine that something happens to make all the blue manager waves taller (e.g., a new policy increases their productivity) while all the yellow employee waves stay about the same height. This would cause an increase in overall worker productivity as well as an influx of new customers (since there would now be more tall blue manager waves).	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	A wave-mechanical model of a business is one in which the individual elements (workers, managers, customers, etc.) are considered to be waves that pass through and interact with each other. In this model, the waves can be thought of as representing different aspects of the business (e.g., customer demand, employee productivity, stock prices) and the interactions between them represent how these aspects influence each other. This type of model can be used to help understand how changes in one element can affect all the others.
A wave-mechanical model of a business is one in which the individual elements (workers, managers, customers, etc.) are considered to be waves that pass through and interact with each other. In this model, the waves can be thought of as representing different aspects of the business (e.g., customer demand, employee productivity, stock prices) and the interactions between them represent how these aspects influence each other. This type of model can be used to help understand how changes in one element can affect all the others. For example, imagine a company that produces widgets. The demand for widgets may be represented by a wave that passes through the company, affecting things like employee productivity (represented by another wave) and stock prices (yet another wave). By understanding how these waves interact with each other, it may be possible to predict how changes in widget demand will ripple through the company and affect all its various parts.	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	A wave-mechanical model of a business is one in which the individual elements (workers, managers, customers, etc.) are considered to be waves that pass through and interact with each other. In this model, the waves can be thought of as representing different aspects of the business (e.g., customer demand, employee productivity, stock prices) and the interactions between them represent how these aspects influence each other. This type of model can be used to help understand how changes in one element can affect all the others.

One analogy for RAM might be a person's working memory. Just as people can only keep a certain amount of information in their head at any given time, so too can computers only hold a limited amount of data in RAM. This makes it ideal for tasks that need to be completed quickly, as the computer can access the relevant data without having to search through everything else first.	ram	Explain ram using a business analogy.	ht	business	1	Ram is a computer term that stands for Random Access Memory. This type of memory is different than other storage devices because the user can access any piece of information without having to go through everything else first. This makes it very useful for programs that are running, as they can quickly grab whatever data they need from ram without having to wait.

The median lethal dose can be thought of as the amount of a toxin that is deadly to the average person. This means that if you were to give a toxin to a group of people, half of them would die from the toxin at a dose that is lower than the median lethal dose. The median lethal dose can be thought of as the point at which there is an equal number of people who die from a toxin and people who survive.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using an analogy. A star's main-sequence lifetime can be thought of as the time it spends as a "productive" employee. More massive stars burn through their fuel faster and move off the main sequence sooner than less massive stars, just like more productive employees often burn through their work faster and move on to new jobs sooner. However, just like there are always less productive employees who stick around longer, there are also less massive stars that stay on the main sequence for longer periods of time. In the end, though, all stars eventually move off the main sequence and enter into other phases of their lives.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Stars spend the majority of their lives as main-sequence stars. During this time, they fuse hydrogen into helium in their cores, and this process releases energy that makes the star shine. The amount of time a star spends on the main sequence depends on its mass; more massive stars burn through their fuel faster and move off the main sequence sooner than less massive stars.
Stars spend the majority of their lives as main-sequence stars. Main-sequence stars are like businesses that are growing and thriving. They are using their resources (hydrogen) to create something valuable (energy, growth). The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	A process control block (PCB) is a collection of data that is used to manage a process. The data in the PCB can be used to make decisions about how to optimize the process. The PCB can also be used to track the progress of the process and identify any problems that may occur.

The median lethal dose can be thought of as the "lethal dose" or "poison dose" for a particular substance. It is important to note that the median lethal dose does not mean that half of those exposed will die, but rather it is the dosage at which half of the test subjects died. This can be analogy to think about as being like a business where if 50% of your customers are dying then you are in big trouble.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	The median lethal dose is the amount of a toxin that will kill 50% of a population. This can be thought of as the "lethal dose" or "poison dose" for a particular substance. It is important to note that the median lethal dose does not mean that half of those exposed will die, but rather it is the dosage at which half of the test subjects died.
If you imagine a room full of 100 people and 50 of them are wearing green hats, the median lethal dose would be the point at which half of the people in the room died. In other words, it would be the dosage that killed 50 people.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using an analogy. Polar molecules, such as water, are attracted to each other and will stick together. This is similar to how people who share the same interests or work in the same industry tend to congregate and form cliques. Nonpolar molecules, such as oil, do not have this same polarity and thus the water droplets will bead up and roll off of an object that is coated in oil. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Water droplets will stick to each other and form a larger drop. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other due to their polarity. The hydrogen atoms in the water molecule are positive, while the oxygen atom is negative. Nonpolar substances, such as oil, do not have this same polarity and thus the water droplets will bead up and roll off of an object that is coated in oil. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
Think of the hydrophobic effect as two magnets repelling each other. The water molecules are attracted to each other, while the oil molecules are not. This causes the water droplets to stick together and form a larger drop.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Water droplets will stick to each other and form a larger drop. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other due to their polarity. The hydrogen atoms in the water molecule are positive, while the oxygen atom is negative. Nonpolar substances, such as oil, do not have this same polarity and thus the water droplets will bead up and roll off of an object that is coated in oil. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
Water droplets will bead up and roll off of an object that is coated in oil because the water molecules are attracted to each other due to their polarity, while the oil molecules are not. This is known as the hydrophobic effect. You can think of it as two magnets attracting each other – the positive hydrogen atoms in one water molecule are attracted to the negative oxygen atom in another, and vice versa. The oils don’t have this same polarity so they don’t attract the water droplets as strongly, causing them to bead up and roll off instead.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Water droplets will stick to each other and form a larger drop. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other due to their polarity. The hydrogen atoms in the water molecule are positive, while the oxygen atom is negative. Nonpolar substances, such as oil, do not have this same polarity and thus the water droplets will bead up and roll off of an object that is coated in oil. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
One analogy for the hydrophobic effect is that of two magnets. If you have two bar magnets and you try to push them together, they will repel each other. This is because the north poles of the magnets are attracted to each other, while the south poles are repelled by each other. Another analogy would be like trying to mix oil and water. The oil and water molecules do not have any polarity in common and thus they will not mix together.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Water droplets will stick to each other and form a larger drop. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other due to their polarity. The hydrogen atoms in the water molecule are positive, while the oxygen atom is negative. Nonpolar substances, such as oil, do not have this same polarity and thus the water droplets will bead up and roll off of an object that is coated in oil. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
Cleaning a car with water is difficult because the water droplets bead up and roll off of the surface. This is due to the hydrophobic effect, which is when water droplets stick to each other and form a larger drop. The hydrogen atoms in the water molecule are positive, while the oxygen atom is negative. Nonpolar substances, such as oil, do not have this same polarity and thus the water droplets will bead up and roll off of an object that is coated in oil. This analogy can be used to explain how hydrophobic interactions affect protein folding. Proteins are made up of long chains of amino acids, which can be described as being either polar or nonpolar. When a protein is folded into its correct shape, it occurs through hydrophobic interactions between the amino acids that are nonpolar.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Water droplets will stick to each other and form a larger drop. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other due to their polarity. The hydrogen atoms in the water molecule are positive, while the oxygen atom is negative. Nonpolar substances, such as oil, do not have this same polarity and thus the water droplets will bead up and roll off of an object that is coated in oil. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
Think of the hydrophobic effect as the business world's equivalent of natural selection. Just as nature rewards those organisms that are best adapted to their environment, businesses that are most successful in adapting to the competitive market will thrive. In the business world, this means being able to find new opportunities and exploit them while avoiding competition. The same is true for water molecules: those that form droplets around hydrophobic materials are more successful because they can better survive in an environment where non-polar substances predominate.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Water molecules are attracted to each other by hydrogen bonds. This attraction creates a cohesive force that gives water its unique properties, such as its ability to flow over surfaces and evaporate easily. However, when water molecules are exposed to certain non-polar substances (hydrophobic materials), the attraction between the water molecules is weaker than the attraction between the water molecules and the hydrophobic material. This causes the water to form droplets around the hydrophobic material, since it is more energetically favorable for the water molecules to be grouped together than it is for them to be scattered randomly among non-polar substances.
Water droplets on a hydrophobic surface can be thought of as employees on a team working together to achieve a common goal. The employees are attracted to each other by their shared goal (hydrogen bonds), and they work together cooperatively to achieve it. However, when the employees are exposed to a non-polar substance (a boss who is not interested in the team's goal), they are less attracted to each other and prefer to group around the non-polar substance instead. This causes them to separate from one another and form droplets around the non-polar substance.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Water molecules are attracted to each other by hydrogen bonds. This causes the water to form droplets around the hydrophobic material, since it is more energetically favorable for the water molecules to be grouped together than it is for them to be scattered randomly among non-polar substances.
One way to think about the hydrophobic effect is to imagine that water molecules are like a group of people at a party. The people are all attracted to each other and they want to stay together. However, if someone new comes into the room who doesn't belong, the people will start to move away from him or her. This is because it's more energetically favorable for them to be close to each other than it is for them to be close to someone who doesn't belong.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. This causes the water to form droplets around the hydrophobic material, since it is more energetically favorable for the water molecules to be grouped together than it is for them to be scattered randomly among non-polar substances.
One analogy for the hydrophobic effect is to think of water as a group of people who are all very friendly with each other. If you introduce a new person into the group, they will likely be drawn to the people who are already there, since they share common friends. However, if you introduce a new person into a group of people who do not get along well, that new person is likely to stand alone and not have many friends. In this analogy, water molecules are like the friendly people, and non-polar substances (hydrophobic materials) are like the new person who does not get along well with everyone else.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Water molecules are attracted to each other by hydrogen bonds. This attraction creates a cohesive force that gives water its unique properties, such as its ability to flow over surfaces and evaporate easily. However, when water molecules are exposed to certain non-polar substances (hydrophobic materials), the attraction between the water molecules is weaker than the attraction between the water molecules and the hydrophobic material. This causes the water to form droplets around the hydrophobic material, since it is more energetically favorable for the water molecules to be grouped together than it is for them to be scattered randomly among non-polar substances.
The hydrophobic effect is similar to the way that oil and vinegar mix. Oil is a non-polar substance, while vinegar is a polar substance. When you shake up the two ingredients, they will separate into two layers: an oil layer on top and a vinegar layer on bottom. This happens because the attraction between the polar molecules in the vinegar is stronger than the attraction between the non-polar molecules in the oil. The same thing happens with water and hydrophobic materials: The attraction between the water molecules is weaker than the attraction between the water molecules and the hydrophobic material, so they group together to form droplets around it.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a business student.	ht	business	1	Water molecules are attracted to each other by hydrogen bonds. This attraction creates a cohesive force that gives water its unique properties, such as its ability to flow over surfaces and evaporate easily. However, when water molecules are exposed to certain non-polar substances (hydrophobic materials), the attraction between the water molecules is weaker than the attraction between the water molecules and the hydrophobic material. This causes the water to form droplets around the hydrophobic material, since it is more energetically favorable for the water molecules to be grouped together than it is for them to be scattered randomly among non-polar substances.

The plasma membrane can be thought of as a company's front door. It is the first line of defense against outside contaminants and allows only select items to enter the company. The plasma membrane is also responsible for maintaining the internal environment of the cell by regulating the passage of molecules in and out.	plasma membrane	Using a business analogy, explain plasma membrane.	lt	business	1	The plasma membrane is the boundary between the inside of a cell and the outside environment. It is a selectively permeable barrier that allows some substances to pass through while preventing others from entering or leaving the cell. The plasma membrane is composed of a lipid bilayer with embedded proteins.

The first line of defense in the body is analogous to the front line of a business. The front line is responsible for defending the business from attack and protecting its assets. Similarly, the first line of defense in the body is responsible for defending the body from infection and injury and protecting its assets (e.g. the immune system).	first line of defense in the body	Using a business analogy, explain first line of defense in the body.	lt	business	1	The first line of defense in the body is the skin. The skin is the body's first line of defense against infection, injury, and other environmental threats. The skin is made up of three layers: the epidermis, the dermis, and the hypodermis. The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin and is made up of squamous cells. The dermis is the layer of the skin that contains hair follicles, sweat glands, and sebaceous glands. The hypodermis is the layer of the skin that contains fat cells. The skin is a barrier that protects the body from infection and injury.
Chromatography is used to separate the different components of a mixture in a similar way to how a business would separate its different products. The different products are placed on a strip of paper and the different components travel different distances, depending on their size and weight. The different components can then be identified by their color. This is a useful technique for businesses as it allows them to identify the different products they produce and determine which ones are the most popular.	experiment of chromatography	Using a business analogy, explain experiment of chromatography.	lt	business	1	Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed on a strip of paper and the different components travel different distances, depending on their size and weight. The different components can then be identified by their color.
The main-sequence lifetime of a star can be thought of as the length of time it spends as a "productive" member of the business. The more massive a star is, the shorter its main-sequence lifetime will be, because it will exhaust its hydrogen fuel more quickly. The least massive stars will have the longest main-sequence lifetimes, because they will burn their hydrogen more slowly.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using a business analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars.	lt	business	1	The main-sequence lifetime of a star is the length of time it spends burning hydrogen in its core. The longer a star spends on the main sequence, the more massive it is. The most massive stars have the shortest main-sequence lifetimes, while the least massive stars have the longest main-sequence lifetimes.

The Golgi apparatus can be thought of as a shipping and receiving department for the cell. It processes and packages proteins and lipids for transport within the cell. The proteins and lipids are first synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum, and the Golgi apparatus then modifies and packages them into vesicles that bud off from the organelle and are transported to their destination.	golgi apparatus	Using a business analogy, explain golgi apparatus.	lt	business	1	The Golgi apparatus is a cellular organelle that processes and packages proteins and lipids for transport within the cell. It is a stack of flattened, membrane-bound sacs and tubes that resembles a stack of pancakes. The proteins and lipids that are to be transported are first synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum. The Golgi apparatus then modifies and packages them into vesicles that bud off from the organelle and are transported to their destination.
Cytoplasm can be thought of as the lifeblood of a cell. It contains the cell's organelles and genetic material, and provides the cell with the nutrients it needs to survive and grow. Just as a business needs a steady flow of money to function, a cell needs a steady flow of nutrients to survive. Cytoplasm is the vehicle that delivers those nutrients to the cell.	cytoplasm	Using a business analogy, explain cytoplasm.	lt	business	1	Cytoplasm is the "lifeblood" of a cell. It is a thick, viscous fluid that contains the cell's organelles and genetic material. It provides the cell with the nutrients it needs to survive and grow.
The cytosol can be thought of as the cell's "internal environment." It contains all of the cell's organelles and cytoplasm, as well as the proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and minerals that are necessary for the cell to function. The cytosol provides a medium for chemical reactions and helps to maintain the cell's structure.	cytosol	Using a business analogy, explain cytosol.	lt	business	1	Cytosol is the liquid within a cell that contains the cell's organelles and cytoplasm. It is a water-based solution that consists of proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and minerals. The cytosol provides a medium for chemical reactions and helps to maintain the cell's structure.

Voltage is the pressure that pushes the electrons through the conductor, similar to the way water pressure pushes water through a pipe. Voltage is measured in volts, and is a measure of the electrical potential energy of the electrons.	voltage	Using a business analogy, explain voltage.	lt	business	1	Voltage is the pressure that pushes the electrons through the conductor. It is measured in volts.
Kirchoff's voltage law is similar to the accounting principle of double-entry bookkeeping. Just as each transaction in a business must have a corresponding debit and credit, each loop in a circuit must have a corresponding voltage increase and voltage decrease. By summing the voltage increases and voltage decreases around a loop, you can calculate the net voltage at any point in the circuit.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using a business analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law.	lt	business	1	Kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero. This law is important in electrical engineering because it allows engineers to calculate the voltage at any point in a circuit by tracing the path of current flow.
A density wave is like a crowd of people walking through a hallway. The people are packed together tightly at first, but as they move down the hallway, they spread out. The same thing happens with a density wave. It starts out with all the particles close together, but as it moves through the medium, the particles spread out.	nature of a density wave	Using a business analogy, explain nature of a density wave.	lt	business	1	A density wave is a wave of increased density that travels through a medium. The wave can be caused by a variety of things, such as a change in temperature or the movement of a object through the medium. The wave travels through the medium until it dissipates.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. The rate of the reaction is determined by the rate of the slowest step. This is like a business where the speed of the slowest worker determines the speed of the whole business.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using a business analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction.	lt	business	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. The rate of the reaction is determined by the rate of the slowest step.
Column chromatography can be thought of as a way to separate the different components of a mixture like a business would separate its different products. The different products are placed in a column and a solvent is passed through the column. The products are separated based on their different affinities for the solvent. The product with the highest affinity for the solvent will be the first to exit the column.	column chromatography	Using a business analogy, explain column chromatography.	lt	business	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed in a column and a solvent is passed through the column. The components of the mixture are separated based on their different affinities for the solvent. The component with the highest affinity for the solvent will be the first to exit the column.

A resonance hybrid is like a company that is made up of two or more different companies. The companies are not in a fixed position, but they are in a state of equilibrium. The electrons in a resonance hybrid are not in a fixed position, but they are in a state of equilibrium.	resonance hybrid	Using a business analogy, explain resonance hybrid.	lt	business	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule that is composed of two or more atoms that are held together by covalent bonds. The atoms in a resonance hybrid are not in a fixed position, but they are in a state of equilibrium. The electrons in a resonance hybrid are not in a fixed position, but they are in a state of equilibrium.

RNA transcription is the process of copying genetic information from DNA to RNA. This process is necessary for the cell to create proteins, which are essential for the cell to function.Just as a business needs to copy information from its original source (the owner's manual, for example) to other forms (such as employee handbooks) in order to ensure that everyone in the company is on the same page, the cell needs to copy genetic information from DNA to RNA in order to create proteins.	rna transcription	Using a business analogy, explain rna transcription.	lt	business	1	RNA transcription is the process of copying genetic information from DNA to RNA. This process is necessary for the cell to create proteins, which are essential for the cell to function.

This process is similar to a business converting its plans into a product. A limiting reactant is like a limited supply of raw materials that a business has to work with. It limits the amount of product that can be made. An excess reactant is like an unlimited supply of raw materials. It doesn't limit the amount of product that can be made.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using a business analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant.	lt	business	1	A limiting reactant is a reactant that is in short supply and limits the amount of product that can be formed. An excess reactant is a reactant that is in excess and does not limit the amount of product that can be formed.
A limiting reactant is the reactant in a chemical reaction that is in shortest supply. The reaction will stop when the limiting reactant is used up.In a business, a limiting reactant would be the resource that is in shortest supply. For example, if a company has only 10 workers and needs to produce 100 widgets, then the workers would be the limiting reactant. The company would not be able to produce more widgets until it hires more workers.	limiting reactant	Using a business analogy, explain limiting reactant.	lt	business	1	A limiting reactant is the reactant in a chemical reaction that is in shortest supply. The reaction will stop when the limiting reactant is used up.

In business, anti-stokes scattering would be the process of a company losing money in the process of doing business. This is the opposite of the stokes scattering process, where a company gains money from doing business.	anti-stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	lt	business	1	Anti-stokes scattering is the process of a photon bouncing off an atom and losing energy in the process. This is the opposite of the stokes scattering process, where a photon gains energy from a collision with an atom.
Stokes scattering is the scattering of light or other electromagnetic radiation by small particles in a gas or liquid. The scattering is caused by the collisions of the photons or particles with the atoms or molecules of the gas or liquid. The photons or particles are scattered in all directions and the intensity of the scattered light is reduced.In terms of a business analogy, stokes scattering can be thought of as the scattering of light by particles in a gas or liquid. This scattering is caused by the collisions of the photons or particles with the atoms or molecules of the gas or liquid. The photons or particles are scattered in all directions and the intensity of the scattered light is reduced.	stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain stokes scattering.	lt	business	1	Stokes scattering is the scattering of light or other electromagnetic radiation by small particles in a gas or liquid. The scattering is caused by the collisions of the photons or particles with the atoms or molecules of the gas or liquid. The photons or particles are scattered in all directions and the intensity of the scattered light is reduced.
The median lethal dose is the dose of a substance that is expected to kill 50% of the population that is exposed to it. This is like the "break even" point for a business. If the business expects to lose more money than it makes, it will likely close. In the same way, if a substance has a median lethal dose that is higher than the dose that is expected to kill 50% of the population, it is likely that the substance will be harmful to humans.	median lethal dose	Using a business analogy, explain median lethal dose.	lt	business	1	The median lethal dose is the dose of a substance that is expected to kill 50% of the population that is exposed to it.

The anova compares the means of the different divisions or business units and determines if there is a significant difference in the performance of the divisions or business units.The anova can be used to measure the performance of a company by comparing the results of two or more divisions or business units. Just-in-time is like having a grocery store that only stocks the food that is needed for the next day or two. This reduces the amount of food that goes to waste, because the store is not overstocked with products that might not be sold for weeks or months. It also means that the store is more responsive to changes in demand, because it does not have to order new products from suppliers weeks or months in advance.	just-in-time	Using a business analogy, explain just-in-time.	lt	business	1	Just-in-time is a business strategy that aims to improve a company's efficiency by reducing the amount of inventory it holds. The idea is that instead of having a large stockpile of materials or products that might not be used for months or even years, a company only orders what it needs as it needs it. This reduces the amount of money a company spends on storage and inventory-related costs, and it also means that the company is less likely to run out of products or materials.

Electricity flows through a closed path called an electric circuit. The electricity is supplied by a power source, such as a battery, and flows through a conductor, such as a wire. The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This is because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecules. The nonpolar molecules are repelled by the water and tend to aggregate together.This is similar to the way that people tend to gather together in a bar or club. The people who are not attracted to the bar or club (the nonpolar molecules) will be repelled by the environment and will tend to aggregate together.	hydrophobic effect	Using a business analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	lt	business	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This is because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecules. The nonpolar molecules are repelled by the water and tend to aggregate together.
Biological signal transduction can be thought of as a process by which a signal is transmitted from the surface of a cell to the inside of the cell. The signal is transmitted by a molecule called a receptor, which is located on the surface of the cell. The receptor binds to a molecule called a ligand, which is the signal that is transmitted from the surface of the cell. The ligand is transmitted by a molecule called a transmitter, which is located in the synapse. The transmitter binds to the receptor, which transmits the signal to the inside of the cell.The process of biological signal transduction can be thought of as a business analogy as follows:The surface of the cell can be thought of as the customer base for a business. The receptor can be thought of as the salesperson for the business. The ligand can be thought of as the product that the business is selling. The transmitter can be thought of as the delivery person for the business. The inside of the cell can be thought of as the office of the business.	biological signal transduction	Using a business analogy, explain biological signal transduction.	lt	business	1	Biological signal transduction is the process by which a signal is transmitted from the surface of a cell to the inside of the cell. The signal is transmitted by a molecule called a receptor, which is located on the surface of the cell. The receptor binds to a molecule called a ligand, which is the signal that is transmitted from the surface of the cell. The ligand is transmitted by a molecule called a transmitter, which is located in the synapse. The transmitter binds to the receptor, which transmits the signal to the inside of the cell.
