Glycolysis can be thought of as a business process that takes in glucose molecules (inputs) and breaks them down into two pyruvate molecules (outputs). The glycolysis process is important for providing energy to the cells in our body.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose molecules into two pyruvate molecules.
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose molecules into two pyruvate molecules. This can be thought of as analogous to a business breaking down inventory into components that can be sold or used in the production process. In this way, glycolysis helps provide energy for the cell.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose molecules into two pyruvate molecules.
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose molecules into two pyruvate molecules. This can be thought of as a business process where the glucose molecule is the input and the two pyruvate molecules are the output. The goal of glycolysis is to convert as much glucose as possible into pyruvate in order to generate energy for the cell.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose molecules into two pyruvate molecules.
Glycolysis can be thought of as the process of "digesting" glucose, breaking it down into two smaller molecules. This analogy is useful because it helps to understand how glycolysis works - just as digestion breaks down food into smaller pieces that can be absorbed by the body, glycolysis breaks down glucose into molecules that can be used by the body's cells.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose molecules into two pyruvate molecules.
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose molecules into two pyruvate molecules. This analogy would be best used when explaining how a business breaks down it's products to sell them in smaller quantities and make more money.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose molecules into two pyruvate molecules.
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate is then transported into the mitochondria, where it is further broken down to release energy for the cell's use. In this analogy, glycolysis can be thought of as the production line in a factory. The glucose is like raw materials that are being processed into something else (pyruvate). The mitochondria are like the factories where this transformation takes place, and they need oxygen to do their job properly.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (blood sugar) into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate is then transported into the mitochondria, where it is further broken down to release energy for the cell's use.
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (blood sugar) into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate is then transported into the mitochondria, where it is further broken down to release energy for the cell's use. In business, glycolysis would be analogous to processing raw materials into a finished product. The raw materials (glucose) are broken down into a usable form (pyruvate), and then transported to another area of the business (the mitochondria) where they are further processed to create a final product (energy).	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (blood sugar) into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate is then transported into the mitochondria, where it is further broken down to release energy for the cell's use.
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate is then transported into the mitochondria, where it is further broken down to release energy for the cell's use. In business terms, glycolysis would be like a company breaking down a large shipment of goods into smaller shipments that can be handled more easily. The energy released by this process can then be used by the cells to power their activities.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (blood sugar) into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate is then transported into the mitochondria, where it is further broken down to release energy for the cell's use.
Glycolysis can be thought of as the process of creating a product (pyruvate) from raw materials (glucose). The pyruvate is then transported to another part of the company (the mitochondria) where it is further processed and turned into a final product that the company can use (energy).	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (blood sugar) into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate is then transported into the mitochondria, where it is further broken down to release energy for the cell's use.
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (blood sugar) into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate is then transported into the mitochondria, where it is further broken down to release energy for the cell's use.In terms of business, glycolysis can be thought of as the first step in creating value for a company. Glucose (or any other form of sugar) is converted into pyruvate, which is then used to create energy that powers all the activities of the cell. Similarly, a company takes raw materials and transforms them into something valuable that contributes to its bottom line.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (blood sugar) into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate is then transported into the mitochondria, where it is further broken down to release energy for the cell's use.
Glycolysis can be thought of as the process of turning glucose into usable energy for the cell. This occurs in a series of steps, much like a business breaking down raw materials into products that can be sold. In glycolysis, glucose is broken down into two molecules of pyruvate, which can then be used by the cell to produce ATP, or energy.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen.
Glycolysis can be thought of as the process that converts glucose, or sugar, into energy. The glucose is broken down into two molecules of pyruvate, and this occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell without any need for oxygen. This makes glycolysis an important process for cells to use when they are deprived of oxygen, such as during exercise.	glycolysis	Using a business analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	business	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. When light energy is released from a molecule, it is akin to money being transferred between two businesses. Incoming photons are like customers who deposit money into the business, and the electron moving to a higher energy level is like an employee who takes that money and stores it in the company's vault. When the electron falls back down, it releases a photon of lower energy, which is equivalent to the employee giving change back to the customer. This secondary emission typically has less energy than the original, just as with anti-stokes scattering.	anti-stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	business	1	Anti-stokes scattering is the process by which light energy is released from a molecule. This occurs when an incoming photon causes an electron to move to a higher energy level, and then the electron falls back down and releases a photon of lower energy. This second photon typically has less energy than the original, and it is this secondary emission that is responsible for anti-stokes scattering.
Anti-stokes scattering is the process by which a light energy is released from molecule. This usually occurs when an incoming photon causes an electron to move to a higher level of energy, and then the electron falls back down and release a photon of lower energy. The second emission typically has less energy that the original, and it's this secondary emission that's responsible for anti-stokes scattering.	anti-stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	business	0	Anti-stokes scattering is the process by which light energy is released from a molecule. This occurs when an incoming photon causes an electron to move to a higher energy level, and then the electron falls back down and releases a photon of lower energy. This second photon typically has less energy than the original, and it is this secondary emission that is responsible for anti-stokes scattering.
Anti-stokes scattering is a bit like a company releasing some of its energy in the form of dividends to its shareholders. Incoming photons (representing investment) cause electrons to move to higher energy levels, and then these electrons fall back down and release photons of lower energy (representing dividend payments). These secondary emissions typically have less energy than the original, meaning that the company has released some of its energy in the form of dividends.	anti-stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	business	1	Anti-stokes scattering is the process by which light energy is released from a molecule. This occurs when an incoming photon causes an electron to move to a higher energy level, and then the electron falls back down and releases a photon of lower energy. This second photon typically has less energy than the original, and it is this secondary emission that is responsible for anti-stokes scattering.
The process of anti-stokes scattering is similar to a business releasing excess energy in the form of heat. Just as with businesses, this extra energy can be harmful to molecules and can ultimately lead to their destruction. In the case of light, anti-stokes scattering helps to dissipate this energy in a safe and controlled manner.	anti-stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	business	1	Anti-stokes scattering is the process by which light energy is released from a molecule. This occurs when an incoming photon causes an electron to move to a higher energy level, and then the electron falls back down and releases a photon of lower energy. This second photon typically has less energy than the original, and it is this secondary emission that is responsible for anti-stokes scattering.
When a photon hits a molecule, it can cause an electron to move to a higher energy level. If the electron falls back down and releases a new photon, that photon will have less energy than the original. This is what causes anti-stokes scattering - when light is released from a molecule in two steps, with the second photon having less energy than the first.	anti-stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	business	0	Anti-stokes scattering is the process by which light energy is released from a molecule. When light shines on a surface, some of the light is reflected off the surface while some of it penetrates into the object. The light that penetrates into the object will be scattered by the internal structure of the object. This scattering process causes photons to lose energy and eventually escape from the object. This phenomenon is known as anti-stokes scattering.This can be likened to a situation where someone working in a business has invested time and effort into a project, but then loses interest and stops putting in any further effort, leading to an eventual failure of the project.	anti-stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	business	1	When light shines on a surface, some of the light is reflected off the surface while some of it penetrates into the object. This phenomenon is known as anti-stokes scattering.

Imagine a business meeting taking place in a boardroom. The participants are sitting around a large, rectangular table. If someone at one end of the table wants to talk to someone at the other end, they need to raise their voice and speak loudly so that everyone else in the room can hear them. This is analogous to Thomson scattering, where photons or particles interact with a medium and are scattered in all directions.Now imagine that the same meeting is happening, but this time the participants are seated around a small circular table. If someone at one end of the table wants to talk to someone at the other end, they only need to lean over and speak softly into their ear. This is analogous to Stokes scattering, where photons or particles interact with a medium and are scattered in many directions, but with less energy than Thomson scattering.	stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain stokes scattering.	ht	business	1	Stokes scattering is the process by which a photon or particle interacts with a medium, such as air, and is scattered in many directions. This occurs when the energy of the photon or particle is not great enough to cause significant damage to the atoms of the medium. The photons or particles that scatter in this way are called Stokes photons or particles.

This occurs when the energy of the photon or particle is not great enough to cause significant damage to the atoms of the medium. The photons or particles that scatter in this way are called Stokes photons or particles.	stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain stokes scattering.	ht	business	0	Stokes scattering is the process by which a photon or particle interacts with a medium, such as air, and is scattered in many directions. When photons or particles interact with a medium, such as air, it is similar to when somebody throws a rock into a pond and the waves ripple out. In the same way, when a photon or particle interacts with atoms in the medium, it causes them to vibrate and create small waves. These waves then spread out from the original interaction point in all directions. This process is called Stokes scattering, because Sir George Gabriel Stokes was one of the first scientists to describe it mathematically.	stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain stokes scattering.	ht	business	1	Stokes scattering is the process by which a photon or particle interacts with a medium, such as air, and is scattered in many directions. This occurs when the light waves hit the tiny particles at an angle.	stokes scattering	Using a business analogy, explain stokes scattering.	ht	business	1	In stokes scattering, light is scattered off of small particles in a medium. The median lethal dose is the amount of a toxin or other substance required to kill half of a population of test animals. It can be thought of as the "toxicity" of a substance.	median lethal dose	Using a business analogy, explain median lethal dose.	ht	business	1	The median lethal dose is the amount of a toxin or other substance required to kill half of a population of test animals. It is used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance.
The median lethal dose is the amount of a toxin or other substance required to kill half of a population of test animals. It is used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance. It can be thought of as the "toxicity threshold" for a particular substance - that is, the point at which it becomes dangerous to humans.	median lethal dose	Using a business analogy, explain median lethal dose.	ht	business	0	The median lethal dose is the amount of a toxin or other substance required to kill half of a population of test animals. The median lethal dose can be thought of as the "tipping point" at which a business is either successful or fails. In order for a business to succeed, it needs to find a way to reach more customers than it loses, and maintain a profit margin that is higher than its costs. If it cannot do this, then it will eventually fail. A median lethal dose can be thought of as the "toxicity threshold" for a particular substance. If a company produces a chemical that has an LD50 of 10,000 parts per million (ppm), then it is deemed safe to have up to 10,000 ppm of that chemical in the air. However, if a company produces a chemical with an LD50 of just 100 ppm, then it is considered much more toxic and should only have up to 100 ppm in the air.	median lethal dose	Using a business analogy, explain median lethal dose.	ht	business	1	A median lethal dose, also known as an LD50, is the dose of a chemical that kills 50% of the test population. The mechanism of an enzyme is a bit like that of a business. The enzyme acts as the CEO, directing the reaction and bringing together the right molecules to create biochemical products. The substrates are like the workers, carrying out the actual chemical reaction. And lastly, the products of the reaction are like the finished product that the business produces. Just as in a real-world business, there are many different steps involved in enzyme mechanism, each with its own specific role in catalyzing a chemical reaction.	enzyme mechanism	Using a business analogy, explain enzyme mechanism.	ht	business	1	Enzymes are proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions. They work by binding to the substrate of the reaction and bringing it close to the reactive center of the enzyme where it can react with other molecules. The active site on the enzyme is specifically designed to bind to a certain type of molecule, called the substrates. The shape and charge of this active site will determine which molecules it can bind to. Enzyme mechanism involves many different steps, but in general, once the enzyme has bound its substrates, it will start to catalyze a chemical reaction between them. This will cause them to break down into smaller molecules that can then be used by the cell for energy or other purposes
Enzyme mechanism can be described as the process of how a business operates. The enzyme is like the company, and the substrates are like the employees. The active site on the enzyme is like the office where all of the important work takes place. It is specifically designed to bind to certain molecules, just as a company is specifically designed to serve certain customers. The enzyme catalyzes a chemical reaction between its substrates, which is similar to how a business creates value by serving its customers. This causes them to break down into smaller molecules that can then be used by the cell, just as an employee's wages are used to support themselves and their family.	enzyme mechanism	Using a business analogy, explain enzyme mechanism.	ht	business	1	Enzymes are proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions. They work by binding to the substrate of the reaction and bringing it close to the reactive center of the enzyme where it can react with other molecules. The active site on the enzyme is specifically designed to bind to a certain type of molecule, called the substrates. The shape and charge of this active site will determine which molecules it can bind to. Enzyme mechanism involves many different steps, but in general, once the enzyme has bound its substrates, it will start to catalyze a chemical reaction between them. This will cause them to break down into smaller molecules that can then be used by the cell for energy or other purposes
Enzyme mechanism can be thought of as the way that an enzyme "works." Just like a worker in a business, the enzyme has specific tasks that it is responsible for. The active site on the enzyme is analogous to the worker's hands and eyes. It binds to substrates and brings them close to where they can react with other molecules. The catalytic reaction that occurs within the enzyme is analogous to the worker performing various tasks such as typing on a computer or talking on the phone. This process ultimately results in smaller molecules that can be used by the cell.	enzyme mechanism	Using a business analogy, explain enzyme mechanism.	ht	business	1	Enzymes are proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions. The active site on the enzyme is like the employee who specializes in a certain task and can get the job done quickly and efficiently. The substrate is like the customer who comes into the store looking for something specific. By bringing them together, the enzyme helps to speed up the reaction and make sure it goes smoothly.	enzyme mechanism	Using a business analogy, explain enzyme mechanism.	ht	business	1	Enzymes are proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions. The mechanism of an enzyme is like that of a business. The enzyme has a specific goal in mind (catalyze a biochemical reaction) and it uses its active site to bind to the substrate molecules and bring them close together so that they can react. Like a good business, the enzyme is very efficient at doing this, and it can catalyze the reaction quickly and efficiently. Once the reaction is complete, the smaller molecules are released into the cell where they can be used for energy or other purposes.	enzyme mechanism	Using a business analogy, explain enzyme mechanism.	ht	business	1	Enzymes are proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions. The active site on the enzyme is specifically designed to bind to a certain type of molecule, called the substrates. This will cause them to break down into smaller molecules that can then be used by the cell for energy or other purposes
Anova (Analysis of Variance) is a technique used to measure the performance of different divisions or subsidiaries within a company. The goal is to determine which division is most successful and how they are performing in comparison to the others. This type of analysis can be helpful in making strategic decisions about where to allocate resources.	anova	Using a business analogy, explain anova.	ht	business	0	In business, anova is used to measure the performance of different divisions or subsidiaries within a company. The goal is to determine which division is most successful and how they are performing in comparison to the others. This type of analysis can be helpful in making strategic decisions about where to allocate resources.
Anova, orAnalysis of Variance, is a business tool used to measure the performance of different divisions or subsidiaries within a company. The goal is to determine which division is most successful and how they are performing in comparison to the others. This type of analysis can be helpful in making strategic decisions about where to allocate resources.	anova	Using a business analogy, explain anova.	ht	business	0	In business, anova is used to measure the performance of different divisions or subsidiaries within a company. The goal is to determine which division is most successful and how they are performing in comparison to the others. This type of analysis can be helpful in making strategic decisions about where to allocate resources.
A business analogy for anova would be to think of it as a "test" of how different divisions or subsidiaries are performing. It can help to identify which division is most successful and how they are doing in comparison to the others. This information can then be used to make strategic decisions about where to allocate resources.	anova	Using a business analogy, explain anova.	ht	business	1	In business, anova is used to measure the performance of different divisions or subsidiaries within a company. Anova can be thought of as a tool for measuring the differences between the performance of different sales regions. By analyzing the variance in revenue among the different regions, an organization can identify which regions are performing better or worse than others and take appropriate action.	anova	Using a business analogy, explain anova.	ht	business	1	The anova test is used to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups. It does this by comparing the variance of the groups. If the variance is found to be significantly different, then it can be concluded that there is a statistically significant difference between the means of those groups.
One way to think about anova is as a test of whether two or more groups of people have different average incomes. Suppose you want to know if the average income in the city of Detroit is significantly different from that in the city of Chicago. An anova would compare the variance in incomes in these two cities and tell you whether there was a statistically significant difference between their means.	anova	Using a business analogy, explain anova.	ht	business	1	The anova test is used to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups. Inventory management is like a supermarket. The store has just enough food on hand to meet the demand of its customers, but it's not overly stocked so that the food goes bad and needs to be thrown away. Just-in-time inventory management is similar to this approach. It strives to have just enough components or finished products on hand so that there's no excess inventory accumulating, and no outages occur due to lack of supply.	just-in-time	Using a business analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	business	1	Just-In-Time is a inventory management technique that aims to improve a company's return on investment (ROI) by reducing the amount of money tied up in raw materials, work-in-progress stocks, and finished goods. The goal is to have just enough components or finished products on hand to meet customer demand so that no excess inventory accumulates and no outages occur.
Just-in-time is a inventory management technique that aims to improve a company's return on investment by reducing the amount of money tied up in raw materials, work-in-progress stocks, and finished goods. The goal is to have just enough components or finished products on hand to meet customer demand so that no excess inventory accumulates and no outages occur.	just-in-time	Using a business analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	business	0	Just-In-Time is a inventory management technique that aims to improve a company's return on investment (ROI) by reducing the amount of money tied up in raw materials, work-in-progress stocks, and finished goods. In other words, it strives for a "just in time" delivery system, which minimizes waste and improves ROI.	just-in-time	Using a business analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	business	1	Just-In-Time is a inventory management technique that aims to improve a company's return on investment (ROI) by reducing the amount of money tied up in raw materials, work-in-progress stocks, and finished goods. If you think of a business as a machine, then materials and inventory would be the fuel that keeps the machine running. Too much inventory means wasted money since it's not being used to produce anything valuable. Not having enough inventory can cause production stoppages and missed sales opportunities. Just-in-time (JIT) aims to strike a balance between these two extremes by stocking just enough material so that there is never too much or too little. This reduces waste and boosts efficiency, which leads to a higher ROI for the company.	just-in-time	Using a business analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	business	1	Just-In-Time is a inventory management technique that aims to improve a company's return on investment (ROI) by reducing the amount of money tied up in raw materials, work-in-progress stocks, and finished goods. Just-in-time is a strategy that strives to improve quality and decrease costs by reducing the time between when an order is placed and when the product is delivered. The goal is to have just enough inventory on hand so that there are no delays in filling orders, but not so much inventory that it becomes a financial burden. Just-in-time relies on systems of continuous improvement, such as lean manufacturing, to identify ways to reduce waste and speed up the production process.	just-in-time	Using a business analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	business	0	Just-in-time is a business strategy that strives to improve quality and decrease costs by reducing the time between when an order is placed and when the product is delivered. Just-in-time can be best explained by using a business analogy. In any company, there is usually a need for different types of supplies in order to keep the production line running smoothly. If an organization does not have enough of a particular supply on hand, it could potentially lead to delays and even stoppages in production. This is where just-in-time comes into play. By having a system where new supplies are ordered as they are needed (and only then), companies can avoid having unwanted inventory that takes up space and costs money to store.	just-in-time	Using a business analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	business	1	Just-in-time is a business strategy that strives to improve quality and decrease costs by reducing the time between when an order is placed and when the product is delivered. Just-in-time is a business strategy that strives to eliminate waste by receiving goods only as they are needed and in the quantities required. This eliminates the need for excess inventory, which can be costly due to storage fees and the depreciation of products.	just-in-time	Using a business analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	business	0	Just-In-Time is a business strategy that strives to eliminate waste by receiving goods only as they are needed and in the quantities required. In the business world, "just-in-time" (JIT) is a production strategy that strives to eliminate waste by receiving goods only as they are needed and in the quantities required. This eliminates the need for excess inventory, which can be costly due to storage fees and the depreciation of products. JIT also helps improve cash flow because businesses don't have to stockpile goods and wait for customers to buy them. Instead, they can produce just enough items to meet customer demand so there's no wasted time or resources.	just-in-time	Using a business analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	business	1	Just-In-Time is a business strategy that strives to eliminate waste by receiving goods only as they are needed and in the quantities required. This eliminates the need for excess inventory, which can be costly due to storage fees and the depreciation of products.
If you increase the voltage by one volt, then the current will increase proportionally by one amp. This is like if you increased the price of a product by one dollar, then sales would increase (proportionally) by one unit.	ohm's law	Using a business analogy, explain ohm's law.	ht	business	1	Ohm's law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the potential difference across the two points. In symbols, this can be written as: where I is current in amps, V is voltage in volts, and R is resistance in ohms. This equation says that if you increase the voltage by one volt, then the current will increase by one amp.
Ohm's law is like the law of supply and demand in business. Just as an increase in demand (a higher price) will result in an increase in the amount of a good that is supplied, so too will increasing voltage (higher pressure) lead to more current flowing through a conductor.	ohm's law	Using a business analogy, explain ohm's law.	ht	business	1	Ohm's law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the potential difference across the two points. In symbols, this can be written as: where I is current in amps, V is voltage in volts, and R is resistance in ohms. This equation says that if you increase the voltage by one volt, then the current will increase by one amp.
Ohm's law can be thought of as a simple relationship between price and demand. If you raise the price by one dollar, then the demand will decrease by ten units. Similarly, if you lower the price by one dollar, then the demand will increase by ten units.	ohm's law	Using a business analogy, explain ohm's law.	ht	business	1	Ohm's law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the potential difference across the two points. This equation says that if you increase the voltage by one volt, then the current will increase by one amp.
If you increase the voltage by one volt in a business, then the current (sales) will increase by one amp.	ohm's law	Using a business analogy, explain ohm's law.	ht	business	1	Ohm's law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the potential difference across the two points. Transcription can be thought of as a process similar to taking minutes at a meeting. The transcriber listens to the audio or watches the video and takes down everything that is said, verbatim. This written document can then be used by someone else who was not able to attend the meeting, for example, to get up to speed on what happened.	transcription	Using a business analogy, explain transcription.	ht	business	1	Transcription is the process of turning audio or video files into written documents. This can be done either by a human transcriber or through automated tools. Transcribing involves listening to the audio or watching the video and writing down what is said, verbatim.
Transcription is the process of turning audio or video files into written documents. This can be done either by a human transcriber or through automated tools. Transcribing involves listening to the audio or watching the video and writing down what is said, verbatim.This is similar to taking meeting minutes; someone needs to listen carefully and record all of the important points without interjecting their own thoughts (or worse yet, daydreaming). The transcriptionist's job is to capture everything that was said so that others can read it and understand the conversation perfectly.	transcription	Using a business analogy, explain transcription.	ht	business	1	Transcription is the process of turning audio or video files into written documents. RNA polymerase is an enzyme that catalyzes the synthesis of RNA from DNA templates. RNA polymerase is a type of enzyme that specifically catalyzes the synthesis of RNA from DNA templates.

The ribosome can be thought of as the engine of protein synthesis. It consists of two subunits, a small and a large, which are composed of RNA and proteins. The small subunit interacts with messenger RNA (mRNA) to read the genetic code and assemble the amino acids into a peptide chain. The large subunit joins successive peptide chains to form a protein molecule.	ribosome	Using a business analogy, explain ribosome.	ht	business	1	The ribosome is the engine of protein synthesis. It consists of two subunits, a small and a large, which are composed of RNA and proteins. The small subunit interacts with messenger RNA (mRNA) to read the genetic code and assemble the amino acids into a peptide chain. The large subunit joins successive peptide chains to form a protein molecule.

The hydrophobic effect is similar to the way that oil and water do not mix. The nonpolar molecules (oil) are attracted to each other and repelled by the polar molecules (water), which creates a barrier that prevents the polar molecules from interacting with the nonpolar molecules.	hydrophobic effect	Using a business analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	business	1	The hydrophobic effect is the phenomenon where nonpolar molecules tend to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because polar molecules are attracted to each other and repelled by the nonpolar molecule, which creates a barrier that prevents the polar molecules from interacting with the nonpolar molecules.
In a business setting, the hydrophobic effect can be seen when managers try to keep their departments separate. By keeping the different departments separated, it minimizes interaction and prevents any conflicts from happening. In a similar way, nonpolar molecules tend to aggregate in an aqueous environment because they are repelled by the polar molecules. This creates a barrier that prevents the polar molecules from interacting with the nonpolar molecules.	hydrophobic effect	Using a business analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	business	1	The hydrophobic effect is the phenomenon where nonpolar molecules tend to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because polar molecules are attracted to each other and repelled by the nonpolar molecule, which creates a barrier that prevents the polar molecules from interacting with the nonpolar molecules.
The hydrophobic effect is similar to how people interact in a business setting. In a business, there are people who are attracted to each other (polar molecules) and repelled by the people who they do not like or want to be around (nonpolar molecules). Just as in real life, the polar molecules are trying to get close to each other while the nonpolar molecules are trying to stay away from each other. This creates a barrier that prevents the polar molecules from interacting with the nonpolar molecule, just as happens in an aqueous environment.	hydrophobic effect	Using a business analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	business	1	The hydrophobic effect is the phenomenon where nonpolar molecules tend to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because polar molecules are attracted to each other and repelled by the nonpolar molecule, which creates a barrier that prevents the polar molecules from interacting with the nonpolar molecules.
The hydrophobic effect is like when all of the people in a business are attracted to each other and repelled by the people who are not employed at that company. The nonpolar molecules (the employees) form a barrier and prevent the polar molecules (the customers) from interacting with them.	hydrophobic effect	Using a business analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	business	1	The hydrophobic effect is the phenomenon where nonpolar molecules tend to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because polar molecules are attracted to each other and repelled by the nonpolar molecule, which creates a barrier that prevents the polar molecules from interacting with the nonpolar molecules.
The hydrophobic effect can be explained using the example of two companies that are competing for market share. The first company is a large, well-funded corporation with a strong marketing and sales department. The second company is a small startup with limited resources.The large corporation has a lot of money to spend on advertising and marketing its products. It also has a large sales force that can reach potential customers all over the country. The small startup, on the other hand, doesn't have as much money to spend on advertising or marketing its products. Its sales force is also limited in size and scope.Given these advantages and disadvantages, which company do you think will be more successful in the long run? Chances are, the large corporation will be more successful because it has more resources at its disposal. This analogy can be used to explain the hydrophobic effect: nonpolar molecules (the large corporation) tend to aggregate in an aqueous environment (the market), while polar molecules (the small startup) tend to disperse (i.e., they won't be able to interact with the nonpolar molecule).	hydrophobic effect	Using a business analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	business	1	The hydrophobic effect is the phenomenon where nonpolar molecules tend to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because polar molecules are attracted to each other and repelled by the nonpolar molecule, which creates a barrier that prevents the polar molecules from interacting with the nonpolar molecules.
One analogy to explain the hydrophobic effect is to imagine water as a group of people at a party. The people are all crowded together and talking with each other. Then, one person who doesn't like being around people (hydrophobic) tries to leave the party. They push their way through the crowd, but it's difficult because everyone is holding onto each other.	hydrophobic effect	Using a business analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	business	1	When two substances are mixed together, the hydrophobic (water-hating) molecules will try to get as far away from the water as possible. This is because water is polar, meaning that it has a positive and negative end. The negatively charged end of a water molecule attracts the positively charged end of another molecule. This creates hydrogen bonds between water molecules, which hold them together in clusters. Hydrophobic molecules have no such charge and so they avoid being close to groups of Water molecules.
The hydrophobic effect is similar to how people organize themselves in a business. The people who are good with numbers and finance will be near the front of the office, while those who are more creative will be towards the back. The hydrophobic molecules act similarly; they try to stay away from water because it is polar and they are not.	hydrophobic effect	Using a business analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	business	1	When two substances are mixed together, the hydrophobic (water-hating) molecules will try to get as far away from the water as possible. This creates hydrogen bonds between water molecules, which hold them together in clusters. Hydrophobic molecules have no such charge and so they avoid being close to groups of Water molecules.
If you think of water molecules as people, the hydrophobic effect would be like them all standing in a circle holding hands. The people on the outside of the circle (the hydrophobic molecules) don't want to be close to the water because it's wet and they don't like getting wet.	hydrophobic effect	Using a business analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	business	1	When two substances are mixed together, the hydrophobic (water-hating) molecules will try to get as far away from the water as possible. A mouse is a small, rodent-like creature that is often used as a symbol of the computer. A good analogy to explain mouse to a business student would be to say that it is like the hand on a clock. The mouse pointer (the arrow) moves around the screen and clicks on things in the same way that your hand points and presses buttons on a real-world clock.	mouse	What is a good analogy to explain mouse to a business student?	ht	business	1	A mouse is a small, rodent-like creature that is often used as a symbol of the computer.
Stokes scattering is a bit like sunlight reflecting off of a lake. When the light hits the surface of the water, some is reflected in a direct line back towards the sun. This is called specular reflection. The rest of the light scatters in all directions as it hits small particles on the surface of the water. This scattering is called diffuse reflection.	stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain stokes scattering to a business student?	ht	business	1	When light shines on a surface, some of the light is reflected off the surface in a direct line back towards the source. This is called specular reflection. The rest of the light scatters in all directions as it hits small particles on the surface. This scattering is called diffuse reflection.
Stokes scattering is a lot like light reflecting off of a mirror. The majority of the light will reflect in a direct line back to the source, similar to how when you look in a mirror you see your reflection. However, some light will also scatter in all directions as it hits small particles on the surface. This is just like how when you take a picture in natural sunlight, some parts of the image are brighter than others because they were directly hit by the sun while other parts are darker because they were only illuminated by scattered light.	stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain stokes scattering to a business student?	ht	business	1	When light shines on a surface, some of the light is reflected off the surface in a direct line back towards the source. This is called specular reflection. The rest of the light scatters in all directions as it hits small particles on the surface. This scattering is called diffuse reflection.
Imagine that you are in a room with a bright lightbulb. If you stand directly under the light, you will see a bright spot on the floor. This is because all of the light from the bulb is reflecting off your skin and being directed straight back at you. If, however, you move to one side or another, the amount of reflected light decreases. This is because some of the light is scattering off of objects in the room and hitting your skin diffusely instead of directly.	stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain stokes scattering to a business student?	ht	business	1	When light shines on a surface, some of the light is reflected off the surface in a direct line back towards the source. This is called specular reflection. The rest of the light scatters in all directions as it hits small particles on the surface. This scattering is called diffuse reflection.
Scattering is like when you toss a handful of sand into the air. The larger particles (like sand) will be scattered in all directions as they hit the air. This is called ballistic scattering. Smaller particles (like dust) will be scattered in all directions as they collide with other molecules in the air. This is called diffusion	stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain stokes scattering to a business student?	ht	business	1	When light shines on a surface, some of the light is reflected off the surface in a direct line back towards the source. This is called specular reflection. The rest of the light scatters in all directions as it hits small particles on the surface. This scattering is called diffuse reflection.
Think of light bouncing off a mirror. The reflected light is travelling in a direct line back towards the source. This is like specular reflection. However, when light bounces off other surfaces (like a wall), it scatters in all directions. This is like diffuse reflection.	stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain stokes scattering to a business student?	ht	business	1	When light shines on a surface, some of the light is reflected off the surface in a direct line back towards the source. This is called specular reflection. The rest of the light scatters in all directions as it hits small particles on the surface. This scattering is called diffuse reflection.
Electric forces are like magnets. They are attracted to each other and push away from each other. This is because like charges repel each other, and unlike charges attract each other.	electric forces	Using an analogy, explain electric forces to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Electric forces are like magnets. They are attracted to each other and push away from each other.
Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed on a strip of paper and the different components travel along the paper at different speeds. This allows the components to be separated and identified.Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to a social science student.Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed on a strip of paper and the different components travel along the paper at different speeds. This allows the components to be separated and identified.For example, if you had a mixture of red and blue pens, you could use chromatography to separate them. The red pens would travel along the paper faster than the blue pens, and so they would be separated and identified.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed on a strip of paper and the different components travel along the paper at different speeds. This allows the components to be separated and identified.
Stars spend most of their lives burning hydrogen in their cores. This process is called fusion. As a star uses up its hydrogen, it begins to use helium. This process is called degeneracy. As a star uses up its helium, it begins to use carbon. This process is called nuclear burning. As a star uses up its carbon, it begins to use oxygen. This process is called photodisintegration. As a star uses up its oxygen, it begins to use silicon. This process is called silicon burning. As a star uses up its silicon, it begins to use iron. This process is called nuclear burning. As a star uses up its iron, it begins to use nickel. This process is called nickel burning. As a star uses up its nickel, it begins to use cobalt. This process is called cobalt burning. As a star uses up its cobalt, it begins to use copper. This process is called copper burning. As a star uses up its copper, it begins to use zinc. This process is called zinc burning. As a star uses up its zinc, it begins to use lead. This process is called lead burning. As a star uses up its lead, it begins to use thorium. This process is called thorium burning. As a star uses up its thorium, it begins to use uranium. This process is called uranium burning. As a star uses up its uranium, it begins to use plutonium. This process is called plutonium burning. As a star uses up its plutonium, it begins to use americium. This process is called americium burning. As a star uses up its americium, it begins to use curium. This process is called curium burning. As a star uses up its curium, it begins to use berkelium. This process is called berkelium burning. As a star uses up its berkelium, it begins to use californium. This process is called californium burning. As a star uses up its californium, it begins to use einsteinium. This process is called einsteinium burning. As a star uses up its einsteinium, it begins to use fermium. This process is called fermium burning. As a star uses up its fermium, it begins to use mendelevium. This process is called mendelevium burning. As a star uses up its mendelevium, it begins to use nobelium. This process is called nobelium burning. As a star uses up its nobelium, it begins to use lawrencium. This process is called lawrencium burning. As a star uses up its lawrencium, it begins to use rutherfordium. This process is called rutherfordium burning. As a star uses up its rutherfordium, it begins to use dubnium. This process is called dubnium burning. As a star uses up its dubnium, it begins to use seaborgium. This process is called seaborgium burning. As a star uses up its seaborgium, it begins to use bohrium. This process is called bohrium burning. As a star uses up its bohrium, it begins to use hassium. This process is called hassium burning. As a star uses up its hassium, it begins to use meitnerium. This process is called meitnerium burning. As a star uses up its meitnerium, it begins to use darmstadtium. This process is called darmstadtium burning. As a star uses up its darmstadtium, it begins to use roentgenium. This process is called roentgenium burning. As a star uses up its roentgenium, it begins to use copernicium. This process is called copernicium burning. As a star uses up its copernicium, it begins to use ununtrium. This process is called ununtrium burning. As a star uses up its ununtrium, it begins to use flerovium. This process is called flerovium burning. As a star uses up its flerovium, it begins to use livermorium. This process is called livermorium burning. As a star uses up its livermorium, it begins to use tennessine. This process is called tennessine burning. As a star uses up its tennessine, it begins to use oganesson. This process is called oganesson burning.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using an analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars to a social science student.	lt	social science	0	Stars spend most of their lives burning hydrogen in their cores. Kirchoff's voltage law can be thought of as a way of measuring the "pressure" of a circuit. The law states that the sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero. This means that the pressure of the circuit is always the same, no matter where you measure it.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero. This law is often used in electrical engineering to calculate the voltage of a circuit. It can also be used to find the current in a circuit, and to determine the resistance of a component.
Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are made of proteins and they work by fitting into the spaces around the molecules they are working on. This helps the molecules move around and react with each other. Enzymes are important because they help the body to break down food, digest it, and use the nutrients to keep us healthy.	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to a social science student.	lt	social science	0	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are made of proteins and they work by fitting into the spaces around the molecules they are working on. This helps the molecules move around and react with each other.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a reaction. This step determines the rate of the reaction. For example, imagine that you are in a hurry to get to a party. If you are walking and the slowest person in your group is walking, then you will be the last to arrive at the party. The same is true for a reaction. If the slowest step in the reaction is the rate-determining step, then the reaction will be slow.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a reaction. This step determines the rate of the reaction.
Column chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed in a column and a solvent is passed through the column. The components of the mixture are separated based on their different rates of movement through the column. This is similar to how people are separated in a line based on their speed. The people in the front of the line move faster than the people in the back of the line.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed in a column and a solvent is passed through the column. The components of the mixture are separated based on their different rates of movement through the column.
Resonance hybrid is a model that helps to explain the bonding in molecules. In a resonance hybrid, the electrons are distributed in such a way that the most stable arrangement is achieved. This is done by combining the best of each of the individual models. In social science, this could be seen as a way to combine the best of each individual's ideas to create a more stable and cohesive whole.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to a social science student.	lt	social science	0	Resonance hybrid is a model that helps to explain the bonding in molecules. In a resonance hybrid, the electrons are distributed in such a way that the most stable arrangement is achieved. This is done by combining the best of each of the individual models. In social science, this could be seen as a way to combine the best of each individual's ideas to create a more stable and cohesive whole.
An electroencephalogram is a test that measures the electrical activity of your brain. This activity is measured by electrodes that are placed on your scalp. This test can help doctors understand how your brain is working and can help them diagnose problems.	electroencephalogram	Using an analogy, explain electroencephalogram to a social science student.	lt	social science	0	An electroencephalogram (EEG) is a test that measures the electrical activity of your brain. This activity is measured by electrodes that are placed on your scalp.
Breathing is the process of exchanging gases between the environment and the body's tissues. In frogs, the process of breathing is done through the skin. The frog's skin is thin and moist, which allows oxygen and carbon dioxide to pass through easily. The frog's lungs are used for gas exchange when the frog is in water. When the frog is out of water, it relies on its skin to breathe.Breathing is a bit like the process of drinking water. When you drink water, it goes into your mouth and then down your throat. From there, it goes into your stomach and then into your small intestine. The small intestine is where the water is absorbed into your body. The same thing happens with breathing. When you breathe in, the air goes into your lungs. From there, it goes into your blood vessels and then into your body's tissues. The tissues are where the oxygen is absorbed into your body.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Using an analogy, explain breathing mechanism of frogs to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Breathing is the process of exchanging gases between the environment and the body's tissues. In frogs, the process of breathing is done through the skin. The frog's skin is thin and moist, which allows oxygen and carbon dioxide to pass through easily. The frog's lungs are used for gas exchange when the frog is in water. When the frog is out of water, it relies on its skin to breathe.
A layered architecture for a computer system can be thought of as similar to the way a city is built. The lowest layer, which is closest to the ground, is the foundation on which the higher layers are built. The higher layers provide more abstract services that are used by the people who live in the city. The foundation is necessary for the city to stand, but the higher layers are what make the city livable.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Layered architecture is a way of organizing computer systems in which each layer represents a different type of system function. The lowest layer, which is closest to the hardware, is the foundation on which the higher layers are built. The higher layers provide more abstract services that are used by the applications that run on the system.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as a scarce resource in a chemical reaction. In order for the reaction to proceed, the limiting reactant must be used up first. An excess reactant is a reactant that is not used up in the reaction. It can be thought of as a plentiful resource.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a reactant that is used up first in a chemical reaction. An excess reactant is a reactant that is not used up in a chemical reaction.
The kernel is like the brain of the system. It is responsible for managing the system's resources and ensuring that all the other parts of the system work together. It is like the coordinator of the system, making sure that everything is running smoothly.	operating systems kernel	Using an analogy, explain operating systems kernel to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	The kernel is the most important part of an operating system. It is responsible for managing the system's resources and ensuring that all the other parts of the system work together. It is like the brain of the system, coordinating all the different parts.
Message encoding is the process of transforming a message into a format that can be transmitted. This may involve translating the message into a code that can be sent over a communication channel, such as a telephone line or the internet. For example, imagine that you want to send a message to your friend about a party that you are going to. You might encode the message by texting it to your friend, rather than speaking it aloud. This would help to ensure that the message is not misunderstood or misinterpreted.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to a social science student.	lt	social science	0	Message encoding is the process of transforming a message into a format that can be transmitted. This may involve translating the message into a code that can be sent over a communication channel, such as a telephone line or the internet.

Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen. In other words, glycolysis is the process of turning sugar into energy without using oxygen.	glycolysis	Using an analogy, explain glycolysis to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen.
The median lethal dose is the dose of a substance that is expected to kill half of the people who take it. It is often used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance. This means that if you took a substance with a median lethal dose of 50 mg, and you took 50 mg of that substance, there is a 50% chance that you would die.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a social science student.	lt	social science	0	The median lethal dose is the dose of a substance that is expected to kill half of the people who take it. It is often used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance.
A thermostat is like a traffic light. It helps to regulate the flow of people (or cars) by turning on and off the heating or cooling system.	thermostat	Using an analogy, explain thermostat to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	A thermostat is a device that regulates the temperature of a room or building by turning on or off the heating or cooling system.
Chemical equilibrium is like a balance in your bank account. The balance in your bank account is always the same, no matter what you do with it. The same is true for chemical equilibrium. The concentrations of the reactants and products are always the same, no matter what happens.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Chemical equilibrium is a state in which the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal. This means that the concentrations of the reactants and products do not change over time.
Just-in-time can be thought of as a grocery store that only stocks enough food for the next day or two. This prevents the store from having to waste food by stocking too much, and it also means that the store is always stocked with fresh food.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Just-in-time is a business model that aims to reduce waste by only producing what is needed, when it is needed. This is done by having a close relationship with suppliers and only ordering what is needed for the next production run.
Just as water flows more quickly through a wider pipe than a narrower one, electricity flows more quickly through a wider wire than a narrower one. This is what Ohm's law states: the current through a conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference across the conductor. In other words, the higher the voltage, the more current will flow.	ohm's law	Using an analogy, explain ohm's law to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Ohm's law is a law that states that the current through a conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference across the conductor. In other words, the higher the voltage, the more current will flow. This law is important in social science because it helps to understand how people respond to different types of stimuli. For example, if a person is exposed to a lot of negative stimuli, they may become overwhelmed and have a higher chance of developing a mental illness.
Transcription is like taking a picture of a document with a camera. The document is the DNA, and the picture is the RNA.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Transcription is the process of copying a text from one form to another. In the context of genetics, it is the process of copying the genetic information from DNA to RNA.
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This is because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecules. This interaction causes the nonpolar molecules to be pushed to the periphery of the water droplet, where they are less likely to interact with the water. This is similar to the way that people tend to congregate together in social settings. The people who are more similar to one another (in terms of their nonpolarity) will be pushed to the periphery of the group, while the people who are more polar will be in the center of the group.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	lt	social science	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This is because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecules. This interaction causes the nonpolar molecules to be pushed to the periphery of the water droplet, where they are less likely to interact with the water.

A social science student may not be familiar with the concept of DNA, so an analogy is useful. DNA can be thought of as a blueprint for life. Just like a blueprint tells a builder how to construct a building, DNA tells our cells how to build all the proteins in our bodies. The sequence of bases in DNA determines which proteins are made.	dna	Using an analogy, explain dna to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	DNA is the blueprint for life. It is a long molecule that is twisted into a double helix. The DNA molecule contains the instructions for making all the proteins in your body.

Glycogen can be thought of as a battery that stores energy. The liver and muscles have special cells called glycogen cells that store glycogen. Glucose is a sugar that provides energy for the body's cells. When we eat food, our stomach breaks down the food into glucose and other nutrients. These glucose molecules flow into the blood stream and are carried to the liver and muscles. The liver and muscles use these glucose molecules to make glycogen.	glycogen	Using an analogy, explain glycogen to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Glycogen is an energy storage molecule found in the liver and muscles. It is made up of long chains of glucose molecules. Glucose is a simple sugar that provides energy for the body's cells. Glycogen can be broken down into glucose to provide energy for the body's cells.
Glycogen is to the body what gasoline is to a car. Glycogen is stored in the liver and muscles and can be used as an energy source for the body's cells. Just as gasoline can be used to power a car, glycogen can be used to power the body's cells.	glycogen	Using an analogy, explain glycogen to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Glycogen is an energy storage molecule found in the liver and muscles. It is made up of long chains of glucose molecules. Glucose is a simple sugar that provides energy for the body's cells. Glycogen can be broken down into glucose to provide energy for the body's cells.

Glycogen can be thought of as the body's "fossil fuel." Like coal or oil, glycogen is a stored form of energy that can be broken down and used to power the body's cells. The liver and muscles both contain stores of glycogen, which can be tapped into when needed for energy. Glucose, which is made up of simple sugar molecules, is the main source of energy for the body's cells. When glucose is not available (such as during a famine), the body can break down glycogen into glucose to provide energy.	glycogen	Using an analogy, explain glycogen to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Glycogen is an energy storage molecule found in the liver and muscles. The Golgi apparatus is like a mailroom for a school. It takes information from the different classrooms (dendrites) and packages it into small envelopes (vesicles). These envelopes then travel along the hallways of the school to the main office, where they are delivered and the information is transmitted to other students.	golgi	Using an analogy, explain golgi to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Golgi is a process that takes information from the dendrites of a neuron and packages it into small sacs called vesicles. These vesicles travel along the axon of the neuron to the cell body, where they are released and transmit the information to other neurons.
Golgi is like a postal service. It takes information from the dendrites of a neuron- which are like letters- and packages it into small sacs called vesicles. These vesicles travel along the axon of the neuron to the cell body, where they are released and transmit the information to other neurons.	golgi	Using an analogy, explain golgi to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Golgi is a process that takes information from the dendrites of a neuron and packages it into small sacs called vesicles. He then travels along the street to the central post office (cell body), where he drops off the sacks of information. Like people in a social science class, electrons can be found in different places around the nucleus. Some electrons are closer to the center of the atom than others. The s-orbital diagram shows how the electron is most likely to be found near the nucleus. The p-orbital diagram shows how the electron can be spread out over two different areas near the nucleus. The d-orbital diagram shows how the electron can be spread out over four different areas near	hydrogen electron's orbital	Using an analogy, explain hydrogen electron's orbital to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	As electrons orbit the nucleus of an atom, their positions can be mapped out using orbital diagrams. Each type of orbital diagram represents a different way that these electrons can be arranged around the nucleus. The s-orbital diagram is shaped like a sphere and shows how the electron is most likely to be found near the nucleus. The p-orbital diagram is shaped like a dumbbell and shows how the electron can be spread out over two different areas near the nucleus. The d-orbital diagram is shaped like a four-leaf clover and shows how the electron can be spread out over four different areas near the nucleus
An analogy for electron orbital can be made with planets orbiting the sun. The s-orbital is like Mercury, close to the sun. The p-orbital is like Venus and Earth, both orbiting closer to the sun than Mercury. The d-orbital is like Mars and Jupiter, both orbiting much further from the sun than Mercury.	hydrogen electron's orbital	Using an analogy, explain hydrogen electron's orbital to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	As electrons orbit the nucleus of an atom, their positions can be mapped out using orbital diagrams. The d-orbital diagram is shaped like a four-leaf clover and shows how the electron can be spread out over four different areas near the nucleus

Chromatography is a technique used to separate the different parts of a compound. For example, if you wanted to separate the red and blue ink in a pen, you could use chromatography. The different colors would travel along the paper at different speeds, and they would end up separated on the paper.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	Chromatography is a process that can be used to separate the different parts of a compound. For example, if you wanted to separate the red and blue ink in a pen, you could use chromatography. The different colors would travel along the paper at different speeds, and they would end up separated on the paper.
In a social science experiment, chromatography can be used to separate the different opinions of people. For example, if you wanted to know what people thought about a certain issue, you could use chromatography to separate the opinions. The different opinions would travel along the survey at different speeds, and they would end up separated on the survey.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	Chromatography is a process that can be used to separate the different parts of a compound. Chromatography is like a race. The different molecules in the mixture are represented by runners. The stationary phase is the track and the mobile phase is the water that flows around it. As each runner passes through the track, they interact with it differently. This interaction causes them to move at different speeds and allows for their separation.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Chromatography is a technique used to separate the individual components of a mixture. It can be used to separate molecules, atoms, or ions. The chromatograph is made up of two parts: the stationary phase and the mobile phase. The stationary phase is a solid or liquid that is placed in the column of the chromatograph. The mobile phase is a liquid that flows through the column and carries the individual components of the mixture with it. As each component passes through the column, it interacts differently with both phases. This interaction causes them to move at different speeds and allows for their separation.
Chromatography can be thought of as a kind of “sorting” process. In a sense, it separates different substances or chemicals based on how well they interact with two particular materials – in this case, a liquid and a solid. The end result is that each substance is left traveling down the chromatograph at its own unique pace, which means they can then be easily identified and separated from one another.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Chromatography is a technique used to separate the individual components of a mixture. It can be used to separate molecules, atoms, or ions. The chromatograph is made up of two parts: the stationary phase and the mobile phase. The stationary phase is a solid or liquid that is placed in the column of the chromatograph. The mobile phase is a liquid that flows through the column and carries the individual components of the mixture with it. As each component passes through the column, it interacts differently with both phases. This interaction causes them to move at different speeds and allows for their separation.
The experiment of chromatography is similar to the process of sorting through a deck of cards. The stationary phase would be like a table, and the mobile phase would be like someone shuffling through the cards. As each card passes by the table, it interacts with both the surface and the air around it. This interaction causes them to move at different speeds and allows for their separation.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Chromatography is a technique used to separate the individual components of a mixture. A star's main-sequence lifetime is like the lifespan of a human. Just as all humans are not created equal, with some living to be very old and others dying prematurely, stars also have different lifespans. The larger the star, the longer it will stay on the main sequence because it has more fuel to burn. Smaller stars will exhaust their fuel sooner and leave the main sequence.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using an analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Stars spend the majority of their lives on the main sequence. This is because they fuse hydrogen into helium in their cores, and this process creates energy that powers the star. The more mass a star has, the longer it will stay on the main sequence. So, smaller stars will exhaust their fuel and leave the main sequence sooner than larger stars.
A star's main-sequence lifetime is like the amount of time a typical person spends working at their job. A smaller, less massive star will exhaust its fuel and leave the main sequence sooner than a larger, more massive star. This is because the larger star has more hydrogen to fuse in its core and create energy.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using an analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Stars spend the majority of their lives on the main sequence. This is because they fuse hydrogen into helium in their cores, and this process creates energy that powers the star. The more mass a star has, the longer it will stay on the main sequence. So, smaller stars will exhaust their fuel and leave the main sequence sooner than larger stars.
A star's main sequence lifetime is analogous to the amount of time a person can stay awake without feeling tired. The larger and more massive a star is, the longer it will be able to stay on the main sequence and produce energy. So, smaller stars will eventually wear out and leave the main sequence, just like people who can't stay awake for as long as bigger people.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using an analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Stars spend the majority of their lives on the main sequence. Lysosomes are like the garbage cans of cells. They digest and break down old or damaged proteins, organelles, and other cellular debris. This process is called autolysis. Lysosomes also play a role in cell signaling and can fuse with other vesicles to transfer their contents (e.g., enzymes) to other parts of the cell.	lysosomes	Using an analogy, explain lysosomes to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Lysosomes are the "garbage cans" of cells.
