The nuclear envelope can be thought of as a fence or wall around the nucleus of a cell. This barrier allows some molecules to pass in and out, while keeping larger objects from entering. This is important because it helps protect the genetic material inside the nucleus from damage.	nuclear envelope	Using an analogy, explain nuclear envelope to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The nuclear envelope is the boundary that separates the nucleus of a cell from the rest of the cytoplasm. It is made up of two lipid bilayers, each with embedded proteins, that create a selectively permeable barrier. This allows molecules to move in and out of the nucleus while preventing larger objects from entering. The nuclear envelope also helps protect the genetic material inside the nucleus from damage.
The nuclear envelope can be thought of as a cell's equivalent of a security fence. It separates the nucleus, which contains the genetic material, from the rest of the cytoplasm. This allows molecules to move in and out of the nucleus while preventing larger objects from entering. The nuclear envelope also helps protect the genetic material inside the nucleus from damage.	nuclear envelope	Using an analogy, explain nuclear envelope to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The nuclear envelope is the boundary that separates the nucleus of a cell from the rest of the cytoplasm. It is made up of two lipid bilayers, each with embedded proteins, that create a selectively permeable barrier. This allows molecules to move in and out of the nucleus while preventing larger objects from entering. The nuclear envelope also helps protect the genetic material inside the nucleus from damage.
The nuclear envelope is the equivalent to a border or fence around a country. It is what separates the nucleus (representing the people) from everything else in the cell (the environment). The nuclear envelope allows certain things to pass through it, such as small molecules, while keeping larger objects out. This protects the genetic material inside the nucleus and helps maintain its integrity.	nuclear envelope	Using an analogy, explain nuclear envelope to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The nuclear envelope is the boundary that separates the nucleus of a cell from the rest of the cytoplasm. It is made up of two lipid bilayers, each with embedded proteins, that create a selectively permeable barrier. This allows molecules to move in and out of the nucleus while preventing larger objects from entering. The nuclear envelope also helps protect the genetic material inside the nucleus from damage.
The nuclear envelope can be thought of as a protective barrier around the nucleus of a cell. It is made up of two lipid bilayers, each with embedded proteins, that create a selectively permeable barrier. This allows molecules to move in and out of the nucleus while preventing larger objects from entering. The nuclear envelope also helps protect the genetic material inside the nucleus from damage.	nuclear envelope	Using an analogy, explain nuclear envelope to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The nuclear envelope is the boundary that separates the nucleus of a cell from the rest of the cytoplasm. The nuclear envelope can be thought of as a cell’s security guard. It is responsible for keeping the nucleus and its valuable genetic material safe from harm, while also allowing important molecules to pass in and out. The nuclear envelope is made up of two lipid bilayers, each with embedded proteins. These layers create a selectively permeable barrier, which allows certain molecules to move in and out while preventing larger objects from entering. This allows the nucleus to function effectively despite being enclosed within the rest of the cytoplasm.	nuclear envelope	Using an analogy, explain nuclear envelope to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The nuclear envelope is the boundary that separates the nucleus of a cell from the rest of the cytoplasm. A cell can be thought of as a tiny society, with its own internal rules and regulations that dictate how it functions. The membrane is like the border between two countries, controlling what enters and leaves the cell. The cytoplasm is like the city center, where all the important activities take place. And the DNA is like the Constitution, dictating how the cell should behave and grow.	cell	Using an analogy, explain cell to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A cell is the smallest living unit of an organism. It is made up of a membrane, cytoplasm, and DNA. The cell membrane separates the inside of the cell from its environment and controls what enters and leaves the cell. The cytoplasm contains organelles which perform different functions in the cell such as producing energy or making proteins. The DNA stores genetic information which determines how a particular organism will grow and develop.
A cell can be thought of as a small town. The town has a population (the cells in the organism), a mayor (the nucleus), police officers and firefighters (the organelles), and businesses that provide essential services to the townspeople (ribosomes, mitochondria, etc.). like any small town, each cell is responsible for its own well-being while also contributing to the overall health of the organism.	cell	Using an analogy, explain cell to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A cell is the smallest living unit of an organism. The cytoplasm contains organelles which perform different functions in the cell such as producing energy or making proteins. The DNA stores genetic information which determines how a particular organism will grow and develop.

A cell can be thought of as a small community. It has a boundary (the cell membrane) that separates it from its environment and controls what enters and leaves. The cytoplasm is the main area of the cell where different functions take place, similar to how different parts of a city have different purposes (e.g., business district, residential area, etc.). Capacitance can be thought of as the ability of a material to hold onto electric charge. Just as a jar can hold more water when it is full than when it is empty, a capacitor can store more electric charge when it is fully charged than when it is not.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A capacitor is a device that stores electrical energy in an electric field. It does this by having two metal plates separated by an insulator. The more charge you put on the plates, the more energy the capacitor can store.
A capacitor is like a bucket. You can fill the bucket with water by using a hose. The more water you put in, the higher the level of water will be in the bucket. A capacitor works in a similar way. It has two metal plates that are separated by an insulator. If you put charge on the plates, it will create an electric field between them. This electric field stores energy just like water does in a bucket.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A capacitor is a device that stores electrical energy in an electric field. It does this by having two metal plates separated by an insulator. The more charge you put on the plates, the more energy the capacitor can store.
A capacitor can be thought of as a container for water. The more water that is poured into the container, the higher the water level will become. In the same way, capacitance is a measure of how much electrical charge can be stored in a capacitor.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A capacitor is a device that stores electrical energy in an electric field. It does this by having two metal plates separated by an insulator. The more charge you put on the plates, the more energy the capacitor can store.
A capacitor is like a rubber band. The more you stretch the rubber band, the more potential energy it has. A capacitor is charged by putting electrons on one of the plates. This creates an electric field between the plates. The more charge you put on the plates, the more energy the capacitor can store.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A capacitor is a device that stores electrical energy in an electric field. It does this by having two metal plates separated by an insulator. The more charge you put on the plates, the more energy the capacitor can store.
A capacitor is a bit like a battery – it stores electrical energy. The difference is that a battery does this by using chemicals, while a capacitor uses electric fields. This means that capacitors can store more energy than batteries and they also recharge much faster.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A capacitor is a device that stores electrical energy in an electric field. It does this by having two metal plates separated by an insulator. The more charge you put on the plates, the more energy the capacitor can store.
In a social science context, specialization can be thought of as people fulfilling specific roles within a community in order to achieve common goals. For example, in a work environment some people might be responsible for sales, others for accounting, and still others for customer service. Communication between these different workers is essential so that everyone is aware of their role and what needs to be done in order to meet the team's objectives. In the same way, bacteria within a cell must communicate with each other in order to specialized jobs and keep the cell functioning.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using an analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A single cell is a community of specialized bacteria that each carry out a specific job in order to keep the cell alive and functioning. For example, some bacteria are responsible for digesting food, others produce energy, and still others maintain the cell's structure. In order for these different bacteria to work together efficiently, they must be able to communicate with one another. This communication occurs through chemical signals that allow the cells to share information about what type of jobs need to be done and when they should be done.
A single cell is like a small community of specialized people who each carry out a specific job in order to keep the cell functioning. For example, some people might be responsible for cooking food, others might be responsible for cleaning, and still others might be responsible for managing the finances. In order for these different people to work together efficiently, they must be able to communicate with one another. This communication occurs through verbal or written instructions that allow the cells to share information about what type of jobs need to be done and when they should be done.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using an analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A single cell is a community of specialized bacteria that each carry out a specific job in order to keep the cell alive and functioning. Let's say you're walking around a city block. If you start at any point and walk in any direction, the total distance you will have walked is zero when you return to your starting point. This is because the sum of all the distances between where you started and ended up is zero. Kirchoff's voltage law works in a similar way: it states that the total voltage experienced by electrons as they flow through a circuit is always zero. This allows us to calculate voltages without having to measure them, which can be helpful for troubleshooting electrical problems.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law is a statement that the algebraic sum of voltages around a loop is zero. This means that if you start at any point in a circuit and follow the path of the electrons, the total voltage they experience will be zero when they reach their starting point again. This law is important for understanding how electrical circuits work, because it allows us to calculate the voltages across different parts of a circuit without actually having to measure them.
Kirchoff's Voltage law can be explained using the analogy of water flowing through a pipe. Just as the sum of water pressure at every point in a pipe is zero, so too is the voltage at every point in an electrical circuit equal to zero. This law is important for understanding how electrical circuits work, because it allows us to calculate the voltages across different parts of a circuit without actually having to measure them.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law is a statement that the algebraic sum of voltages around a loop is zero. This means that if you start at any point in a circuit and follow the path of the electrons, the total voltage they experience will be zero when they reach their starting point again. This law is important for understanding how electrical circuits work, because it allows us to calculate the voltages across different parts of a circuit without actually having to measure them.
Kirchoff's Voltage Law states that the sum of all voltages in a loop is zero. This law helps us understand how electrical circuits work by allowing us to calculate voltages across different parts of a circuit without having to measure them. An analogy for this might be if you were walking around your neighborhood and kept track of the total distance walked (the sum of all the distances traveled). You would end up at your starting point again and the total distance would be zero.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law is a statement that the algebraic sum of voltages around a loop is zero. This means that if you start at any point in a circuit and follow the path of the electrons, the total voltage they experience will be zero when they reach their starting point again. This law is important for understanding how electrical circuits work, because it allows us to calculate the voltages across different parts of a circuit without actually having to measure them.
Kirchoff's voltage law is like the law of gravity. It is a fundamental law that always applies, no matter what else happens in the system. Just as we can predict how an object will move based on the force of gravity, we can predict how electrical current will flow through a circuit based on the voltages around it.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law is a statement that the algebraic sum of voltages around a loop is zero. Kirchoff's voltage law is similar to the Law of Gravity. Just as gravity ensures that all objects fall towards the ground, Kirchoff's Voltage Law ensures that all electrical current flows in a specific direction. This law helps us understand how circuits work by allowing us to calculate voltages without having to measure them.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law is a statement that the algebraic sum of voltages around a loop is zero. This means that if you start at any point in a circuit and follow the path of the electrons, the total voltage they experience will be zero when they reach their starting point again. A density wave is similar to a human tsunami. Just as a tsunami moves through the ocean, displacing water and leaving behind evidence of its presence, a density wave moves through an area, displacing people and leaving behind evidence of its presence. The wave can be seen as it moves through the area, and often leaves behind trash, graffiti, or other signs of disturbance.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A density wave is a type of social movement that occurs when people move in groups to occupy a certain space. The wave can be seen as it moves through the area, and often leaves behind evidence of its presence (e.g., trash, graffiti, etc.).
A density wave is a bit like a human tsunami. Just as the waves in the ocean can travel great distances and cause devastation when they crash onto shore, so too can human density waves move through an area, leaving destruction in their wake.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A density wave is a type of social movement that occurs when people move in groups to occupy a certain space. The wave can be seen as it moves through the area, and often leaves behind evidence of its presence (e.g., trash, graffiti, etc.).
A density wave is much like a traditional wave. It starts with one person or group and then spreads to other people or groups until the entire area is covered. Just like in a physical wave, the energy behind a density wave builds as it moves through an area. This can often lead to heightened emotions and excitement among those taking part in the movement.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A density wave is a type of social movement that occurs when people move in groups to occupy a certain space. The wave can be seen as it moves through the area, and often leaves behind evidence of its presence (e.g., trash, graffiti, etc.).
A density wave is a bit like a school of fish. The fish swim together in a pack, and as they move through the water they create a wave that can be seen by observers on the surface. Similarly, people who participate in density waves move together to occupy a certain space. This often leaves behind evidence of their presence (e.g., trash, graffiti, etc.).	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A density wave is a type of social movement that occurs when people move in groups to occupy a certain space. The wave can be seen as it moves through the area, and often leaves behind evidence of its presence (e.g., trash, graffiti, etc.).
A density wave is a type of social movement that occurs when people move in groups to occupy a certain space. The wave can be seen as it moves through the area, and often leaves behind evidence of its presence (e.g., trash, graffiti, etc.).Density waves are often started by a small group of people who take action and begin occupying the desired space. As more people join in, the wave grows until it reaches its peak size. After reaching its peak size, the wave begins to dissipate as people leave or get pushed out of the area.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	A density wave is a type of social movement that occurs when people move in groups to occupy a certain space. Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. The different compounds will move through the column at different rates, so they can be separated. This is like when we are trying to separate people into groups based on their interests. We might have a group of people who like sports, and a group of people who like art. These two groups will move through the column at different rates, so they can be separated.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. The mixture is placed in a column and then a solvent (usually water) is pumped through the column. The different compounds in the mixture will move at different rates through the column, so they can be separated.

Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. The mixture is placed in a column and then a solvent (usually water) is pumped through the column. The different compounds in the mixture will move at different rates through the column, so they can be separated. For example, let's say you have a jar of mixed candy. You can use column chromatography to separate the candy into its individual components. The chocolate pieces will move slower than the peppermints, so they will end up on top of the column. The peppermints will move faster than the butterscotches, so they will end up at the bottom of the column.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. A good analogy for dynamic chemical equilibrium in the social science context would be to think of it as a balancing act. Like two groups of kids trying to push each other off a see-saw, if there is equilibrium then neither group wins and both remain balanced. If one group pushes harder than the other, then equilibrium is upset and one side or the other will become dominant. Just like with real children on a see-saw, if too much force is exerted then someone could get hurt. In the political context, this might mean that if one faction becomes too powerful then they can start to oppress others, leading to unrest and possibly violence.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Dynamic chemical equilibrium can be best described as a situation in which two opposing forces are balanced. In the social science context, this might be used to describe a political system in which there is a balance of power between different groups.
In a chemical equilibrium, two opposing forces or chemicals are balanced. In the social science context, this might be used to describe a political system in which there is a balance of power between different groups. For example, in the United States, there is a balance of power between Democrats and Republicans. Each group has equal representation and no one group can dominate the others.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	Dynamic chemical equilibrium can be best described as a situation in which two opposing forces are balanced. In social science, dynamic chemical equilibrium might be used to describe a political system in which there is a balance of power between different groups. This happens when two opposing forces are balanced and it creates a state of equilibrium. The example of a chemical reaction can help illustrate this idea. Imagine you have two jars with chemicals in them that will create a gas when mixed together. If you put one jar on the left side of a scale and one on the right, the scale will be balanced because the force of gravity is equal on both sides. Now imagine if you shook the jars so that they were mixing together. The scale would no longer be balanced because there would now be a force pulling down on the right side due to the gas being created. However, if you stopped shaking the jars and let them settle, eventually they would reach another state of equilibrium in which the force of gravity was again equal on both sides. This is similar to what happens in politics when different groups are competing for power. There can often be periods of upheaval as different groups try to gain an advantage, but eventually they reach a point where there is balance once again	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Dynamic chemical equilibrium can be best described as a situation in which two opposing forces are balanced. A resonance hybrid is like a model of a car that combines the best features of two or more different models of cars. It might be more accurate than any one model, but it's not perfect and there are still some things it can't do. Similarly, in social science, the use of resonance hybrids can help to combine the best features of different theories so that we have a more accurate understanding of complex phenomena.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Resonance hybrid is a model that combines the best features of two or more theories to provide a more accurate description of a phenomenon. It is often used in social science when there are competing theories that cannot be easily reconciled.
When two or more theories about a phenomenon exist and they cannot be easily reconciled, a resonance hybrid model can be used to combine the best features of each theory to provide a more accurate description. This is similar to how different musical notes can be combined to create a chord that sounds better than any individual note. In social science, this can be helpful in understanding complex phenomena where there are multiple factors at work.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Resonance hybrid is a model that combines the best features of two or more theories to provide a more accurate description of a phenomenon. Resonance hybrid can be explained as a type of bond that is stronger than just sharing electrons equally, but not as strong as the bonds in any of the individual Lewis structures. This occurs when two or more Lewis structures for a molecule can be drawn, and each structure has different electron-pair distributions.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	Resonance hybrids are molecules formed by atoms that have multiple electrons in their outer shells. These atoms can share their electrons with other atoms, forming covalent bonds. In some cases, the sharing of electrons can create a special type of bond called a resonance hybrid. This occurs when two or more Lewis structures for a molecule can be drawn, and each structure has different electron-pair distributions. The bonding in the resonance hybrid is not as strong as it would be in any of the individual Lewis structures, but it is stronger than if the atoms just shared electrons equally.

A resonance hybrid is a molecule that is made up of more than one type of atom. These atoms are held together by chemical bonds. The different types of atoms in the molecule will vibrate at their own frequencies. When these frequencies are combined, they create a new frequency that is higher than any of the individual frequencies. This new frequency is what makes the resonance hybrid possible.An analogy for this could be two people singing together in harmony. Their separate voices combine to create a new sound that is greater than the sum of its parts.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule that is made up of more than one type of atom. These atoms are held together by chemical bonds. The different types of atoms in the molecule will vibrate at their own frequencies. When these frequencies are combined, they create a new frequency that is higher than any of the individual frequencies. This new frequency is what makes the resonance hybrid possible.
Resonance hybrid is a bit like when you put two speakers next to each other and play music. The different frequencies from the individual speakers will merge together to create a new frequency that is higher than either of the original frequencies. This new frequency will be heard as one sound, rather than two separate sounds.The same thing happens with resonance hybrids. The different atoms in the molecule will vibrate at their own frequencies. When these frequencies are combined, they create a new frequency that is higher than any of the individual frequencies. This new frequency is what makes the resonance hybrid possible.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule that is made up of more than one type of atom. These atoms are held together by chemical bonds. The different types of atoms in the molecule will vibrate at their own frequencies. When these frequencies are combined, they create a new frequency that is higher than any of the individual frequencies. This new frequency is what makes the resonance hybrid possible.
A resonance hybrid is like a choir. The different types of atoms in the molecule are like the different voices in the choir. When these voices are combined, they create a new frequency that is higher than any of the individual frequencies. This new frequency is what makes the resonance hybrid possible.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule that is made up of more than one type of atom. Think of people in a social setting as particles. The wave mechanical model uses equations to describe the movement and interaction of these particles. This can help to explain things like diffusion, momentum, and energy transfer. Just as waves on the ocean can move objects floating on the surface, social waves (like trends or fads) can impact how people behave and interact with each other.	wave mechanical model	Using an analogy, explain wave mechanical model to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A wave mechanical model is a way of understanding the behavior of particles in a system. The electroencephalogram is like a machine that records the electrical activity of your brain. It can tell us things like how active your brain is, what kind of waves are being produced, and where in your brain this activity is taking place. This information can be really useful for understanding things like how our brains work, how we process information, and how different activities or disorders might affect our brains.	electroencephalogram	Using an analogy, explain electroencephalogram to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	An electroencephalogram is a machine that measures and records the electrical activity of your brain.

An action potential can be thought of as an email being sent from one person to another. The dendrite is like the person's computer and the axon is like the postal service. When the message reaches the terminal buttons, it is released as neurotransmitters into the synapse. These neurotransmitters act like emails going out to other people's computers.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When an action potential is generated by the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. When it reaches the terminal buttons, neurotransmitters are released into the synapse and diffuse across to the next neuron. This process continues until the message reaches its target, such as a muscle or gland cell.
When an action potential is generated by the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. When it reaches the terminal buttons, neurotransmitters are released into the synapse and diffuse across to the next neuron. This process continues until the message reaches its target, such as a muscle or gland cell. In order to explain how this works in terms of social science, let's use an example from everyday life. Imagine that you are at work and your boss sends you an email with instructions for a project that needs to be completed by tomorrow morning. You immediately begin typing up a reply to let your boss know that you will get right on it. As you type, you can see the words appear on your screen almost as if they are traveling down an invisible cable directly from your brain to your fingers. This is very similar to what is happening inside your body when an action potential travels down a neuron to its target cells.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When an action potential is generated by the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. When it reaches the terminal buttons, neurotransmitters are released into the synapse and diffuse across to the next neuron. This process continues until the message reaches its target, such as a muscle or gland cell.
Propagation of an action potential down a neuron can be likened to the spreading of news or information from one person to another. An action potential is generated by the dendrite (the person who first hears the news) and travels down the axon (the line of communication) to the terminal buttons (where the message is sent out). When it reaches the terminal buttons, neurotransmitters are released into the synapse (the social media platform) and diffuse across to the next neuron (the recipient). This process continues until the message reaches its target, such as a muscle or gland cell (the final destination).	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When an action potential is generated by the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. When it reaches the terminal buttons, neurotransmitters are released into the synapse and diffuse across to the next neuron. This process continues until the message reaches its target, such as a muscle or gland cell.
When someone sends a text message, the message starts at their phone and goes through a series of cell towers until it reaches the recipient's phone. The same thing happens with an action potential traveling down a neuron. The impulse starts at the dendrite and travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. When it reaches them, neurotransmitters are released into the synapse and diffuse across to the next neuron. This process continues until the message reaches its target, such as a muscle or gland cell.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When an action potential is generated by the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. When it reaches the terminal buttons, neurotransmitters are released into the synapse and diffuse across to the next neuron. This process continues until the message reaches its target, such as a muscle or gland cell.
An action potential is similar to an electric current. Just as a current flowing through a wire will cause the wire to heat up, an action potential passing down a neuron will make the neuron's membrane hot. This heat causes voltage-gated ion channels in the membrane to open, and ions (charged particles) start to flow into or out of the neuron. The influx of positive ions (such as Na+) makes the inside of the neuron more positive relative to the outside, and this difference in voltage starts to spread quickly along the length of the axon like a wave. This wave of electrical activity is called an action potential.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When an action potential is generated by the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. When it reaches the terminal buttons, neurotransmitters are released into the synapse and diffuse across to the next neuron. This process continues until the message reaches its target, such as a muscle or gland cell.
Breathing is like a process of inhaling and exhaling air to either give or take away oxygen. This is done by the lungs in our chest cavity. When we breathe in, fresh air comes into our lungs through tiny blood vessels called capillaries. The oxygen from the fresh air passes into our bloodstreams and is exchanged for carbon dioxide. The carbon dioxide then goes back out of our bodies when we breathe out, through other blood vessels that lead to the stomach.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Using an analogy, explain breathing mechanism of frogs to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Breathing mechanism of frogs can be explained as the process of inhaling and exhaling air to exchange oxygen for carbon dioxide. This is done by the frog's lungs, which are located in its chest cavity. When the frog inhales, it brings fresh air into its lungs. The air passes through tiny blood vessels called capillaries, where the oxygen is released from the air and exchanged for carbon dioxide. The carbon dioxide then travels back through other blood vessels to the frog's stomach, where it is expelled during exhalation.

The carbon dioxide then travels back through other blood vessels to our stomachs, where it is expelled during exhalation.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Using an analogy, explain breathing mechanism of frogs to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	Breathing mechanism of frogs can be explained as the process of inhaling and exhaling air to exchange oxygen for carbon dioxide. Layered architecture is like the different levels of government in a country. The federal government is at the top, and it oversees all of the state governments. Each state government has its own subdivisions, like counties and cities. And each city has its own subdivisions, like neighborhoods and blocks. Within a neighborhood, you might have houses on one street but not on another. This analogy can be used to explain how layered architectures work: just as each level of government has its own responsibilities, each layer of a computer system has its own responsibilities. The higher levels are responsible for ensuring that the lower levels are functioning properly, and the lower levels are responsible for implementing the functionality that is required by the higher levels.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Layered architecture is a way of organizing computer systems so that programs and data are isolated from each other. This makes it easier to change or update one part of the system without affecting the others. It also makes it easier to protect sensitive data, since unauthorized users can be limited to accessing only certain parts of the system.
Layered architecture is like the different departments in a company. Each department is isolated from the others, so that changes or updates to one department don't affect the other departments. It also makes it easier to protect sensitive data, since unauthorized users can be limited to accessing only certain parts of the system.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Layered architecture is a way of organizing computer systems so that programs and data are isolated from each other. This makes it easier to change or update one part of the system without affecting the others. It also makes it easier to protect sensitive data, since unauthorized users can be limited to accessing only certain parts of the system.
Layered architecture is like the layers of an onion. Each layer can be seen and accessed by looking at the surface, but the deeper layers are hidden from view. You can peel away one layer at a time, or you can cut through the onion to get to all of the layers at once.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Layered architecture is a way of organizing computer systems so that programs and data are isolated from each other. This makes it easier to change or update one part of the system without affecting the others. It also makes it easier to protect sensitive data, since unauthorized users can be limited to accessing only certain parts of the system.
Layered architecture is like the different floors of a building. Each floor can be accessed by anyone who has the right key, but only people on that floor can access the rooms on that floor. The keys to each floor are kept in a locked room on the previous floor. So, if someone wants to get into a particular room on a certain floor, they first need to get into the locked room where the keys for that floor are kept. Then they can use one of those keys to open the door to the desired room.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Layered architecture is a way of organizing computer systems so that programs and data are isolated from each other. This makes it easier to change or update one part of the system without affecting the others. It also makes it easier to protect sensitive data, since unauthorized users can be limited to accessing only certain parts of the system.
Layered architecture is like the different floors of a building. The first floor is the foundation, and it supports the rest of the building. The second floor is built on top of the first, and so on. Each floor can be changed or updated without affecting the other floors. This makes it easier to build and maintain a complex structure.Similarly, layered architecture separates programs and data into different layers. The foundation layer contains basic system functions that all other layers rely on. The next layer up contains more specific functions, and so on. This allows each layer to be changed or updated without affecting the others. It also makes it easier to protect sensitive data, since unauthorized users can be limited to accessing only certain parts of the system	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Layered architecture is a way of organizing computer systems so that programs and data are isolated from each other. A limiting reactant can be thought of as a glass that is only half-full of water. The excess reactant would be the rest of the water that could not fit into the glass.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed from a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the remainder of the chemicals after the limiting reactant has been used up.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as a person who is only capable of doing so much work. For example, if you have two people who are each going to dig a hole, the first person will dig a hole that is 2 feet wide and 1 foot deep. Once that person has stopped digging, the second person will only be able to dig a hole that is 1 foot wide and 1 foot deep because they are limited by the amount of work that the first person has done. The excess reactant would be the extra dirt that is left over after both people have dug their holes.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed from a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the remainder of the chemicals after the limiting reactant has been used up.
Say you are baking a cake and need flour, sugar, eggs, and butter. If you only have enough flour to make half a cake, then the sugar is the limiting reactant. You can still make a cake using just sugar, but it won't be as big as if you had more of all the ingredients. The excess reactant in this case would be eggs and butter - together they would be enough to make a full-sized cake.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed from a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the remainder of the chemicals after the limiting reactant has been used up.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as a scarce resource in a society. For example, suppose there are only 100 jobs in a city and 1000 people apply for them. The limiting reactant would be the number of jobs (100) because no more than that number of people can get jobs. The excess reactant would be the 900 people who don't get jobs.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed from a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the remainder of the chemicals after the limiting reactant has been used up.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as the "bottleneck" in a chemical reaction. Just as a bottleneck in a human population can limit the overall growth of the population, so too can a limiting reactant limit the amount of product that can be formed from a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the remainder of the chemicals after the limiting reactant has been used up.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed from a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the remainder of the chemicals after the limiting reactant has been used up.
In a chemical reaction, the limiting reactant is like the person who is telling a joke and has only one punchline. The excess reactant is like the person who keeps interrupting with his own jokes, preventing the first person from getting laughs.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be produced in a chemical reaction. An excess reactant is a chemical that is present in more than the necessary amount to produce the desired product.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as a bottleneck in the production of a product. The amount of product that can be produced will be limited by the amount of limiting reactant present. An excess reactant is like having too much supply for the demand- it will not produce any additional product, but it may still consume resources needed for producing the desired product.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be produced in a chemical reaction. An excess reactant is a chemical that is present in more than the necessary amount to produce the desired product.
A limiting reactant is like a waiter in a restaurant. The waiter can only serve so many people at one time and if there are more customers than the waiter can handle, then some will not be able to be served. An excess reactant is like having too many waiters in the restaurant. There will be plenty of waiters to serve all the customers and no one will have to go without being served.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be produced in a chemical reaction. An excess reactant is a chemical that is present in more than the necessary amount to produce the desired product.
In any given chemical reaction, there is a certain amount of each reactant that is necessary for the reaction to take place. If you have more of one reactant than the other, then the extra reactant will just sit there and not do anything. This is called an excess reactant. On the other hand, if you don't have enough of one particular reactant, then the reaction won't be able to take place at all and this particular reactant is called a limiting reactant.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be produced in a chemical reaction. An excess reactant is a chemical that is present in more than the necessary amount to produce the desired product.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as a traffic jam on the highway. Cars are trying to get to their destinations, but there is only so much room on the road and too many cars for the space. This causes some cars (the limiting reactants) to not reach their destination while others (the excess reactants) make it to their destinations with ease. In a chemical reaction, the limiting reactant is the chemical that limits how much product can be produced. It's like having only one lane open on a two-lane highway: even if there are more cars than lanes, all the cars will still get through as long as they stay in their lanes. The excess reactants are chemicals that are present in more than necessary amount and they don't affect how much product gets made.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be produced in a chemical reaction. An excess reactant is a chemical that is present in more than the necessary amount to produce the desired product.
In a chemical reaction, the reactants are like people in a room. The products are the things that they produce as a result of their interaction - for example, words or ideas. The limiting reactant is the person who runs out of energy first and can't contribute anymore to the conversation. The excess reactant is the person who's still talking after everyone else has run out of things to say.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	In a chemical reaction, the reactants are the substances that start to change form and the products are the substances that are produced as a result of the reaction. A limiting reactant is a reactant that's used up first in a reaction. The excess reactant is thereactant that's left over after the limiting reactant is gone.
In a reaction, the limiting reactant is like the bread in a sandwich. It's the first thing that gets used up and once it's gone, there's no more bread left. The excess reactant is like the cheese on the sandwich. There's plenty of it and it lasts long after the bread is gone.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	In a chemical reaction, the reactants are the substances that start to change form and the products are the substances that are produced as a result of the reaction. A limiting reactant is a reactant that's used up first in a reaction. The excess reactant is thereactant that's left over after the limiting reactant is gone.
In a reaction, the limiting reactant is like the first person to run out of energy in a race. The excess reactant is like the people who are still running after the first person has finished.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	In a chemical reaction, the reactants are the substances that start to change form and the products are the substances that are produced as a result of the reaction. A limiting reactant is a reactant that's used up first in a reaction. The excess reactant is thereactant that's left over after the limiting reactant is gone.
In a reaction, the reactants are like people who start to change form (by dancing) and the products are like the new people who are produced as a result of the reaction. A limiting reactant is like a person who's used up first in the reaction (and can't dance anymore). The excess reactant is like the other people who are left over after the limiting reactant is gone.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	In a chemical reaction, the reactants are the substances that start to change form and the products are the substances that are produced as a result of the reaction. A limiting reactant is a reactant that's used up first in a reaction. The excess reactant is thereactant that's left over after the limiting reactant is gone.
In a chemical reaction, the reactants are like people who start to change form (for example, they might start dancing). The products are like the people who are produced as a result of the reaction (for example, they might be sweaty and exhausted). A limiting reactant is a person who's used up first in the reaction (in other words, they run out of energy first). The excess reactant is the person who's left over after the limiting reactant is gone.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	In a chemical reaction, the reactants are the substances that start to change form and the products are the substances that are produced as a result of the reaction. A limiting reactant is a reactant that's used up first in a reaction. The excess reactant is thereactant that's left over after the limiting reactant is gone.
Helicase is like a person who can unzip a stuck zipper. The cell needs to be able to access the genetic information inside the DNA in order to create new proteins. Helicase helps to loosen up the strands of DNA so that the cells can use it properly.	helicase	Using an analogy, explain helicase to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Helicase is a protein that helps to unwind DNA strands. It can be thought of as a “unraveler” of the DNA molecule. This is important for cells because it allows them to use the genetic information inside the DNA to create new proteins.
Helicase can be thought of as a “unraveler” of the DNA molecule. This is important for cells because it allows them to use the genetic information inside the DNA to create new proteins. Imagine if you had a very long string, and you wanted to untangle it – helicase would be like the tool that helps to do this. It is essential for cell function, as it allows DNA replication and transcription (the process of reading genes and turning them into proteins) to take place.	helicase	Using an analogy, explain helicase to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Helicase is a protein that helps to unwind DNA strands. Helicase can be thought of as a “unraveler” of the DNA molecule. This is important for cells because it allows them to use the genetic information inside the DNA to create new proteins. Imagine if you had a spool of thread with many loops in it. It would be difficult to use the thread unless it was unwound. The same is true for DNA strands – they are difficult to use if they are tightly wound together. Helicase helps to loosen up these strands, making it easier for cells to access and use the genetic information stored within them.	helicase	Using an analogy, explain helicase to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Helicase is a protein that helps to unwind DNA strands. A process control block is like a bouncer at a club. He checks IDs to make sure that everyone who enters the club is of age and has the right to be there. In the same way, a process control block measures different characteristics of a product as it is being made and compares them to targets set by engineers. If any of the measurements fall outside of acceptable limits, the machine automatically stops so that the issue can be corrected. This ensures that all products are made uniformly and under controlled conditions.	process control block	Using an analogy, explain process control block to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A process control block is a tool used in manufacturing to ensure that products are made consistently and according to specification. The block measures various characteristics of the product as it is being manufactured and compares them to targets set by engineers. If any of the measurements fall outside of acceptable limits, the machine automatically stops so that the issue can be corrected. This ensures that all products are made uniformly and under controlled conditions.
A process control block is like a traffic light. It helps to ensure that cars are moving consistently and under controlled conditions. The traffic light measures the speed of the cars as they approach it and compares it to the target speed set by engineers. If any of the measurements fall outside of acceptable limits, the light automatically turns red so that the issue can be corrected. This ensures that all cars are moving uniformly and under controlled conditions.	process control block	Using an analogy, explain process control block to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A process control block is a tool used in manufacturing to ensure that products are made consistently and according to specification. If any of the measurements fall outside of acceptable limits, the machine automatically stops so that the issue can be corrected. This ensures that all products are made uniformly and under controlled conditions.

Message encoding is the process of translating a message from one form into another. For example, when you send a text message, your phone converts the words you type into a code that can be transmitted over the cellular network. When your recipient receives the message, their phone reverses the process and displays the text on the screen.This analogy might help: Message encoding can be thought of as akin to sending a package through the mail. The words we type are like the address on an envelope - they tell our phones where to find the encoded message inside. Once our phones receive these instructions, they decode them and relay the information contained within back to us in a readable format.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Message encoding is the process of translating a message from one form into another. For example, when you send a text message, your phone converts the words you type into a code that can be transmitted over the cellular network. When your recipient receives the message, their phone reverses the process and displays the text on the screen.

A PSU is like a battery in a car. The AC adapter plugs into the wall outlet and provides power to the device just like the battery in a car provides power to the engine.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of most electronic devices that converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC). It is also responsible for supplying voltage to the device. A PSU usually has an AC adapter that plugs into a standard wall outlet and supplies DC power to the device.
A power supply unit can be thought of as the engine that powers a car. The AC adapter plugs into the wall outlet and provides power to the PSU, which in turn supplies voltage to the device. Just like a car needs gasoline to run, electronic devices need DC power to function.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of most electronic devices that converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC). It is also responsible for supplying voltage to the device. A PSU usually has an AC adapter that plugs into a standard wall outlet and supplies DC power to the device.
A power supply unit (PSU) is like a bridge that helps connect two different parts of a river. In the same way, a PSU helps connect AC power from a wall outlet to DC power inside an electronic device. This allows the device to function properly and receive the correct voltage it needs to operate.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of most electronic devices that converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC). It is also responsible for supplying voltage to the device. A PSU usually has an AC adapter that plugs into a standard wall outlet and supplies DC power to the device.
A power supply unit can be thought of as the heart of a device, supplying it with energy to function. The PSU takes AC current from a wall outlet and converts it into DC current, which is then used to power the device. It is important for the PSU to provide enough voltage to meet the needs of the device, otherwise it may not function correctly or even damage internal components.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of most electronic devices that converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC). It is also responsible for supplying voltage to the device. A PSU usually has an AC adapter that plugs into a standard wall outlet and supplies DC power to the device.
A power supply unit (PSU) is like the heart of a device. It converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), which is what electronic devices need to function. It also supplies voltage to the device, which is necessary for it to operate. A PSU usually has an AC adapter that plugs into a standard wall outlet and provides DC power to the device.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a component of most electronic devices that converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC). It is also responsible for supplying voltage to the device. A PSU usually has an AC adapter that plugs into a standard wall outlet and supplies DC power to the device.

Mice are small, mammalian creatures that live in close association with humans. They were introduced to North America by Europeans, and have thrived in the presence of human buildings and trash. Just as a social science student can learn about someone's age by counting the number of rings in that person's finger, a scientist can learn about a tree's age by counting the number of rings in its trunk. Each ring corresponds to one year of growth, so counting the rings provides an estimate for how old the tree is.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The age of a tree can be determined by counting the number of rings in its trunk. Each ring corresponds to one year of growth.
The number of rings in a tree trunk can be thought of as representing the number of years a person has been alive. Just as you would count how many years you have been alive, a scientist counting tree rings would count each ring to determine the age of the tree.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The age of a tree can be determined by counting the number of rings in its trunk. Each ring corresponds to one year of growth.
The tree's age calculation can be thought of as similar to a social science student's graduation year calculation. Just as each ring in the tree trunk corresponds to one year of growth, each academic year in a student's life corresponds to one ring on their graduation cap. By counting the number of rings on the tree trunk, we can estimate how many years old it is. Similarly, by counting the number of rings on a graduate's cap, we can estimate how many academic years they have completed.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The age of a tree can be determined by counting the number of rings in its trunk. Each ring corresponds to one year of growth.
A social science student might analogy the tree's age calculation to taking attendance in a classroom. Just as each ring on a tree trunk corresponds to one year of growth, each absent mark on a classroom chalkboard corresponds to one day that student was not present. By counting the number of rings (or absent marks), we can estimate how many years the tree has been alive (or how long ago students stopped attending class).	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The age of a tree can be determined by counting the number of rings in its trunk. Glycolysis can be thought of as a process that breaks down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate then enters the mitochondria where it is broken down further to release energy that can be used by the cells	glycolysis	Using an analogy, explain glycolysis to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen. The pyruvate then enters the mitochondria where it is broken down further to release energy that can be used by the cells.

Imagine a tiny basketball bouncing off of a huge wall. Most of the energy from the bounce will be reflected back in the direction it came from. A very small amount will be absorbed by the wall. Now imagine a tennis ball bouncing off of the same wall. The tennis ball has much more energy than the basketball, so it will cause more absorption and less reflection. Finally, imagine a golf ball bouncing off of the wall. The golf ball has even more energy than the tennis ball, so it will cause even more absorption and less reflection. This analogy illustrates how anti-stokes scattering works: photons with more energy are scattered less than photons with less energy.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light or any type of radiation encounters an obstacle, some of the energy is reflected off the surface and some is absorbed by the object. If the object is small compared to the wavelength of light, then most of the light will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Raleigh scattering. If a beam of light passes through an area where there are many small particles, such as smoke or haze, then it will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Rayleigh scattering.Anti-Stokes scattering occurs when a photon collides with an atom and causes the atom to emit another photon. The emitted photon has less energy than the original photon.
If someone throws a rock into a pond, the ripples will move out in all directions. If another person throws a rock into the same pond very close to the first rock, the second ripple will be bigger than the first ripple. This is because when the first rock hits the water, it creates a lot of small waves that spread out. When the second rock hits the water, it creates one big wave. This analogy explains how anti-stokes scattering works. The original photon (the rock) creates lots of little photons (ripples), and when they hit other atoms they create more photons (bigger waves).	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light or any type of radiation encounters an obstacle, some of the energy is reflected off the surface and some is absorbed by the object. If the object is small compared to the wavelength of light, then most of the light will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Raleigh scattering. If a beam of light passes through an area where there are many small particles, such as smoke or haze, then it will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Rayleigh scattering.Anti-Stokes scattering occurs when a photon collides with an atom and causes the atom to emit another photon. The emitted photon has less energy than the original photon.
Anti-Stokes scattering is like when two people are talking and one person interrupts the other. The first person might speak louder to be heard over the second person, but this will only make matters worse because it will be harder for the second person to hear what the first person is saying. In the same way, anti-Stokes scattering makes it harder for photons to pass through an area where there are many small particles.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light or any type of radiation encounters an obstacle, some of the energy is reflected off the surface and some is absorbed by the object. If the object is small compared to the wavelength of light, then most of the light will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Raleigh scattering. If a beam of light passes through an area where there are many small particles, such as smoke or haze, then it will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Rayleigh scattering.Anti-Stokes scattering occurs when a photon collides with an atom and causes the atom to emit another photon. The emitted photon has less energy than the original photon.
One analogy to help explain anti-Stokes scattering is the rippling of water when a pebble is thrown into a pond. When the stone hits the surface of the water, it creates waves that ripple out in all directions. The smaller and more numerous the stones on the bottom of the pond, the more diffuse and random these waves will be. This is similar to what happens with light when it encounters an obstacle: some energy is reflected off and some is absorbed by the object. If there are many small particles (like smoke or haze), then much of the light will be scattered in all directions, just like in Rayleigh scattering.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light or any type of radiation encounters an obstacle, some of the energy is reflected off the surface and some is absorbed by the object. If the object is small compared to the wavelength of light, then most of the light will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Raleigh scattering. If a beam of light passes through an area where there are many small particles, such as smoke or haze, then it will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Rayleigh scattering.Anti-Stokes scattering occurs when a photon collides with an atom and causes the atom to emit another photon. The emitted photon has less energy than the original photon.
When two cars collide, one is usually more damaged than the other. In a similar way, when a photon collides with an atom, the atom is usually more damaged than the photon. When an atom absorbs a photon, it becomes excited and can emit another photon. The emitted photon has less energy than the original photon. This process of atoms absorbing and emitting photons is called anti-stokes scattering.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light or any type of radiation encounters an obstacle, some of the energy is reflected off the surface and some is absorbed by the object. If the object is small compared to the wavelength of light, then most of the light will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Raleigh scattering. If a beam of light passes through an area where there are many small particles, such as smoke or haze, then it will be scattered in all directions. This phenomenon is called Rayleigh scattering.Anti-Stokes scattering occurs when a photon collides with an atom and causes the atom to emit another photon. The emitted photon has less energy than the original photon.
Stokes scattering is like people in a room talking to each other. The smaller the person, the more random their conversation will be. This is why we see a blue sky - tiny oxygen and nitrogen molecules scattered short-wavelength light (blue) to a far greater degree than they scatter long-wavelength light (red).	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Stokes scattering is the phenomenon of light scattering off small particles. The smaller the particle, the more random the scattering will be. This is why we see a blue sky - tiny oxygen and nitrogen molecules scatter short-wavelength light (blue) to a far greater degree than they scatter long-wavelength light (red).
Stokes scattering is a lot like people in a crowd. The more people there are, the more likely it is that someone will bump into you and cause you to scatter. In the same way, smaller particles produce more random scattering than larger ones.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Stokes scattering is the phenomenon of light scattering off small particles. The median lethal dose is the amount of a drug or poison that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance. This means that if you were to take a certain dose of a drug, there is a 50/50 chance that you would die from it.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	The median lethal dose is the amount of a drug or poison that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance.
The median lethal dose is the amount of a drug or poison that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance. This means that if you were to take a certain drug, there is a 50% chance that you would die from taking it, even in small doses.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	The median lethal dose is the amount of a drug or poison that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance.
The median lethal dose is the amount of a drug or poison that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance. In other words, if you were to take a certain drug, and there was a 50% chance that you would die from taking it, then the median lethal dose for that particular drug would be said to be 1mg/kg.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The median lethal dose is the amount of a drug or poison that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance.
The median lethal dose is the amount of a drug or poison that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance. This means that if you put 100 people in a room and give them all different doses of a drug, the median lethal dose is the dose that will kill 50 people. So, while some may die at lower doses and some may survive at higher doses, this measurement gives us an idea of how deadly the drug is on average.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	The median lethal dose is the amount of a drug or poison that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance.

It can be used as a measure of the toxicity of a substance.
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance required to kill 50% of the test population. For example, if a drug has a median lethal dose of 10 grams, then it would take 10 grams of that drug to kill half the people who took it. This means that out of 100 people who take the drug, 50 will die from taking it.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance required to kill 50% of the test population. For example, if a drug has a median lethal dose of 10 grams, then it would take 10 grams of that drug to kill half the people who took it.
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance required to kill 50% of the test population. In other words, it's the point at which half of those exposed will die as a result. To put it in perspective, think about how many milligrams or grams are in a single pill. Now imagine that there were 50 pills in a bottle. The median lethal dose would be equivalent to taking 25 of those pills at once - enough to seriously harm or potentially kill half the people who take them.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance required to kill 50% of the test population. This means that out of 100 people who takes this drug, 50 will die and 50 will not.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance required to kill 50% of the test population. For example, if a drug has a median lethal dose of 10 grams, then it would take 10 grams of that drug to kill half the people who took it.
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance required to kill 50% of the test population. In other words, it's the point at which half of those exposed will die as a result. This number can be helpful in understanding how dangerous a particular drug or toxin might be.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance required to kill 50% of the test population. The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance required to kill 50% of the test population. Just as machines help us do things faster and easier in the real world, enzymes help speed up chemical reactions in the body. They work by attaching to one molecule of a substrate (the thing that is being changed) and then another molecule of the same substrate, creating what is called an enzyme-substrate complex. This complex helps break down the two molecules into smaller pieces, which makes the reaction happen faster.	enzyme mechanism	Using an analogy, explain enzyme mechanism to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions occur in the body. They work by attaching to one molecule of a substrate (the thing that is being changed) and then another molecule of the same substrate, creating what is called an enzyme-substrate complex. This complex helps speed up the reaction between the two molecules by breaking them down into smaller pieces.
