This complex helps speed up the reaction between the two molecules by breaking them down into smaller pieces. Enzymes can be compared to social science students because they both help break things down into smaller pieces. ANOVA is a bit like putting all of the students in your class into two different groups (let's say boys and girls) and then measuring how well they do on a test. Once we have the test scores for each group, we can use ANOVA to see if there is any difference between the two groups. This technique allows us to compare the average score of each group while controlling for things that might affect the test scores (like how smart each student is).	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	One of the most common ways to analyze variance in data is with ANOVA, or Analysis of Variance. This technique can be used when you have two (or more) groups of data that you want to compare. For example, let's say you wanted to know if there was a difference in test scores between boys and girls. You would gather data from a bunch of students, divide them into two groups (boys and girls), and then compare their test scores. ANOVA allows you to do this comparison in a statistically rigorous way.
ANOVA is a bit like taking a group of people and splitting them into two groups, then seeing if there is a difference in how they perform on some task. For example, you might want to know if there is a difference in test scores between boys and girls. You would gather data from a bunch of students, divide them into two groups (boys and girls), and then compare their test scores. ANOVA allows you to do this comparison in a statistically rigorous way.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	One of the most common ways to analyze variance in data is with ANOVA, or Analysis of Variance. This technique can be used when you have two (or more) groups of data that you want to compare. For example, let's say you wanted to know if there was a difference in test scores between boys and girls. You would gather data from a bunch of students, divide them into two groups (boys and girls), and then compare their test scores. ANOVA allows you to do this comparison in a statistically rigorous way.
Suppose you want to know whether men and women differ in their earning power. You could randomly select a group of men and a group of women, ask them how much money they earn, and then compare the two groups. However, this approach would not take into account that men and women might differ in all sorts of ways other than their earnings (e.g., education, experience).An analysis of variance (ANOVA) takes into account these differences by comparing the average earnings for each group with a statistic known as an F-ratio. This ratio tells us how likely it is that the difference in earnings between groups is due to chance alone. In general, if the F-ratio is very small, we can conclude that there is no significant difference between the groups; if it is large, we can conclude that there is a significant difference.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	One of the most common ways to analyze variance in data is with ANOVA, or Analysis of Variance. This technique can be used when you have two (or more) groups of data that you want to compare. For example, let's say you wanted to know if there was a difference in test scores between boys and girls. You would gather data from a bunch of students, divide them into two groups (boys and girls), and then compare their test scores. ANOVA allows you to do this comparison in a statistically rigorous way.
ANOVA is a bit like taking a big group of people and splitting them into smaller groups. Then, you compare how well each of the smaller groups does on some task. ANOVA lets you do this comparison in a statistically rigorous way, so that you can say with confidence whether there is a difference between the groups or not.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	One of the most common ways to analyze variance in data is with ANOVA, or Analysis of Variance. ANOVA is like a tool that helps you compare different groups of data. For example, let's say you wanted to know if there was a difference in test scores between boys and girls. You would gather data from a bunch of students, divide them into two groups (boys and girls), and then compare their test scores using ANOVA. A thermostat can be thought of as a controller or "brain" of the heating and cooling system. It reads the temperature in the room and turns on or off the heating or cooling system to maintain the desired temperature.	thermostat	Using an analogy, explain thermostat to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A thermostat is a device that controls the temperature of a room. It does this by turning on or off the heating or cooling system, depending on the temperature that is set.

The thermostat measures the temperature of the room and compares it to the temperature that has been set. If the room is too warm or too cold, then the thermostat will turn on or off the heating or cooling system, depending on which one is needed.	thermostat	Using an analogy, explain thermostat to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	A thermostat is a device that controls the temperature of a room. Chemical equilibrium can be thought of as a state where two armies are fighting each other and, after some time, they both reach a stalemate. This means that the soldiers on each side stop attacking and start defending. The same analogy can be used for chemical reactions; at equilibrium, the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal, so the concentrations of reactants and products do not change with time.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Chemical equilibrium is a state in which the rates of forward and reverse reactions are equal. This means that the concentrations of reactants and products do not change with time. In order to achieve chemical equilibrium, the reaction must be reversible (i.e., have an equilibrium constant).
Chemical equilibrium is like a balance in your bank account. The amount of money that goes into your account (the number of deposits) is the same as the amount of money that goes out of your account (the number of withdrawals). This means that the balance in your account stays constant over time.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Chemical equilibrium is a state in which the rates of forward and reverse reactions are equal. This means that the concentrations of reactants and products do not change with time. In order to achieve chemical equilibrium, the reaction must be reversible (i.e., have an equilibrium constant).
Chemical equilibrium can be thought of as a state in which two people are equally matched in a fight, so that neither person is able to gain an advantage. In the same way, at chemical equilibrium the rates of forward and reverse reactions are equal, so that the concentrations of reactants and products do not change with time.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Chemical equilibrium is a state in which the rates of forward and reverse reactions are equal. This means that the concentrations of reactants and products do not change with time. In order to achieve chemical equilibrium, the reaction must be reversible (i.e., have an equilibrium constant).
Chemical equilibrium can be thought of as a state in which two forces are equal and opposite, leading to no change. In the context of chemical reactions, this means that the concentrations of reactants and products remain constant over time.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Chemical equilibrium is a state in which the rates of forward and reverse reactions are equal. This means that the concentrations of reactants and products do not change with time. In order to achieve chemical equilibrium, the reaction must be reversible (i.e., have an equilibrium constant).
Chemical equilibrium can be thought of as a state in which two people are equally matched in a fight. Just as the individuals in the fight are not making any progress, neither is the reaction at chemical equilibrium. Neither side is winning or losing.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Chemical equilibrium is a state in which the rates of forward and reverse reactions are equal. Just-in-time can be thought of as an assembly line in a factory. Instead of having workers wait around until they have a full car to work on, just-in-time has them working on individual parts that are then put together to create the finished product. The same idea applies to services: instead of providing all the services up front, just-in-time delivers them as needed so that no resources are wasted.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time is a business model that produces goods or services only when they are needed. This eliminates the need for stockpiling, which can be expensive and wasteful. It also allows companies to respond more quickly to changes in customer demand.
A just-in-time business model is similar to a grocery store that only stocks fresh produce. The store does not have any rotten fruit or vegetables taking up space, and it does not need to worry about selling out of its most popular items. This analogy can be applied to a company that manufactures products. For example, if the demand for a product suddenly increases, the company can quickly respond by manufacturing more units.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time is a business model that produces goods or services only when they are needed. This eliminates the need for stockpiling, which can be expensive and wasteful. It also allows companies to respond more quickly to changes in customer demand.
Just-in-time is like a food delivery service. Instead of having to cook all of your meals in advance, you can have them delivered fresh when you need them. This way, you don't have to waste any food and you can get exactly what you want, when you want it.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time is a business model that produces goods or services only when they are needed. This eliminates the need for stockpiling, which can be expensive and wasteful. It also allows companies to respond more quickly to changes in customer demand.
Just-in-time is like a grocery store that only stocks as much food as it needs at any given time. This prevents the store from wasting money on food that will go bad before it can be sold, and also allows it to quickly adapt to changes in customer demand.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time is a business model that produces goods or services only when they are needed. It also allows the store to respond more quickly to changes in customer demand.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time is a business model that produces goods or services only when they are needed. It also reduces the need for storage space, which can be expensive.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time is a manufacturing strategy that aims to reduce waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. This approach requires close cooperation between suppliers and manufacturers.
Just-in-time can be thought of as a strategy for social science students to use when trying to reduce waste in their own lives. Just as suppliers and manufacturers must work closely together to minimize waste using just-in-time, so too must students take care to coordinate their efforts with others (e.g., classmates, roommates) in order to avoid wasting time and energy. In addition, by being mindful of the resources they are consuming (e.g., time, energy, money), students can ensure that they make the most effective use of them – just as manufacturers seek to do with their materials and supplies.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time is a manufacturing strategy that aims to reduce waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. This approach requires close cooperation between suppliers and manufacturers.

This approach requires close cooperation between suppliers and manufacturers.
Just-in-time can be thought of as a grocery store that only stocks the food that is needed for the day. This eliminates waste and maximizes efficiency.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time is a manufacturing strategy that aims to reduce waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. This approach requires close cooperation between suppliers and manufacturers.
Just-in-time is like a grocery store that only stocks what it needs and when it needs it. This approach eliminates waste by not stocking items that will expire or go bad before they are used. It also means that the store doesn't have to carry as much inventory, freeing up space and money.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time is a manufacturing strategy that aims to reduce waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. Transcription is the process of converting genetic information from DNA to RNA. This occurs in the nucleus of a cell and is necessary for protein synthesis. In other words, transcription is similar to when you take notes during a lecture - it's a way of copying down what's being said so that you can remember it later.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Transcription is the process of converting genetic information from DNA to RNA. This occurs in the nucleus of a cell and is necessary for protein synthesis.
Transcription can be thought of as a translation process, where the genetic code in DNA is converted into instructions that are understandable by proteins. This occurs inside the nucleus of cells, and is necessary for them to create new proteins.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Transcription is the process of converting genetic information from DNA to RNA. This occurs in the nucleus of a cell and is necessary for protein synthesis.
To explain transcription to a social science student, one might use the analogy of a musician reading sheet music. Just as the musician follows the notes on the page to play a song, the genetic information in DNA is "read" by enzymes during transcription to create RNA. This process is necessary for protein synthesis - just as musicians need music to play songs, cells need proteins to function.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Transcription is the process of converting genetic information from DNA to RNA. This occurs in the nucleus of a cell and is necessary for protein synthesis.

Transcription can be thought of as similar to typing up a document on a computer. The DNA is like the original document, and the RNA is like the typed-up version.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Transcription is the process of converting genetic information from DNA to RNA. The genetic information in DNA is like the original handwritten text, and the RNA that is produced as a result of transcription is like the typed-up version. Just as with typing up a document, making mistakes while transcribing can lead to errors (e.g., typos), which might have consequences for the final product (e.g., the protein).	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Transcription is the process of converting genetic information from DNA to RNA. The hydrophobic effect can be thought of as people avoiding each other in a crowded room. The polar water molecules are like the people in the room, constantly attracting and repelling one another. The nonpolar molecules are like the people trying to avoid contact with others, clustering together in isolated pockets.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules are attracted to each other and surround the nonpolar molecules, pushing them away from one another.
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of people who do not like to be around other people (nonpolar molecules) to group together in an environment where there are a lot of people (polar water molecules). Just as the polar water molecules are attracted to each other and push the nonpolar molecules away from one another, so too are people drawn to others like themselves and pushed away from those who are different.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules are attracted to each other and surround the nonpolar molecules, pushing them away from one another.
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency for nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules are attracted to each other and surround the nonpolar molecules, pushing them away from one another. Nonpolar molecules do not have these same attractions to one another, so they tend to clump together.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules are attracted to each other and surround the nonpolar molecules, pushing them away from one another.
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of people who do not like others (nonpolar molecules) to aggregate in an environment where there are many people around them (the aqueous environment). This occurs because the people who do like others (polar water molecules) are attracted to each other and surround the people who don't like others, pushing them away from one another.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules are attracted to each other and surround the nonpolar molecules, pushing them away from one another.
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of people who do not get along well to stay away from each other. Just like nonpolar molecules, these people are repelled by the polar water molecules that surround them and push them apart.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules are attracted to each other and surround the nonpolar molecules, pushing them away from one another.
One way to think about the hydrophobic effect is to imagine a group of people in a room. The people are all talking and interacting with one another, but there is one person in the room who is not interested in talking to anyone. This person will try to stay away from the center of the group where all of the activity is taking place and instead will hang out on the outskirts or even leave the room altogether. This is essentially what happens with nonpolar molecules in an aqueous environment - they try to stay away from the polar water molecules and cluster together on the outside of the group or move out of solution altogether.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecule, pushing it away from the center of the cluster.
The hydrophobic effect can be thought of as analogous to people avoiding contact with others in a crowded room. Nonpolar molecules are like the people who do not want to be around other people, and the polar water molecules are like the people who do want to be around other people. The nonpolar molecule is pushed away from the center of the cluster (just as the person would be pushed away from the center of a crowd), because it is not attracted to or compatible with the polar water molecules.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecule, pushing it away from the center of the cluster.
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecule, pushing it away from the center of the cluster.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecule, pushing it away from the center of the cluster.
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecule, pushing it away from the center of the cluster. In other words, hydrophobic substances try to avoid being near water because they don't like getting wet!	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecule, pushing it away from the center of the cluster.
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of people who do not like to be around others (nonpolar molecules) to stick together in clusters, or groups. This occurs because the people who do want to be around others (polar water molecules) interact more strongly with one another than with the people who do not want to be around others. This pushes the people who do not want to be around others away from the center of the cluster.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to a social science student.	ht	social science	0	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecule, pushing it away from the center of the cluster.
Lysosomes can be thought of as the digestive system of a cell. They digest old or damaged proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids from within the cell. This is similar to how your stomach digests food in order to extract energy and nutrients from it.	lysosome	Explain lysosome using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	A lysosome is a little bag of digestive enzymes that floats around in the cytoplasm of cells. It's kind of like your stomach, except it's tiny enough to fit inside a cell. The lysosomes digest old or damaged proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids from within the cell.
Lysosomes can be thought of as the garbage collectors of a cell. They digest old or damaged proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids from within the cell. This allows the cell to recycle these materials and use them for new purposes.	lysosome	Explain lysosome using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	A lysosome is a little bag of digestive enzymes that floats around in the cytoplasm of cells. Lysosomes are like the recycling center in a city. They break down old or damaged materials so that the cell can reuse them.	lysosome	Explain lysosome using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	A lysosome is a little bag of digestive enzymes that floats around in the cytoplasm of cells. A nucleus is the center of something. In social science, it can be thought of as the center of a family or group. It is the most important part and everything else revolves around it. For example, in a family, the parents are the nucleus and they make all the decisions for the family. They are surrounded by their children and other relatives who all depend on them.	nucleus	Explain nucleus using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	A nucleus is the center of something. In social science, it can be thought of as the center of a family or group. It is the most important part and everything else revolves around it.
The nucleus is the center of a family or group. It is the most important part and everything else revolves around it. For example, in a nuclear family, the father is the nucleus because he provides the most support for his wife and children. In a group of friends, the strongest friendship might be called the nucleus because all other friendships orbit around it.	nucleus	Explain nucleus using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	0	A nucleus is the center of something. The cell membrane can be seen as a border or boundary between two different social groups. It allows things like nutrients and oxygen to enter the group, while keeping toxins and other harmful substances out.	cell membrane	Explain cell membrane using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	0	The cell membrane can be seen as a border or boundary. A capacitor is a device used to store electrical energy. The capacitance of a social group is the total amount of emotional energy that can be stored in the group. This energy can be used to motivate and unite the members of the group, or it can be released as negative emotions such as hatred, anger, and violence. The more emotionally charged a situation becomes, the more capacitance is built up in the group.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	0	The capacitance of a social group is the total amount of emotional energy that can be stored in the group. The more emotionally charged a situation becomes, the more capacitance is built up in the group.

Column chromatography is a bit like Facebook. imagine that your friend list is the mixture of compounds that you want to separate. Facebook's algorithm will sort through all of your friends and determine who you are closest to (who has been most strongly absorbed). It will then place those friends at the top of your newsfeed, while everyone else falls further down the page (or off the page altogether).	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with a material that selectively absorbs certain compounds. The compounds that are most strongly absorbed will travel furthest down the column, while those that are less absorbed will stay closer to the top.
Column chromatography can be thought of as a process that separates people into different social groups. The most popular and influential people will stay at the top of the column, while those who are less popular will move further down. This analogy is imperfect, as some compounds may travel in both directions or stick to the sides of the column, but it provides a basic understanding of how column chromatography works.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with a material that selectively absorbs certain compounds. The compounds that are most strongly absorbed will travel furthest down the column, while those that are less absorbed will stay closer to the top.
Column chromatography can be thought of as a way to separate people into different social "groups" based on their levels of education, income, or other factors. The people who are most strongly associated with a certain factor (e.g. those with the highest level of education) will travel furthest down the column, while those who are less associated with that factor will stay closer to the top.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with a material that selectively absorbs certain compounds. The compounds that are most strongly absorbed will travel furthest down the column, while those that are less absorbed will stay closer to the top.
Column chromatography is like a job interview. The compounds in the mixture are like potential employees, and the column is like the interviewer. The most strongly absorbed compounds (the ones who travel furthest down the column) are like the candidates who impress the interviewer most and get hired. The less strongly absorbed compounds (the ones who stay closer to the top) are like the candidates who don't make such a good impression and don't get hired.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with a material that selectively absorbs certain compounds. The compounds that are most strongly absorbed will travel furthest down the column, while those that are less absorbed will stay closer to the top.
Column chromatography can be thought of as a way to separate people into different social groups. The material that selectively absorbs certain compounds can be thought of as the group's culture, which determines what types of people are attracted to it. The further down the column someone travels, the more they share in the culture of that group.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with a material that selectively absorbs certain compounds. The compounds that are most strongly absorbed will travel furthest down the column, while those that are less absorbed will stay closer to the top.
Column chromatography can be thought of as a way to separate people into different "groups" based on how strongly they are connected to other people in the group. The slower someone moves down the column, the more tightly they are bound to the other people in their group. This allows different groups of people to be separated based on how closely they are connected to each other.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with a material that can selectively adsorb (attach) certain molecules from the mixture. The more tightly a molecule sticks to the adsorbing material, the slower it will move down the column. This allows different molecules in the mixture to be separated based on how strongly they are bound to the adsorbent.
Column chromatography can be thought of as a sorting process. Mixtures of compounds are passed through a column, and the molecules that stick to the column are sorted from those that do not. The more strongly a molecule sticks to the column, the slower it will move down. This allows different molecules in the mixture to be separated based on how tightly they are bound to the adsorbent.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with a material that can selectively adsorb (attach) certain molecules from the mixture. The more tightly a molecule sticks to the adsorbing material, the slower it will move down the column. This allows different molecules in the mixture to be separated based on how strongly they are bound to the adsorbent.
One way to think of column chromatography is as a process that separates people into different “social classes” based on how strongly they are bound to society. The more tightly someone is bound to society, the slower they will move down the social ladder. This allows different people in society to be separated based on how closely they adhere to societal norms.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. Tumor suppressor genes can be thought of as the brakes on a car. Just like a car needs brakes to stop it from going too fast, our cells need tumor suppressor genes to keep them from growing out of control and becoming cancerous. If these genes are not working properly, then the cells can become very dangerous and can spread throughout the body.	tumor suppressor genes	Explain tumor suppressor genes using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	One example of a tumor suppressor gene is the TP53 gene. This gene produces a protein that helps to regulate the growth of cells in the body. If this protein is absent or not functioning properly, then it can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and cancer. Like many other genes, the TP53 gene is inherited from our parents. However, just because we have this gene does not mean that we will definitely develop cancer. Many other factors such as smoking, diet, and exposure to radiation also play a role in whether or not someone develops cancer.
Tumor suppressor genes can be thought of as the “brakes” of the body. They help to regulate cell growth and prevent cancer from developing. If a person does not have any or enough tumor suppressor genes, then it can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and cancer. Just like a car without brake pads, if there is no stopping mechanism then the car will continue going until it crashes. The same is true for cells in the body – if they are not regulated by tumor suppressor genes, they will continue growing out of control until something stops them (like cancer).	tumor suppressor genes	Explain tumor suppressor genes using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	One example of a tumor suppressor gene is the TP53 gene. This gene produces a protein that helps to regulate the growth of cells in the body. If this protein is absent or not functioning properly, then it can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and cancer. Like many other genes, the TP53 gene is inherited from our parents. However, just because we have this gene does not mean that we will definitely develop cancer. Many other factors such as smoking, diet, and exposure to radiation also play a role in whether or not someone develops cancer.
A tumor suppressor gene can be thought of as a “brake” on cell growth. This gene produces a protein that helps to control the rate at which cells grow and divide. If this protein is absent or not functioning properly, then it can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and cancer. Just like many other genes, the tumor suppressor gene is inherited from our parents. However, just because we have this gene does not mean that we will definitely develop cancer. Many other factors such as smoking, diet, and exposure to radiation also play a role in whether or not someone develops cancer.	tumor suppressor genes	Explain tumor suppressor genes using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	One example of a tumor suppressor gene is the TP53 gene. If one member of the group is absent or not working properly, then it can lead to chaos and disorder. Just like tumor suppressor genes, social institutions such as schools, families, and communities also play an important role in regulating our growth and preventing cancer.	tumor suppressor genes	Explain tumor suppressor genes using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	One example of a tumor suppressor gene is the TP53 gene. Breathing is an important life process for all animals, including frogs. Frogs use their lungs to breathe air just like people do. However, frogs also have a special mechanism called buccal breathing that allows them to breathe under water. Buccal breathing works by pumping water in and out of the frog's mouth cavity. This causes a vacuum to form which draws in air from the surrounding water. The air then travels through the frog's throat and into its lungs	breathing mechanism of frogs	Explain breathing mechanism of frogs using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	0	Breathing is an important life process for all animals, including frogs. Frogs use their lungs to breathe air just like people do. However, frogs also have a special mechanism called buccal breathing that allows them to breathe under water. Buccal breathing works by pumping water in and out of the frog's mouth cavity. This causes a vacuum to form which draws in air from the surrounding water. The air then travels through the frog's throat and into its lungs

Frogs use their lungs to breathe air just like people do. However, frogs also have a special mechanism called buccal breathing that allows them to breathe under water. Buccal breathing works by pumping water in and out of the frog's mouth cavity. This causes a vacuum to form which draws in air from the surrounding water. The air then travels through the frog's throat and into its lungs
When a frog inhales, its ribcage expands and pulls in new information (air) into the lungs. The diaphragm muscle also contracts, which pushes down on the stomach and intestines, creating a vacuum that sucks in new information (air). When the frog exhales, the ribcage relaxes and pushes out old information (carbon dioxide-rich air) from the lungs.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Explain breathing mechanism of frogs using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	0	When a frog inhales, its ribcage expands and pulls air into the lungs. In a social group, the limiting reactant is the person who has the least amount of friends. The excess reactant is the person who has the most friends. This analogy can be used to explain how a limited resource (such as friendships) can be distributed in a way that maximizes its use. In this analogy, the limiting reactant would be like a substance that is being consumed at a faster rate than it can be replenished. The excess reactant would be like a substance that is being produced at a slower rate than it is consumed.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	The limiting reactant is the person in a social group who has the least amount of friends. Mice are very similar to humans when it comes to the way they live in social groups. Just like in human society, there is a dominant male and female who lead the group, and all of the other members work together to survive. It is known for its ability to run quickly, and for making squeaking noises. Mice live in colonies of up to 50 individuals, with a dominant male and female at the head of the group. The mice use their speed and agility to protect themselves from predators such as hawks, foxes, and snakes.

If you wanted to know if there was a significant difference between the number of hours males and females spent studying for an upcoming test, you could use Anova. This would allow you to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between the means of the two groups (males and females).	anova	Explain anova using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	An Anova is a statistical analysis tool that can be used to compare the means of two or more groups. It stands for “Analysis of Variance” and it allows researchers to determine if there is a significant difference in the means of the groups being compared. This test is often used in social science research, such as studies on human behavior.

Imagine that you are a sociologist who is interested in understanding the differences in attitudes between people who live in big cities and those who live in small towns. You might gather data on people's attitudes towards, say, public transportation. You could then break down the variability in these data into within-group (e.g., variation among city dwellers), between-group (e.g., variation among town dwellers), and residual (error) variability. The ANOVA would then calculate how much of the total variability can be explained by group differences. If there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups, it means that at least some of the variation in your data can be attributed to those group differences	anova	Explain anova using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	An ANOVA is a scientific way of testing whether there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups. It does this by breaking down the total variability in the data into three parts: variability within groups, variability between groups, and residual (error) variability. The ANOVA then calculates how much of the total variability can be explained by group differences. If there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups, it means that at least some of the variation in the data can be attributed to those group differences.
Suppose you want to know whether there is a statistically significant difference between the mean IQs of men and women. You could gather a bunch of data on male and female IQs and run an ANOVA, which would tell you how much of the variation in the data can be explained by group differences. If there is a statistically significant difference between the means, it means that at least some of the variation in IQ scores can be attributed to differences between men and women.	anova	Explain anova using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	An ANOVA is a scientific way of testing whether there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups. It does this by breaking down the total variability in the data into three parts: variability within groups, variability between groups, and residual (error) variability. The ANOVA then calculates how much of the total variability can be explained by group differences. If there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups, it means that at least some of the variation in the data can be attributed to those group differences.
Suppose you wanted to know whether there was a statistically significant difference in the average number of friends between people who identified as Democrats and those who identified as Republicans. You could do an ANOVA to find out. The ANOVA would break down the total variability in the data into three parts: variability within groups (the amount of variation that exists within each group), variability between groups (the amount of variation that exists between the two groups), and residual (error) variability (the amount of variation that can't be explained by group differences). The ANOVA would then calculate how much of the total variability can be explained by group differences. If there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups, it means that at least some of the variation in the data can be attributed to those group differences.	anova	Explain anova using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	An ANOVA is a scientific way of testing whether there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups. The ANOVA then calculates how much of the total variability can be explained by group differences. If there is a statistically significant difference between the means of two or more groups, it means that at least some of the variation in the data can be attributed to those group differences.

The ANOVA then calculates how much of the total variability can be explained by group differences. Just-in-time is a theory that suggests groups and organizations function most efficiently when tasks are completed as close to the time they are needed as possible. As an analogy, think of a factory where parts are only produced when they are needed on the assembly line. This would minimize waste and maximize efficiency. In the social sciences, just-in-time also relies on members of the group being able to communicate effectively and work together to achieve common goals.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	In the social sciences, just-in-time is a theory that suggests that groups and organizations function most efficiently when tasks are completed as close to the time they are needed as possible. This means that people only receive information or complete tasks when it is absolutely necessary. Just-in-time also relies on members of the group being able to communicate effectively and work together to achieve common goals.
In the social sciences, just-in-time is a theory that suggests that groups and organizations function most efficiently when tasks are completed as close to the time they are needed as possible. This means that people only receive information or complete tasks when it is absolutely necessary. Just-in-time also relies on members of the group being able to communicate effectively and work together to achieve common goals.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	0	In the social sciences, just-in-time is a theory that suggests that groups and organizations function most efficiently when tasks are completed as close to the time they are needed as possible. This means that people only receive information or complete tasks when it is absolutely necessary. Just-in-time also relies on members of the group being able to communicate effectively and work together to achieve common goals.
A social science analogy for just-in-time would be a classroom where the teacher only provides information to students when they need it and students are able to ask questions and provide feedback immediately. This allows for more efficient learning since people are not overwhelmed with information and can focus on one task at a time. It also allows teachers to modify their teaching methods based on what is working and what is not.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	In the social sciences, just-in-time is a theory that suggests that groups and organizations function most efficiently when tasks are completed as close to the time they are needed as possible. This means that people only receive information or complete tasks when it is absolutely necessary. Just-in-time also relies on members of the group being able to communicate effectively and work together to achieve common goals.
In a social science analogy, just-in-time would be like a football coach who only calls plays when his team is on the field. The coach doesn't spend time during practice planning for potential situations that might never happen; he saves that for game day. Similarly, workers in a just-in-time organization only complete tasks as they are needed and rely on communication and cooperation to get the job done. This allows people to focus on the task at hand without being bogged down by unnecessary distractions.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	1	In the social sciences, just-in-time is a theory that suggests that groups and organizations function most efficiently when tasks are completed as close to the time they are needed as possible. This means that people only receive information or complete tasks when it is absolutely necessary. Just-in-time also relies on members of the group being able to communicate effectively and work together to achieve common goals.
Just-in-time is a theory that suggests groups and organizations should complete tasks as close to the time they are needed as possible. This means people only receive information or complete tasks when it is absolutely necessary. Just-in-time also relies on members of the group being able to communicate effectively and work together to achieve common goals.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a social science analogy.	ht	social science	0	In the social sciences, just-in-time is a theory that suggests that groups and organizations function most efficiently when tasks are completed as close to the time they are needed as possible. Lysosomes are like tiny garbage cans inside of cells. They digest old or damaged proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids. This is similar to how a garbage truck collects trash from people's homes and takes it to a landfill to be disposed of. Lysosomes are like the garbage truck, and the proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids are like the trash.	lysosome	Explain lysosome using an analogy. The median lethal dose can be thought of as the amount of a substance that is lethal to the average person. Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. Just like a machine needs fuel to run, enzymes need a specific molecule called a substrate to help them do their job. The substrate binds to the enzyme, and the two work together to convert one molecule of the substrate into another molecule. This process is called catalysis, and it's what enzymes do to help chemical reactions happen.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	lt	social science	1	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are like tiny robots that help chemical reactions happen in the body.

Column chromatography is a bit like a giant version of the water filter pitcher you might have at home. If you put muddy water into the pitcher, the mud will be filtered out and the clear water will stay in the pitcher. The same thing happens with column chromatography - different compounds are adsorbed to the material at different rates, so they are separated as they travel down the column.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate different compounds in a mixture. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with material that can adsorb the compounds. The different compounds will be adsorbed to the material at different rates, so they will be separated as they travel down the column.
Column chromatography can be thought of as a party where everyone is wearing different colors. If you want to find someone who is wearing green, you would look for the person who is standing out from the rest because they are the only one wearing green. Column chromatography works in a similar way. The material in the column will adsorb the compounds at different rates, so the different compounds will be separated as they travel down the column.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate different compounds in a mixture. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with material that can adsorb the compounds. The different compounds will be adsorbed to the material at different rates, so they will be separated as they travel down the column.
Column chromatography is a bit like people standing in line at the bank. The different compounds in the mixture are like people, and they will be adsorbed to the material at different rates. This means that they will be separated as they travel down the column.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate different compounds in a mixture. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with material that can adsorb the compounds. The different compounds will be adsorbed to the material at different rates, so they will be separated as they travel down the column.
Column chromatography is similar to a person standing at the bottom of a hill and watching as different cars drive past them. The cars will be separated by their color, with each color traveling down the hill at its own unique speed.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an analogy. Column chromatography can be thought of as a kind of party game. Imagine you have a bunch of different kinds of candy in front of you - chocolate, gummy bears, licorice, etc. You want to separate them into piles according to type. One way to do this would be to put all the candies into a large bowl and mix them together. Then, you could take turns pulling out one piece of candy at a time and putting it into a pile for each type. This is basically what column chromatography does - it takes a mixture of compounds and separates them based on how quickly they are adsorbed to the material in the column.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an analogy. Prokaryotic cells are like small villages. They are relatively simple, and everyone does their own thing. There is little organization, and people just sort of go about their business. This makes prokaryotic cells easy to manage and understand.	prokaryotic cell	Explain prokaryotic cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	0	Prokaryotic cells are like small villages. They are relatively simple, and everyone does their own thing. This analogy is suitable for a social science student because it highlights the simplicity of prokaryotic cells and how they lack the complex organizational structures found in eukaryotic cells.	prokaryotic cell	Explain prokaryotic cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	Prokaryotic cells are like small villages. They are relatively simple, and everyone does their own thing. There is little organization, and people just sort of go about their business.
Prokaryotic cells are like small villages. They are relatively simple, and everyone does their own thing. There is little organization, and people just sort of go about their business. This lack of organization can be seen in the way that prokaryotes do not have a defined nucleus or organelles. Instead, the genetic material is spread throughout the cell. Prokaryotes also tend to be smaller than eukaryotic cells, and they don't have as many complex features.	prokaryotic cell	Explain prokaryotic cell using an analogy. Imagine you are in a large room with several friends. Someone turns on a bright light and it shines in your eyes. You might shield your eyes from the light or turn away from it. If you continue to look at the light, you will eventually see spots.Spots happen because when photons enter your eye, they cause electrons to jump up to higher levels in atoms or molecules. When the electrons fall back down, they release energy in the form of new photons. These new photons stimulate other electrons to jump up, and so on. This process creates a chain reaction that spreads out from the original photon like waves crashing against the shoreline	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light shines on a material, some of the photons bounce off and some are absorbed. If a photon is absorbed, it may give up its energy to cause an electron to jump up to a higher level in an atom or molecule. When the electron falls back down to a lower level, it releases energy in the form of a new photon. This process of absorbing and then releasing photons is called fluorescence.If you shine light on something that doesn't have any electrons (like a vacuum), then almost all of the photons will be scattered in random directions. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering because it occurs against the direction of the incoming light beam
Imagine a group of people walking in one direction and being pushed back by another group coming the other way. This is anti-stokes scattering - it's like the opposite of what usually happens.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light shines on a material, some of the photons bounce off and some are absorbed. If a photon is absorbed, it may give up its energy to cause an electron to jump up to a higher level in an atom or molecule. When the electron falls back down to a lower level, it releases energy in the form of a new photon. This process of absorbing and then releasing photons is called fluorescence.If you shine light on something that doesn't have any electrons (like a vacuum), then almost all of the photons will be scattered in random directions. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering because it occurs against the direction of the incoming light beam
One way to think of anti-stokes scattering is as a kind of "reverse" fluorescence. In fluorescence, photons are absorbed and then released in a new direction. With anti-stokes scattering, the incoming photons scatter in random directions and most of the energy is lost. This analogy might be helpful: imagine someone throwing balls into a crowd of people. Most of the balls will be scattered in all different directions, but a few will make their way back to the person who threw them. Anti-stokes scattering is like those few balls that make it back to the person who threw them – it's an extremely inefficient process that sends almost all of the energy away from its source.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light shines on a material, some of the photons bounce off and some are absorbed. If a photon is absorbed, it may give up its energy to cause an electron to jump up to a higher level in an atom or molecule. When the electron falls back down to a lower level, it releases energy in the form of a new photon. This process of absorbing and then releasing photons is called fluorescence.If you shine light on something that doesn't have any electrons (like a vacuum), then almost all of the photons will be scattered in random directions. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering because it occurs against the direction of the incoming light beam
Imagine a group of people in a room. Some are sitting, some are standing, and some are walking around. If you shine a light on the group, most of the photons will be scattered in random directions - this is like anti-stokes scattering. However, if someone stands up or starts to walk across the room, they will absorb more photons and cause more scattering in the direction they are moving.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light shines on a material, some of the photons bounce off and some are absorbed. If a photon is absorbed, it may give up its energy to cause an electron to jump up to a higher level in an atom or molecule. When the electron falls back down to a lower level, it releases energy in the form of a new photon. This process of absorbing and then releasing photons is called fluorescence.If you shine light on something that doesn't have any electrons (like a vacuum), then almost all of the photons will be scattered in random directions. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering because it occurs against the direction of the incoming light beam
Anti-stokes scattering can be thought of as a kind of noise that obscures the signal (incoming light) being observed. Just as background noise in an audio recording makes it difficult to hear the actual conversation, anti-stokes scattering makes it difficult to see the object being illuminated.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light shines on a material, some of the photons bounce off and some are absorbed. If a photon is absorbed, it may give up its energy to cause an electron to jump up to a higher level in an atom or molecule. When the electron falls back down to a lower level, it releases energy in the form of a new photon. This process of absorbing and then releasing photons is called fluorescence.If you shine light on something that doesn't have any electrons (like a vacuum), then almost all of the photons will be scattered in random directions. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering because it occurs against the direction of the incoming light beam
Anti-stokes scattering can be thought of as a molecular game of catch. Suppose there are two people playing catch, and one has a much stronger arm than the other. The person with the stronger arm is going to throw the ball farther and faster than the person with the weaker arm. This is because they have more energy to throw the ball. Anti-stokes scattering works in a similar way. When a photon has enough energy to break one or more molecular bonds within a molecule, it can cause the molecule to rotate faster than it would normally. This is because the photon gives the molecule some extra energy, just like how someone with a strong arm gives their ball an extra push.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light hits a particle, it can be scattered in many directions. Some of this scattering is due to the light interacting with the electric fields of the particles. This type of scattering is known as Thomson scattering. Another type of scattering occurs when a photon interacts with a molecule in such a way that it causes the molecule to rotate. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering. It occurs when a photon has enough energy to break one or more molecular bonds within the molecule.
A good analogy for anti-stokes scattering is a person throwing a rock into a pond. When the rock hits the water, it causes ripples to spread out in all directions. The same thing happens with light when it interacts with a molecule. The light causes the molecule to rotate and spread out in all directions.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light hits a particle, it can be scattered in many directions. Some of this scattering is due to the light interacting with the electric fields of the particles. This type of scattering is known as Thomson scattering. Another type of scattering occurs when a photon interacts with a molecule in such a way that it causes the molecule to rotate. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering. It occurs when a photon has enough energy to break one or more molecular bonds within the molecule.
One way to think about anti-stokes scattering is to imagine a party in which everyone is talking and shouting. If you stand close to the person who is speaking, you can hear them quite clearly. If, however, you move further away from that person, their voice will become softer and harder to hear. This analogy works well for understanding anti-stokes scattering because it occurs when a photon has enough energy to break one or more molecular bonds within the molecule.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light hits a particle, it can be scattered in many directions. Some of this scattering is due to the light interacting with the electric fields of the particles. This type of scattering is known as Thomson scattering. Another type of scattering occurs when a photon interacts with a molecule in such a way that it causes the molecule to rotate. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering. It occurs when a photon has enough energy to break one or more molecular bonds within the molecule.
One example of anti-stokes scattering is when a photon with enough energy breaks one or more molecular bonds within the molecule. This can be thought of as two people pushing against each other. Once one person stops pushing, the other person will start moving in the opposite direction.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light hits a particle, it can be scattered in many directions. Some of this scattering is due to the light interacting with the electric fields of the particles. This type of scattering is known as Thomson scattering. Another type of scattering occurs when a photon interacts with a molecule in such a way that it causes the molecule to rotate. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering. It occurs when a photon has enough energy to break one or more molecular bonds within the molecule.
Imagine a group of friends sitting around a campfire. When one friend stands up to leave, she scatters the fire's light in all directions. The scattering that occurs when she leaves is analogous to Thomson scattering. Now imagine another friend getting up from the fire and running away as fast as she can. The scattering that occurs when she runs away is analogous to anti-stokes scattering.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for a social science student.	ht	social science	1	When light hits a particle, it can be scattered in many directions. Some of this scattering is due to the light interacting with the electric fields of the particles. This type of scattering is known as Thomson scattering. Another type of scattering occurs when a photon interacts with a molecule in such a way that it causes the molecule to rotate. This type of scattering is called anti-stokes scattering. It occurs when a photon has enough energy to break one or more molecular bonds within the molecule.
Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They work by fitting into a specific spot on a molecule and helping it to move or change shape. This makes it easier for the molecules to react with each other and complete the reaction. For example, imagine you have a bunch of Legos® blocks (molecules) and you want to build a house. You need some tiny machines (enzymes) to help you fit the blocks together and complete the house. Without enzymes, building anything would be much harder!	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using an analogy. Glycogen can be thought of as the social security of the body. It is a storage molecule for glucose, which is the body's main source of energy. It is made up of chains of glucose molecules and is stored in the liver and muscles. Glycogen is used to provide energy for the body, especially during exercise. Just as social security is a safety net for people in case of tough times, glycogen is a safety net for the body in case of times of need.	glycogen	Using a social science analogy, explain glycogen.	lt	social science	1	Glycogen is a storage molecule for glucose in the body. Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed on a strip of paper and the different components are then separated by their different rates of travel. This is similar to how people from different social backgrounds are separated by their different rates of travel. They then enter into their working years, where they contribute to society. Finally, they enter into their retirement years, where they enjoy their accomplishments and relax.Stars follow a similar pattern. The Golgi apparatus can be thought of as the "mailroom" of the cell. It is responsible for processing and packaging proteins that are to be exported from the cell. The proteins are first synthesized on the ribosomes and then they are transported to the Golgi apparatus, where they are modified and then packaged into vesicles. The vesicles are then transported to the cell membrane, where they are released into the extracellular environment.	golgi apparatus	Using a social science analogy, explain golgi apparatus.	lt	social science	1	The Golgi apparatus is a cellular organelle that is found in the cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells. It is responsible for the processing and packaging of proteins that are to be exported from the cell. The proteins are first synthesized on the ribosomes and then they are transported to the Golgi apparatus, where they are modified and then packaged into vesicles. The vesicles are then transported to the cell membrane, where they are released into the extracellular environment.

A capacitor is like a social group. It has two metal plates (people) separated by a dielectric material (space). When a voltage is applied (social pressure), the electric field builds up between the plates (people). The capacitor can store a lot of energy in a small space (social cohesion).	capacitance	Using a social science analogy, explain capacitance.	lt	social science	1	A capacitor is a device that stores energy in an electric field. Voltage is a measure of how much potential energy there is between two points in an electrical circuit. It is a measure of how much work can be done per unit of charge. Voltage is like the difference in height between two points in a social science analogy. It is a measure of how much potential energy there is to do work.	voltage	Using a social science analogy, explain voltage.	lt	social science	1	Voltage is the measure of potential energy between two points in an electrical circuit. It is a measure of how much work can be done per unit of charge. Voltage is also known as electrical potential.
Kirchhoff's voltage law is similar to the law of conservation of energy. Just as energy cannot be created or destroyed, the voltage around a closed loop cannot be created or destroyed. It can only be transferred from one component to another.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using a social science analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law.	lt	social science	1	Kirchhoff's voltage law states that the sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero. This law is important in electrical engineering because it allows engineers to calculate the voltage at any point in a circuit by tracing the path of the current.
A density wave is a wave of increased density that moves through a medium. It is created when a disturbance causes the medium to compress on one side and expand on the other. The wave travels until the medium returns to its original state.A density wave can be thought of as a wave of excitement or energy that travels through a population. It is created when something exciting happens and causes the population to compress on one side (those who are excited) and expand on the other (those who are not excited). The wave travels until the population returns to its original state.	nature of a density wave	Using a social science analogy, explain nature of a density wave.	lt	social science	1	A density wave is a wave of increased density that moves through a medium. It is created when a disturbance causes the medium to compress on one side and expand on the other. The wave travels until the medium returns to its original state.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. The rate of the reaction is determined by the rate of the slowest step. This is like when two people are talking to each other. The rate at which they are talking is determined by the rate of the person who is talking the slowest.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using a social science analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction.	lt	social science	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. The rate of the reaction is determined by the rate of the slowest step.
Column chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed in a column and a solvent is passed through the column. The components of the mixture are separated based on their different rates of movement through the column. This is similar to how people are separated in a social setting. People are separated based on their different rates of movement through the column. People who move quickly through the column are separated from people who move slowly through the column.	column chromatography	Using a social science analogy, explain column chromatography.	lt	social science	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. A resonance hybrid is like a group of people who are all friends. Each person in the group has their own individual relationships with each of the other people in the group, but they also share a common relationship with all of the other people in the group. The group as a whole is more stable than any of the individual members.	resonance hybrid	Using a social science analogy, explain resonance hybrid.	lt	social science	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule formed from two or more atoms that are held together by covalent bonds. The atoms share one or more pairs of electrons, and the resulting molecule is more stable than the individual atoms. In a resonance hybrid, the electrons are shared in such a way that the molecule has more than one possible Lewis structure.

Anti-stokes scattering is the process of a person being scattered in the opposite direction of the person who threw them. This occurs when the person who was thrown is heavier than the person who threw them.	anti-stokes scattering	Using a social science analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	lt	social science	0	Anti-stokes scattering is the process of a photon being scattered in the opposite direction of the incident photon. This occurs when the energy of the scattered photon is greater than the energy of the incident photon.
Stokes scattering is the scattering of light or other electromagnetic radiation by small particles in a gas or liquid. The scattering is caused by the collisions of the photons or particles with the atoms or molecules of the gas or liquid. The photons or particles are scattered in all directions and the intensity of the scattered light is reduced.Stokes scattering is similar to the scattering of light by small particles in a social science setting. Just as in a physical setting, the photons or particles are scattered in all directions and the intensity of the scattered light is reduced. This scattering process can be used to measure the size of the particles in a social science setting.	stokes scattering	Using a social science analogy, explain stokes scattering.	lt	social science	1	Stokes scattering is the scattering of light or other electromagnetic radiation by small particles in a gas or liquid. The scattering is caused by the collisions of the photons or particles with the atoms or molecules of the gas or liquid. The photons or particles are scattered in all directions and the intensity of the scattered light is reduced.
The median lethal dose is the dose of a substance that is expected to kill 50% of the population that is exposed to it. This means that if a large group of people were to be exposed to a particular substance, half of them would die at or before a dose of the substance that is equal to the median lethal dose.	median lethal dose	Using a social science analogy, explain median lethal dose.	lt	social science	0	The median lethal dose is the dose of a substance that is expected to kill 50% of the population that is exposed to it.

Anova allows us to determine whether the means of the groups are statistically different from each other.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	lt	social science	1	Anova is a statistical technique used to compare the means of two or more groups. It stands for "analysis of variance."

Just-in-time can be thought of as a way of managing one's social life. Rather than having a large number of friends that may or may not be useful, a person should only have friends that they can rely on when they need them. This reduces the amount of time spent on maintaining relationships that are not beneficial, and eliminates the need to feel embarrassed or rejected by not having friends when they are needed.	just-in-time	Using a social science analogy, explain just-in-time.	lt	social science	1	Just-in-time is a business strategy that aims to improve a company's efficiency by reducing the amount of inventory it holds. The idea is that instead of having a large stockpile of goods that may or may not sell, a company should only produce or order what it needs as it needs it. This reduces the amount of money spent on storage and eliminates the need to dispose of unused inventory.

The genetic code is made up of a sequence of codons, which are the building blocks of DNA. Each codon is made up of three nucleotides, and each nucleotide is represented by a letter. The sequence of codons in a gene is converted into a sequence of amino acids, which are the building blocks of proteins.

The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of people who are not friends to avoid each other. The polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecules. The nonpolar molecules are repelled by the water and tend to aggregate together.	hydrophobic effect	Using a social science analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	lt	social science	0	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in aqueous solutions. This is because the polar water molecules interact more strongly with one another than with the nonpolar molecules. The nonpolar molecules are repelled by the water and tend to aggregate together.
