This causes a change in the activity of the receptor, which in turn causes a change in the activity of the cell.

DNA is like the recipe for a cake. It tells your body how to make all of the proteins it needs to build and maintain you. The sequence of nucleotides in DNA determines which proteins are made, and in what quantities. Just like each baker has her own unique way of making a cake, each person's DNA is different from everyone else's. This is what makes us all unique!	dna	Using a social science analogy, explain dna.	ht	social science	1	DNA is the "genetic blueprint" of an organism. It is a long molecule made up of smaller molecules called nucleotides. The sequence of these nucleotides determines the characteristics of an organism.

The plasma membrane can be thought of as the cell's border patrol. It regulates what substances enter and leave the cell, allowing some things to pass through while blocking others. This is similar to how a nation's border patrol restricts who and what can come into the country, controlling what information (or materials) is allowed to cross into its borders.	plasma membrane	Using a social science analogy, explain plasma membrane.	ht	social science	1	The plasma membrane is the cell's outer boundary. It is a thin sheet of lipid (fat) molecules and proteins that encloses the cell and separates its interior from its environment. The plasma membrane regulates what enters and leaves the cell, allowing some substances to pass through while blocking others.
The plasma membrane can be thought of as a boundary between two countries. It determines what goods and people are allowed to cross the border, and how much control each country has over what goes on within its borders. For example, the plasma membrane allows certain molecules like water and oxygen to pass freely into and out of the cell, while blocking others like sugar or salt. It also helps regulate what goes on inside the cell by controlling which proteins are allowed to enter or leave.	plasma membrane	Using a social science analogy, explain plasma membrane.	ht	social science	1	The plasma membrane is the cell's outer boundary. It is a thin sheet of lipid (fat) molecules and proteins that encloses the cell and separates its interior from its environment. The plasma membrane regulates what enters and leaves the cell, allowing some substances to pass through while blocking others.
The plasma membrane can be thought of as the cell's outer boundary. It is like a fence that surrounds the cell and separates its interior from its environment. The plasma membrane regulates what enters and leaves the cell, allowing some substances to pass through while blocking others.	plasma membrane	Using a social science analogy, explain plasma membrane.	ht	social science	1	The plasma membrane is the cell's outer boundary. It is a thin sheet of lipid (fat) molecules and proteins that encloses the cell and separates its interior from its environment. The plasma membrane regulates what enters and leaves the cell, allowing some substances to pass through while blocking others.
The plasma membrane can be thought of as a boundary between the individual and their social environment. It regulates what information (or substances) passes in and out of the cell, allowing some things to pass while blocking others. Just as with a physical boundary, the plasma membrane can protect the cell from harm or danger (incoming pathogens, for example), while also allowing necessary nutrients and information to enter.	plasma membrane	Using a social science analogy, explain plasma membrane.	ht	social science	1	The plasma membrane is the cell's outer boundary. Just as a border patrol checks the identification of people entering and leaving a country, the plasma membrane controls what substances enter and leave a cell. The plasma membrane is selective about what it allows to pass through; for example, it blocks harmful toxins while allowing essential nutrients to enter. Like a border patrol, the plasma membrane also monitors traffic flow in both directions to make sure everything runs smoothly.	plasma membrane	Using a social science analogy, explain plasma membrane.	ht	social science	1	The plasma membrane is the cell's outer boundary. Lysosomes are like the garbage disposal of the cell - they digest all of the unwanted, broken down materials. This includes proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids.	lysosome	Using a social science analogy, explain lysosome.	ht	social science	1	A lysosome is a sac-like organelle found in the cytoplasm of all cells. It is surrounded by a single membrane and contains enzymes that digest proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids.
Lysosomes can be thought of as the "garbage collectors" of a cell. They digest proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids that are no longer needed by the cell and recycle their components. Lysosomes are also important for cell survival, because they help to destroy harmful toxins and bacteria that enter the cells.	lysosome	Using a social science analogy, explain lysosome.	ht	social science	1	A lysosome is a sac-like organelle found in the cytoplasm of all cells. A chloroplast is analogous to a small business. It is responsible for producing goods (glucose and oxygen) that are necessary for the larger community (the plant cell). It is important for photosynthesis, which is the process that uses sunlight to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen. The chloroplast contains structures called thylakoids, which are where light energy is converted into chemical energy.

Nadph is like a social worker who helps connect people with needed resources. In the electron transport chain, nadh provides electrons to nadph, and nadph transfers them to oxygen. This process helps generate adp from atp, which provides energy for the cell.	nadph	Using a social science analogy, explain nadph.	ht	social science	1	Nadph is a cofactor found in the cytochrome c oxidase complex of the electron transport chain. It is responsible for transporting electrons from nadh to oxygen, and it helps generate adp from atp.
Nadph is like a taxi driver. It transports electrons from nadh to oxygen, and helps generate adp from atp.	nadph	Using a social science analogy, explain nadph.	ht	social science	1	Nadph is a cofactor found in the cytochrome c oxidase complex of the electron transport chain. It is responsible for transporting electrons from nadh to oxygen, and it helps generate adp from atp.

Macrophages are the police of the immune system. They patrol the body for anything that doesn't belong there - like bacteria, viruses, or other cells that are damaged or cancerous. Once they identify something as a threat, they attack and destroy it. This is similar to how police officers patrol cities and towns, looking for criminals and illegal activity. When they find something suspicious, they take action to stop it.	macrophages	Using a social science analogy, explain macrophages.	ht	social science	1	Macrophages are the police of the immune system. Action potentials are a bit like the tweets that people send on Twitter. They are short, simple messages that propagate quickly from one person to another. Just as with tweets, action potentials don't carry a lot of information individually, but they can add up over time to create a more complex message.	action potential	Using a social science analogy, explain action potential.	ht	social science	1	Action potentials are what allow communication between neurons. They are created when an electrical current passes through a neuron, and they propagate down the axon of the neuron. This allows for messages to be sent from one part of the brain to another.
Action potentials are kind of like telephone messages. They allow communication between different parts of the brain.	action potential	Using a social science analogy, explain action potential.	ht	social science	1	Action potentials are what allow communication between neurons. This allows for messages to be sent from one part of the brain to another very quickly.	action potential	Using a social science analogy, explain action potential.	ht	social science	1	Action potentials are what allow communication between neurons. Action potentials can be thought of as the brain's way of sending text messages. Just like a text message requires an electrical current to pass through your phone in order to send the message, action potentials require an electrical current to travel down a neuron in order to communicate a message. And just like with text messages, if there's a problem with the transmission (like poor service), you may not get all of the information that was sent.	action potential	Using a social science analogy, explain action potential.	ht	social science	1	Action potentials are what allow communication between neurons. In the experiment of chromatography, a solvent is used to dissolve the mixture being analyzed. The solution is then poured onto a social media platform (the stationary phase), which can be either public or private. The mobile phase (the users) are then passed over the social media platform, causing the different compounds in the mixture to move at different speeds. This allows each compound to be separated from the others and ultimately identified.	experiment of chromatography	Using a social science analogy, explain experiment of chromatography.	ht	social science	0	In chromatography, a solvent is used to dissolve the mixture being analyzed. The solution is then poured onto a stationary phase, which can be either solid or liquid. The mobile phase (the liquid or gas) is then passed over the stationary phase, causing the different compounds in the mixture to move at different speeds. This allows each compound to be separated from the others and ultimately identified.
Just as different compounds move at different speeds in a chromatography experiment, people with different opinions on a topic will also have varying levels of engagement. This can be represented by the speed of their "migration" across the stationary phase (in this analogy, social media). By measuring how quickly each participant moves across various platforms, researchers can get an idea of which topics generate more or less conversation.	experiment of chromatography	Using a social science analogy, explain experiment of chromatography.	ht	social science	1	In chromatography, a solvent is used to dissolve the mixture being analyzed. The solution is then poured onto a stationary phase, which can be either solid or liquid. This allows each compound to be separated from the others and ultimately identified.
Chromatography is used to separate different compounds in a mixture. It works by using a solvent to dissolve the mixture, and then pouring it onto a stationary phase. The mobile phase (the liquid or gas) is then passed over the stationary phase, causing the different compounds to move at different speeds. This allows each compound to be separated from the others and ultimately identified.	experiment of chromatography	Using a social science analogy, explain experiment of chromatography.	ht	social science	0	In chromatography, a solvent is used to dissolve the mixture being analyzed. This allows each compound to be separated from the others and ultimately identified.
In social science, chromatography can be used to separate people into different groups. Just as an individual's lifespan is determined by their initial health and genetics, a star's main-sequence lifetime is largely determined by its mass. The more massive a star is, the shorter its main-sequence lifetime will be. This is because high-mass stars consume their fuel much more quickly than low-mass stars. As these high-mass stars run out of energy, they collapse under their own weight to form dense objects called black holes.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using a social science analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars.	ht	social science	1	A star's main-sequence lifetime is determined by its initial mass. The more massive a star, the shorter its main-sequence lifetime. Low-mass stars like our sun have long main-sequence lifetimes because they burn hydrogen slowly. High-mass stars consume their fuel much more quickly and exhaust their nuclear reserves in just a few million years. As these high-mass stars run out of energy, they collapse under their own weight to form dense objects called black holes.
The main-sequence lifetime of a star is determined by its initial mass. The more massive a star, the shorter its main-sequence lifetime. Low-mass stars like our sun have long main-sequence lifetimes because they burn hydrogen slowly. High-mass stars consume their fuel much more quickly and exhaust their nuclear reserves in just a few million years. As these high-mass stars run out of energy, they collapse under their own weight to form dense objects called black holes.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using a social science analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars.	ht	social science	0	A star's main-sequence lifetime is determined by its initial mass. The more massive a star, the shorter its main-sequence lifetime. Low-mass stars like our sun have long main-sequence lifetimes because they burn hydrogen slowly. High-mass stars consume their fuel much more quickly and exhaust their nuclear reserves in just a few million years. As these high-mass stars run out of energy, they collapse under their own weight to form dense objects called black holes.
Just as different people have different lifespans, due to differences in their initial characteristics (such as size, health, and genetics), stars also have different lifespans, depending on their mass. Low-mass stars like our sun burn hydrogen slowly and can live for billions of years. High-mass stars consume fuel more quickly and die within a few million years. As these high-mass stars run out of energy, they collapse under their own weight to form dense objects called black holes.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using a social science analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars.	ht	social science	1	A star's main-sequence lifetime is determined by its initial mass. Just as different people have different lifespans, depending on their size and health, so too do stars. The more massive a star is, the shorter its lifetime on the main sequence. This is because it burns through its hydrogen fuel at a faster rate than a smaller star. When all the hydrogen in its core has been used up, the star moves off of the main sequence and enters another stage of life.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using a social science analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars.	ht	social science	1	Stars spend most of their lives on the main sequence, a period of time in which they fuse hydrogen into helium. This process creates energy that makes the star shine. The amount of time a star spends on the main sequence depends on its mass; the more massive a star is, the shorter its lifetime. When all the hydrogen in a star's core has been used up, it moves off the main sequence and enters another stage of life.

It has a positive charge and contains protons and neutrons. The electrons orbit around the nucleus in shells.
Ribosomes are the cells' protein factories. They are made up of RNA and proteins, and they play a critical role in translating the genetic code into proteins. Ribosomes can be found in all living cells, and they vary in size depending on the organism. Just as a factory is responsible for producing goods that are used by society, ribosomes produce proteins that are essential to the cell's functioning.	ribosomes	Using a social science analogy, explain ribosomes.	ht	social science	1	Ribosomes are the cells' protein factories. The golgi apparatus can be thought of as a mailroom in a company. The endoplasmic reticulum is the factory where the products are made, and the golgi apparatus is responsible for getting them ready to be shipped out. It creates a network of tubes that connect the two areas, and sorts and packages the products according to their destination. The vesicles that it produces contain proteins that are ready to be used by the cell or secreted into the environment.	golgi apparatus	Using a social science analogy, explain golgi apparatus.	ht	social science	1	The golgi apparatus performs many functions in the cell, but is most well-known for its role in packaging proteins into secretory vesicles. It does this by first creating a network of protein tubules that reach from the endoplasmic reticulum to the surface of the cell. The proteins passing through this network are modified and sorted according to their destination. Those destined for secretion are packaged into vesicles that bud off from the ends of the tubules.
The golgi apparatus can be thought of as a mailroom in a business. The endoplasmic reticulum is the factory where the products are made, and the golgi apparatus is responsible for getting them ready to ship. It creates a network of tubes that connect the two areas, and sorts and packages the products according to their destination. Those that are destined for shipment are put into vesicles that bud off from the ends of the tubes.	golgi apparatus	Using a social science analogy, explain golgi apparatus.	ht	social science	1	The golgi apparatus performs many functions in the cell, but is most well-known for its role in packaging proteins into secretory vesicles. It does this by first creating a network of protein tubules that reach from the endoplasmic reticulum to the surface of the cell. The proteins passing through this network are modified and sorted according to their destination. Those destined for secretion are packaged into vesicles that bud off from the ends of the tubules.
The golgi apparatus can be compared to a mailroom in a business. The endoplasmic reticulum is like the main office where all of the original work is done. The protein tubules are like the mail delivery system, transporting messages (proteins) from one part of the company to another. And finally, the golgi apparatus is like the mailroom employees who sort and package the messages according to their destinations.	golgi apparatus	Using a social science analogy, explain golgi apparatus.	ht	social science	1	The golgi apparatus performs many functions in the cell, but is most well-known for its role in packaging proteins into secretory vesicles. The golgi apparatus can be thought of as the office of a cell. This is where proteins are processed and packaged for transport from the cell body. The organelle consists of a series of different areas, each with its own specific function in getting the proteins ready for secretion or storage.	golgi apparatus	Using a social science analogy, explain golgi apparatus.	ht	social science	1	A Golgi apparatus is a key organelle in cells that helps to process and package proteins for transport from the cell body. It is named after its Italian discoverer, Camillo Golgi. The organelle consists of a series of flattened, membrane-enclosed sacs and vesicles that collect proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The proteins are modified and then sorted into appropriate packages for secretion or storage.
The Golgi apparatus can be thought of as a mailroom in a company. The ER is the warehouse where products are stored, and the Golgi apparatus is responsible for processing and packaging these products into appropriate sizes and shapes for shipping. It also modifies some of the proteins so that they can be secreted from the cell.	golgi apparatus	Using a social science analogy, explain golgi apparatus.	ht	social science	1	A Golgi apparatus is a key organelle in cells that helps to process and package proteins for transport from the cell body. A vesicle can be thought of as a small 'community' within the cell. This community is used to store and transport materials between different parts of the cell. The contents of the vesicle can be released by either fusing it with the plasma membrane or by breaking it open.	vesicles	Using a social science analogy, explain vesicles.	ht	social science	1	A vesicle is a small sac-like structure within a cell that is used to store and transport cellular materials. Vesicles are formed when the cell membrane pinches off a small section of the cytoplasm. The contents of the vesicle can be released by fusing the vesicle with the plasma membrane or by breaking open the vesicle.
A vesicle can be thought of as a small, personal computer that is used to store and transport information. The contents of the vesicle can be released by fusing the vesicle with the plasma membrane or by breaking open the vesicle.
A vesicle can be seen as a small, autonomous parcel that is used to transport goods or materials within a city. The contents of the vesicle can be released by the sender either by opening it up and allowing the material to spill out into the surrounding area, or by delivering it to its intended destination and letting it merge with whatever receiving structure exists there.	vesicles	Using a social science analogy, explain vesicles.	ht	social science	1	A vesicle is a small sac-like structure within a cell that is used to store and transport cellular materials. Vesicles are formed when the cell membrane pinches off a small section of the cytoplasm. The contents of the vesicle can be released by fusing the vesicle with the plasma membrane or by breaking open the vesicle.

The Golgi body can be thought of as a processing and packaging center for proteins. Just like in a social science context, where various tasks need to be completed in order to produce a final product, the Golgi body synthesizes proteins in the rough endoplasmic reticulum and then transports them to the cis-Golgi network. From here, specific proteins are selected and packaged into vesicles which bud off from the membrane of the Golgi body and travel to their destination within or outside of the cell.	golgi body	Using a social science analogy, explain golgi body.	ht	social science	1	A Golgi body is a cellular organelle which processes and packages proteins for transport within the cell. A capacitor is like a container that can store a certain amount of water. Kirchoff's voltage law states that the total voltage around a closed loop is always 0. This means that the sum of all the voltages in a loop is equal to 0. This law is similar to the principle of conservation of energy, which states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed, it can only be transferred or changed from one form to another. Just like energy, voltage can't be created or destroyed, it can only be transferred or changed from one form to another.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using a social science analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law.	ht	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law states that the algebraic sum of all voltages in a loop is zero. This means that the total voltage around a closed loop is always 0.
Just as in a social science, if there is a loop of money flowing around, the total amount of money will always be 0. Anytime money flows into or out of the system, it has to go somewhere else in order to maintain balance. The same thing happens with electricity- any time voltage enters or leaves a circuit, it has to go somewhere else so that the total voltage remains at 0.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using a social science analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law.	ht	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law states that the algebraic sum of all voltages in a loop is zero. This means that the total voltage around a closed loop is always 0.
Kirchoffs voltage law can be thought of as a social rule that states that the total value of all assets within a closed system is always zero. This means that the total wealth or value within a closed system is always 0.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using a social science analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law.	ht	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law states that the algebraic sum of all voltages in a loop is zero. This means that the total voltage around a closed loop is always 0.
Kirchoff's voltage law is like the social science concept of equilibrium. Just as in equilibrium, when all forces are balanced, the total voltage around a closed loop is always 0. This means that any electrical current flowing through a circuit will always be equal to the sum of all voltages in that circuit.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using a social science analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law.	ht	social science	1	Kirchoff's voltage law states that the algebraic sum of all voltages in a loop is zero. The rate-determining step of a reaction can be thought of as the "social speed" of a reaction. Just as different people have different social speeds, reactions have different rates depending on the step that is most limiting. This step determines how quickly the entire reaction will occur.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using a social science analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction.	ht	social science	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This step determines how quickly the entire reaction occurs.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This step determines how quickly the entire reaction occurs. In social science, this may be analogous to a process that takes a long time to complete, such as changing someone's mind about an issue. If this step is performed more slowly, then it will take longer for the overall change to occur; if it is completed more quickly, then the change will happen sooner.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using a social science analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction.	ht	social science	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This step determines how quickly the entire reaction occurs.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is like the slowest person in a race. This person determines how quickly the race occurs.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using a social science analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction.	ht	social science	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This step determines how quickly the entire reaction occurs.

This step determines how quickly the entire conversation unfolds.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using a social science analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction.	ht	social science	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This step determines how quickly the entire reaction occurs.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This means that it determines how quickly the entire reaction occurs. In other words, if this step is slowed down, then the whole reaction will be slowed down. For example, imagine two people are walking down a sidewalk. If one person walks slowly, then the other person will have to walk slower to keep up with them. The same thing happens with reactions – if one step is slow, then the entire reaction will be slow.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using a social science analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction.	ht	social science	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This step determines how quickly the entire reaction occurs.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the equivalent of getting people in a room to have a conversation. The faster people can enter and leave the room, the more likely it is that a conversation will happen. However, if someone takes forever to enter or leaves the room, then the conversation becomes much less likely.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using a social science analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction.	ht	social science	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This is because the reactants need to collide with each other in order to form the product. The faster the steps leading up to this collision, the more likely it is that the reaction will happen.

Column chromatography can be thought of as a way to sort people into different "groups" based on their similarities and differences. The column is filled with material that selectively adsorbs (attaches to) certain characteristics or attributes of the people passing through it. As each person moves down the column, they are gradually separated from the other people based on how closely their characteristics match those of the adsorbent. At the end of the column, each group will have its own distinct set of characteristics that distinguish it from all the other groups.	column chromatography	Using a social science analogy, explain column chromatography.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is the process of separating a mixture into its component parts by passing it through a long, thin tube packed with material that selectively adsorbs (attaches to) one or more of the mixture's components. The different components are then eluted (extracted) from the column in order of their relative affinity for the adsorbent.

Column chromatography is the process of separating a mixture into its component parts by passing it through a long, thin tube packed with material that selectively adsorbs (attaches to) one or more of the mixture's components. The different components are then eluted (extracted) from the column in order of their relative affinity for the adsorbent. For example, if you wanted to separate a bowl of Skittles into its individual flavors, you could use column chromatography. The different flavors would be eluted from the column in order of their relative affinities for the adsorbent (e.g., red > orange > yellow > green > blue), allowing you to isolate each flavor separately.	column chromatography	Using a social science analogy, explain column chromatography.	ht	social science	1	Column chromatography is the process of separating a mixture into its component parts by passing it through a long, thin tube packed with material that selectively adsorbs (attaches to) one or more of the mixture's components. Resonance hybrids are formed when two or more atoms come together and share their electrons. Just as in a social setting, where people can share ideas and come to a consensus that is better than any individual could have come up with alone, the resonance hybrid is stronger than any of the atomic species would be on its own. The shared electrons create a strong bond between the atoms, similar to how people can form strong relationships by sharing their thoughts and feelings with one another.	resonance hybrid	Using a social science analogy, explain resonance hybrid.	ht	social science	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule formed from two or more atoms that have been joined together by covalent bonds. The atoms in a resonance hybrid are held together by delocalized electrons, which circulate around the atom-pairs in such a way that the whole molecule has an overall lower energy than any of the individual atomic species would have.
A resonance hybrid is like a group of people who are friends. They all interact with each other and have conversations, which causes them to form a bond. This bond is stronger than any of the individual relationships would be on their own.	resonance hybrid	Using a social science analogy, explain resonance hybrid.	ht	social science	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule formed from two or more atoms that have been joined together by covalent bonds. The atoms in a resonance hybrid are held together by delocalized electrons, which circulate around the atom-pairs in such a way that the whole molecule has an overall lower energy than any of the individual atomic species would have.
Resonance hybrid is similar to a social group. In a social group, people come together and interact with each other. They share thoughts and feelings, and they work together to achieve common goals. The individuals in the group are held together by their shared interactions, which create a bond that is stronger than the sum of its parts. Similarly, the atoms in a resonance hybrid are held together by their shared electrons, which create a bond that is stronger than the sum of its parts.	resonance hybrid	Using a social science analogy, explain resonance hybrid.	ht	social science	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule formed from two or more atoms that have been joined together by covalent bonds. A resonance hybrid is like a group of people who have all come together to form one big, happy family. The members of the family are all bound together by strong ties, and they share their love and support for each other. The whole family has an overall lower energy than any of the individual members would have on their own.	resonance hybrid	Using a social science analogy, explain resonance hybrid.	ht	social science	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule formed from two or more atoms that have been joined together by covalent bonds. Just as a resonance hybrid molecule has lower energy than the individual atoms that comprise it, a social science analogy with resonance hybrid would be a society or community that has lower energy than the sum of its individual members. Much like the electrons in a resonance hybrid molecule, the members of a community with resonance hybrid would circulate around each other in such a way that the whole is stronger and more stable than any of the individual parts.	resonance hybrid	Using a social science analogy, explain resonance hybrid.	ht	social science	1	A resonance hybrid is a molecule formed from two or more atoms that have been joined together by covalent bonds. A wave mechanical model can be thought of as a way to describe the behavior of people in a social group. Just as waves spread out from a point source, people in a social group will tend to move away from each other. The amplitude of the wave (or the size of the group) is determined by the potential energy at each point in space (or by the amount of available resources). The phase of the wave (or the direction that people are moving) is determined by the relative position of each person in the group.	wave mechanical model	Using a social science analogy, explain wave mechanical model.	ht	social science	1	A wave mechanical model is used to describe the behavior of a particle in a periodic potential. In this model, the position of the particle is described by a wavefunction, which oscillates with time. The amplitude and phase of the wavefunction are determined by the potential energy at each point in space.
A wave mechanical model is used to describe the behavior of a particle in a periodic potential. In this model, the position of the particle is described by a wavefunction, which oscillates with time. The amplitude and phase of the wavefunction are determined by the social energy at each point in space.Using a social science analogy, explain wave mechanical model.	wave mechanical model	Using a social science analogy, explain wave mechanical model.	ht	social science	1	A wave mechanical model is used to describe the behavior of a particle in a periodic potential. In this model, the position of the particle is described by a wavefunction, which oscillates with time. The amplitude and phase of the wavefunction are determined by the potential energy at each point in space.
A wave mechanical model is like a social map that shows how people move in relation to each other. The map might show the downtown area as a crowded, bustling place, while the suburbs are shown as sparsely populated. In the wave mechanical model, the potential energy of a point in space determines how crowded or busy it is. A high potential energy means that there are many particles nearby, while low potential energy means that there are few particles nearby.	wave mechanical model	Using a social science analogy, explain wave mechanical model.	ht	social science	1	A wave mechanical model is used to describe the behavior of a particle in a periodic potential. In this model, the position of the particle is described by a wavefunction, which oscillates with time. The amplitude and phase of the wavefunction are determined by the potential energy at each point in space.
A wave mechanical model can be thought of as a way of describing the behavior of people in a social setting. Just like waves traveling through water, social waves travel through populations, affecting the behavior of individuals. The amplitude and phase of these waves are determined by the potential energy at each point in space (e.g., how much someone is respected, how popular they are, etc.).	wave mechanical model	Using a social science analogy, explain wave mechanical model.	ht	social science	1	A wave mechanical model is used to describe the behavior of a particle in a periodic potential. In this model, the position of the particle is described by a wavefunction, which oscillates with time. The amplitude and phase of the wavefunction are determined by the potential energy at each point in space.
A wave mechanical model can be used to describe the behavior of a particle in a periodic potential, analogous to how people interact in a social setting. In this model, the position of the particle is described by a wavefunction, which oscillates with time. The amplitude and phase of the wavefunction are determined by the potential energy at each point in space. This analogy can help us understand how particles interact in a social setting by considering their potential energy. Just as different points in space have different potential energies for a particle, different areas of society have different potential energies for people. For example, someone's home has much more potential energy than an area like a shopping mall. Similarly, someone's family has more potential energy than friends they just met. Understanding these differences can help us better understand how people behave in various settings.	wave mechanical model	Using a social science analogy, explain wave mechanical model.	ht	social science	1	A wave mechanical model is used to describe the behavior of a particle in a periodic potential. In this model, the position of the particle is described by a wavefunction, which oscillates with time. The amplitude and phase of the wavefunction are determined by the potential energy at each point in space.
EEG is a measure of the electrical activity of the brain, similar to how heart rate can be measured through an ECG. It can be used to detect abnormalities in brain function, such as seizures.	electroencephalogram	Using a social science analogy, explain electroencephalogram.	ht	social science	1	EEG is a measure of the electrical activity of the brain. It can be used to detect abnormalities in brain function, such as seizures.
An electroencephalogram (EEG) is like a car engine's "check engine light." It is a measure of the electrical activity of the brain. Just as a "check engine light" comes on in a car when there is something wrong with the engine, an EEG can be used to detect abnormalities in brain function, such as seizures.	electroencephalogram	Using a social science analogy, explain electroencephalogram.	ht	social science	1	EEG is a measure of the electrical activity of the brain. EEG is a measure of the electrical activity of the brain. It can be used to detect abnormalities in brain function, such as seizures. This test measures the tiny fluctuations in voltage between electrodes placed on the scalp. These voltages are caused by the synchronized firing of large numbers of neurons within specific areas of the brain.	electroencephalogram	Using a social science analogy, explain electroencephalogram.	ht	social science	0	EEG is a measure of the electrical activity of the brain. Rna transcription is a bit like making a copy of a document. The dna molecule is like the original document, and the rna transcript is like the copy. This happens in the nucleus of cells, and the new rna transcript is then exported to the cytoplasm where it can be used to make proteins.	rna transcription	Using a social science analogy, explain rna transcription.	ht	social science	1	RNA transcription is the process by which a strand of rna is copied from a dna molecule. This occurs in the nucleus of cells, and the new rna transcript is then exported to the cytoplasm where it can be used to make proteins.
Rna transcription can be compared to the process of photocopying a document. The dna molecule is like the original document, and the rna transcript is like the copy that is produced. Just as with photocopying, there may be slight differences between the original document and the copy, due to imperfections in the copying process.	rna transcription	Using a social science analogy, explain rna transcription.	ht	social science	1	RNA transcription is the process by which a strand of rna is copied from a dna molecule. This occurs in the nucleus of cells, and the new rna transcript is then exported to the cytoplasm where it can be used to make proteins.

This occurs in the nucleus of cells, and the new RNA transcript is then exported to the cytoplasm where it can be used to make proteins.	rna transcription	Using a social science analogy, explain rna transcription.	ht	social science	1	RNA transcription is the process by which a strand of rna is copied from a dna molecule. This occurs in the nucleus of cells, and the new rna transcript is then exported to the cytoplasm where it can be used to make proteins.

The new rna transcript is exported to the cytoplasm where it can be used to make proteins, just like the new information in a social network is distributed to other users.	rna transcription	Using a social science analogy, explain rna transcription.	ht	social science	1	RNA transcription is the process by which a strand of rna is copied from a dna molecule. Transcription is the process of copying genetic information from a DNA molecule to a related RNA molecule. During transcription, the DNA double helix is unwound and the hydrogen bonds between complementary base pairs are broken. This exposes single strands of DNA which can be used as templates for building the new RNA strand. Transcription occurs in the cell nucleus, where the enzymes that make RNA are located.	rna transcription	Using a social science analogy, explain rna transcription.	ht	social science	0	In molecular biology, transcription is the process of copying genetic information from a DNA molecule to a related RNA molecule. During transcription, the DNA double helix is unwound and the hydrogen bonds between complementary base pairs are broken. This exposes single strands of DNA which can be used as templates for building the new RNA strand. Transcription occurs in the cell nucleus, where the enzymes that make RNA are located.

Protein translation is the process of taking a set of instructions, similar to those found in an instruction manual, and turning them into something tangible and useful. In the same way that an instruction manual can be used to create a toy or piece of furniture, mRNA can be used to create proteins. The ribosome is like the worker who follows the instructions in the manual and assembles all of the parts necessary to create a functioning product. The amino acids are like the screws, nails, and other pieces that go into making the finished product. And finally, protein translation is like having a completed toy or piece of furniture sitting in your living room.	protein translation	Using a social science analogy, explain protein translation.	ht	social science	1	Protein translation is the process of creating a protein molecule from an mRNA sequence. The ribosome reads the mRNA and assembles amino acids to form a protein chain.
Protein translation can be thought of as a social process in which people come together to create something larger than themselves. The ribosomes reads the mRNA and assembles amino acids to form a protein chain. Just as in society, there are many different parts (amino acids) that come together to create something new and larger (a protein molecule).	protein translation	Using a social science analogy, explain protein translation.	ht	social science	1	Protein translation is the process of creating a protein molecule from an mRNA sequence. The ribosome reads the mRNA and assembles amino acids to form a protein chain.
Translation is similar to a social network. The mRNA sequence is like the text or content on a social media website. The ribosome reads and assembles the amino acids just as people read and assemble comments on a social media website.	protein translation	Using a social science analogy, explain protein translation.	ht	social science	1	Protein translation is the process of creating a protein molecule from an mRNA sequence. The ribosome reads the mRNA and assembles amino acids to form a protein chain.
The process of protein translation can be thought of as a social gathering in which people come together to share ideas. The mRNA acts as the host, providing information about the party. The ribosomes are the guests, reading and assembling the information provided by the mRNA. Amino acids are the attendees, arriving at the party to join in on the fun.	protein translation	Using a social science analogy, explain protein translation.	ht	social science	1	Protein translation is the process of creating a protein molecule from an mRNA sequence. The ribosome reads the mRNA and assembles amino acids to form a protein chain.
Protein translation can be thought of as a social event in which people come together to form a new organization. The mRNA sequence is like the agenda for the meeting, and the amino acids are like the people who attend. The ribosome reads the mRNA and assembles the amino acids according to the instructions given by the sequence. This creates a protein chain that performs specific functions within the cell.	protein translation	Using a social science analogy, explain protein translation.	ht	social science	1	Protein translation is the process of creating a protein molecule from an mRNA sequence. A limiting reactant can be thought of as the "population size" in an equation. The amount of product that can be formed is limited by how many people are available to produce it. The excess reactant is like everyone else who isn't contributing to the production of product.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other chemical present in excess relative to the limiting reactant.
A limiting reactant is like a scarce resource in society. It limits the amount of product that can be formed, just as a limited number of jobs might limit the amount of products that can be produced. The excess reactant is like the unemployed people in our analogy - it's present in excess relative to the limiting reactant.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other chemical present in excess relative to the limiting reactant.
In a social science analogy, the limiting reactant would be like the number of people in a room. The excess reactant would be like the number of chairs in the room. If there are not enough people to fill all of the chairs, then some people will have to stand.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other chemical present in excess relative to the limiting reactant.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as the "x" variable in a mathematical equation. Just as you cannot solve for x if there is not enough information, you cannot produce the desired product if there is not enough of the limiting reactant. The excess reactant is like the number that can be added to both sides of an equation to make it balance - it does not affect the final outcome.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other chemical present in excess relative to the limiting reactant.
In a social science analogy, the limiting reactant would be the amount of time one has to spend on a task. The excess reactant would be the amount of time leftover after spending the allotted time on the task.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other chemical present in excess relative to the limiting reactant.
In a social science analogy, the limiting reactant would be like the amount of money someone has to spend on groceries. The person can only buy so much food no matter how much money is available. The excess reactant would be like the extra money someone has after buying groceries. The kernel can be thought of as the brains of an operating system. It controls all other aspects of the system, including how resources are allocated to programs, managing files and directories, and communication between hardware and software. Additionally, the kernel provides basic security features such as access control lists.	operating systems kernel	Using a social science analogy, explain operating systems kernel.	ht	social science	1	The kernel is the most important component of an operating system because it controls all other aspects of the system. It allocates resources to programs, manages files and directories, and handles communication between hardware and software. The kernel also provides basic security features, such as access control lists.

A limiting reactant can be thought of as the "max headcount" for a party. The number of people that can attend is limited by the amount of space available (the house, in this analogy) and the number of people who RSVP'd (the number of guests). In the reaction analogy, the "space" would be equivalent to the amount of starting material present, while the "number of RSVPs" would be equivalent to how much product is formed.	limiting reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that determines the amount of a product that can be produced. In a reaction, the limiting reactant is the one that becomes exhausted first and limits the amount of product that can be formed.
In a social science analogy, the limiting reactant would be like the amount of money someone has. The more money someone has, the more products they can buy. However, if someone only has a limited amount of money, they will have to be more selective about what products they purchase.	limiting reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that determines the amount of a product that can be produced. The other individuals in the group would then become limited in their ability to interact with that person.	limiting reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that determines the amount of a product that can be produced. The other chemicals involved in the reaction would be like the other people in that person's life. The limiting reactant determines how much product (in this analogy, happiness) can be produced from the reaction (in this analogy, interactions with others). If there is not enough money in the account to cover all of the expenses (in this analogy, all of the interactions), then some products will not be able to be purchased.	limiting reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that determines the amount of product that can be produced in a chemical reaction. The other chemicals involved in the reaction are called excess reagents.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as the "maximizing" agent in a relationship. It is the one that determines how much fun (or love, or happiness) can be had by both parties. The other agents in the reaction are like excess reagents; they may add to the experience, but they cannot replace what is provided by the limiting reactant.	limiting reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that determines the amount of product that can be produced in a chemical reaction. The other chemicals involved in the reaction are called excess reagents.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as the amount of flour that is needed to make a certain number of cookies. The other ingredients, such as sugar and butter, are the excess reagents. If too much sugar or butter is used, there will not be enough flour left to make all of the desired cookies.	limiting reactant	Using a social science analogy, explain limiting reactant.	ht	social science	1	A limiting reactant is a chemical that determines the amount of product that can be produced in a chemical reaction. The other chemicals involved in the reaction are called excess reagents.

In social science, ligase is a term used to describe the process of unifying two or more elements into a single entity. In biology, ligase refers to the enzyme responsible for catalyzing the joining of two DNA strands into one molecule.A good analogy for ligase would be welding two pieces of metal together. The welding process uses intense heat and pressure to fuse the metals together, creating a single unit. Ligase works in a similar way, by using enzymes to join DNA strands together.	ligase	Using a social science analogy, explain ligase.	ht	social science	1	In social science, ligase is a term used to describe the process of unifying two or more elements into a single entity. Message encoding is like translating a message from one language to another. The process of translation ensures that the message arrives intact and can be understood by the recipient. Message decoding is like translating a message back to its original language. This process allows the sender to confirm that the message was received as intended.	message encoding	Using a social science analogy, explain message encoding.	ht	social science	1	Message encoding is the process of transforming a message into a format that can be transmitted. This may involve translating the words into an agreed upon code, or adding specific formatting to ensure the message arrives intact. Message decoding is the reverse process, taking a formatted message and returning it to its original form.
Message encoding is like translating a message from one language to another. The sender and receiver need to agree on a code or format that will be used to send the message. A social science analogy for monitor would be to think of it as a microscope. Just like a scientist uses a microscope to look at tiny things that the human eye cannot see, monitors use technology to watch and record what people say and do on the internet. This information can then be used to help companies or governments understand how people are using the internet, what they are talking about, and who they are talking to.	monitor	Using a social science analogy, explain monitor.	ht	social science	1	Monitoring is the process of observing and recording some aspect of social life. It can involve systematically observing and measuring specific behaviors or it can be more informal, involving simply noting what people are talking about in a given situation.

It is an important factor in determining how much power your system can draw and how stable it will be. An audio card is similar to the human auditory cortex which processes and interprets sound. The auditory cortex takes in information from the ears, filters it, and sends it to the brain where it is interpreted. An audio card does a similar job for a computer- it takes input from devices like microphones or music players, filters it, and outputs it to speakers or headphones.	audio card	Using a social science analogy, explain audio card.	ht	social science	1	Audio cards are used to process and output sound for computers. They allow users to connect speakers, headphones, or other audio devices to their computer in order to hear sounds.

They allow users to connect speakers, headphones, or other audio devices to their computer in order to hear sounds more clearly.	audio card	Using a social science analogy, explain audio card.	ht	social science	1	Audio cards are used to process and output sound for computers. They allow users to connect speakers, headphones, or other audio devices to their computer in order to hear sounds.

It then sends these processed sounds out to our speakers or headphones so that we can hear them.	audio card	Using a social science analogy, explain audio card.	ht	social science	1	Audio cards are used to process and output sound for computers. In glycolysis, glucose is broken down into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen. In social science, this would be analogous to two people breaking up a large piece of food into smaller pieces so that it can be eaten.	glycolysis	Using a social science analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	social science	1	In glycolysis, glucose is broken down into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen.
Glycolysis can be thought of as the process that breaks down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen.	glycolysis	Using a social science analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	social science	1	In glycolysis, glucose is broken down into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen.
Glycolysis can be thought of as a process where the larger, more complex molecule (glucose) is broken down into smaller molecules that are easier to use and manage. This analogy can be used to explain many social processes, such as divorce or the spread of rumors. In both cases, a complex event is reduced into smaller parts that are easier to understand and deal with.	glycolysis	Using a social science analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	social science	1	In glycolysis, glucose is broken down into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen.
In glycolysis, glucose is broken down into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen. The analogy that can be used to explain this process is that of a busy city street. Cars (glucose) are constantly moving and being broken down into smaller parts (pyruvate). This process happens without requiring any outside help or interference (oxygen).	glycolysis	Using a social science analogy, explain glycolysis.	ht	social science	1	In glycolysis, glucose is broken down into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen.

Anti-stokes scattering can be thought of as a social situation where someone is trying to promote one person from the ground state (a regular citizen) to an excited state (someone with more power or influence). This process creates a new person that is emitted in a different direction than where they were originally traveling.	anti-stokes scattering	Using a social science analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	social science	1	Anti-stokes scattering is when a photon hits an atom and the energy of the photon is greater than the energy difference between the ground state and first excited state of the atom. When this happens, some of the excess energy from the photon is used to promote one electron from the ground state to an excited state. This process creates a new photon that is emitted in a different direction than where it was originally traveling.
When an atom is hit by a photon with more energy than the difference between its ground and first excited state, some of the excess energy can be used to promote one electron from the ground state to an excited state. This creates a new photon that is emitted in a different direction than where it was originally traveling. Stokes scattering is like people in a room talking to each other. The sound of their voices is diffused throughout the room, and the degree of deflection (or diffusion) depends on how big and how close together the people are.	stokes scattering	Using a social science analogy, explain stokes scattering.	ht	social science	1	Stokes scattering is the diffusion of light or other particles through a medium. It is named after George Gabriel Stokes, who first described it mathematically in 1852. The scattering process causes light to be deflected from its original path, and the degree of deflection depends on the size, shape, and composition of the scatterers.
Stokes scattering is the diffusion of light or other particles through a medium. It is named after George Gabriel Stokes, who first described it mathematically in 1852. The median lethal dose is the dose of a substance that kills half the members of a tested population. In other words, it is the point at which 50% of the test subjects die as a result of exposure to a particular chemical. This measure can be used to assess the toxicity of different substances.	median lethal dose	Using a social science analogy, explain median lethal dose.	ht	social science	1	A median lethal dose, or LD50, is the dose of a substance that kills half the members of a tested population. It can be used to measure the toxicity of a substance.
A median lethal dose, or LD50, is the dose of a substance that kills half the members of a tested population. It can be used to measure the toxicity of a substance. In social science, it would be like taking a poll where 50% of respondents said they would vote for a candidate. This could be used as an indicator that the candidate is not very popular.	median lethal dose	Using a social science analogy, explain median lethal dose.	ht	social science	1	A median lethal dose, or LD50, is the dose of a substance that kills half the members of a tested population. Suppose you want to know whether there is a difference in the average test scores of male and female students. You could collect data from a large number of schools and then conduct an anova to see if the average score for males was different than the average score for females. An anova would partition the total variability in test scores into two components: (1) variation among school means and (2) variation within school means. If there was a statistically significant difference between the mean scores for males and females, it would suggest that there is a real difference in the ability of males and females to do well on tests.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	1	Anova is the statistical technique most often used to compare the means of two or more groups. It stands for analysis of variance. The technique partitions the total variability in a set of data into two components: (1) variation among group means and (2) variation within group means.
The analysis of variance is a way to understand the difference between groups. It splits the variation in a set of data into two parts: the part that is due to differences between group means, and the part that is due to differences within group means. This technique can be helpful when you want to understand if there are any real differences between different groups or if all of the variation is just because of chance fluctuations.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	0	Anova is the statistical technique most often used to compare the means of two or more groups. It stands for analysis of variance. The technique partitions the total variability in a set of data into two components: (1) variation among group means and (2) variation within group means.
Anova is a bit like a courtroom trial. The prosecutor (anova) tries to show that the defendant (the difference between group means) is guilty of the crime of variability. The defense attorney (variability within group means) tries to show that the defendant is innocent, or at least that there is not enough evidence to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	1	Anova is the statistical technique most often used to compare the means of two or more groups. It stands for analysis of variance. The technique partitions the total variability in a set of data into two components: (1) variation among group means and (2) variation within group means.
Suppose you want to know whether there is a difference in the average number of friends that men and women have. You could gather data from a large number of people, divide them into groups based on their sex, and then calculate the mean number of friends for each group. Anova would allow you to determine whether there is a statistically significant difference between the means for men and women.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	1	Anova is the statistical technique most often used to compare the means of two or more groups. It stands for analysis of variance. The technique partitions the total variability in a set of data into two components: (1) variation among group means and (2) variation within group means.
ANOVA is a bit like taking the average of several different classrooms of students. The first ANOVA calculation would compare the averages of all the classes, to see if they were significantly different from each other. If they were not, then we might calculate a second ANOVA that compares only the averages of boys' classes against girls' classes. This would tell us if there was a significant difference between the average test scores for boys and girls in general.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	1	Anova is the statistical technique most often used to compare the means of two or more groups. It stands for analysis of variance. The technique partitions the total variability in a set of data into two components: (1) variation among group means and (2) variation within group means.
Imagine that you want to know whether there is a difference in the average amount of money that men and women spend on Christmas gifts. You could compare the average spending for each group by hand, but this would be very time consuming. An anova would allow you to do this more quickly and easily. It would first account for any variability in spending within each group (due to things like different incomes, numbers of people being gift-ed to, etc.), and then identify any differences between the groups.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	1	An anova is a statistical analysis tool that allows researchers to compare the means of two or more groups. It does this by accounting for the amount of variability in the data that is due to differences between the groups, as opposed to variability within each group. This makes it possible to identify which groups differ from one another in terms of mean values.
Think of anova as being like a court trial. The goal of the analysis is to identify which groups are guilty (i.e., differ from one another in terms of mean values) and determine how much evidence there is to support this conclusion. In order to do this, the analysis takes into account the amount of variability that is due to differences between groups, as opposed to variability within each group. This makes it possible to see whether there is enough evidence to declare that one group is different from another in terms of mean values.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	1	An anova is a statistical analysis tool that allows researchers to compare the means of two or more groups. It does this by accounting for the amount of variability in the data that is due to differences between the groups, as opposed to variability within each group. This makes it possible to identify which groups differ from one another in terms of mean values.
Think of anova as a way to compare the average test scores of two different classes. Let's say that one class has 20 students and the other has 30 students. The average score in the first class is 85, while the average score in the second class is 95. Even though the second class has higher average scores, we can't conclude that the students in that class are necessarily smarter than the students in the first class. This is because there may be more variability in the data from the smaller group (the first class) than there is in the data from the larger group (the second class). anova accounts for this difference and allows us to identify which group differs from another in terms of mean values.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	1	An anova is a statistical analysis tool that allows researchers to compare the means of two or more groups. It does this by accounting for the amount of variability in the data that is due to differences between the groups, as opposed to variability within each group. This makes it possible to identify which groups differ from one another in terms of mean values.
Suppose you want to know whether men or women are better at math. You could give a math test to a bunch of men and women and find out the average score for each group. But this would only tell you how well men and women do on the average. An anova would allow you to determine whether there is a statistically significant difference in the mean scores of men and women.	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	1	An anova is a statistical analysis tool that allows researchers to compare the means of two or more groups. An anova is a bit like the Supreme Court. It is a way of evaluating whether groups (e.g., states) are statistically different from one another in terms of some measure (e.g., average income). An anova takes into account the amount of variability in the data that is due to differences between groups, as opposed to variability within each group. This makes it possible to identify which groups differ from one another in terms of mean values	anova	Using a social science analogy, explain anova.	ht	social science	1	An anova is a statistical analysis tool that allows researchers to compare the means of two or more groups. It does this by accounting for the amount of variability in the data that is due to differences between the groups, as opposed to variability within each group. This makes it possible to identify which groups differ from one another in terms of mean values.
A thermostat can be thought of as a social scientist who is tasked with regulating the temperature of a room or building. In a social science analogy, chemical equilibrium can be thought of as two forces (pro and con) being equal in strength. This means that the overall attitude of a population is neutral - there is no prevailing opinion on an issue.	chemical equilibrium	Using a social science analogy, explain chemical equilibrium.	ht	social science	1	In chemical equilibrium, the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal. This means that the concentrations of all reactants and products remain constant.
In chemical equilibrium, the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal. This means that the concentrations of all reactants and products remain constant. This analogy can be used to explain how a society remains in balance. If there is an influx of new people into a city, for example, the rate at which homes are built needs to increase in order to maintain equilibrium. A social science analogy for JIT would be to think of it as a vaccination campaign. Just-in-time prevents an outbreak (of illness) by ensuring that only those who need the vaccine receive it (only when they need it). This limits the spread of the virus and ultimately protects more people.	just-in-time	Using a social science analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time (JIT) is a business strategy that aligns production with customer demand. It relies on a continuous flow of materials from suppliers to the manufacturing floor and finished products to customers. JIT eliminates waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed.
JIT is a business strategy that aligns production with customer demand. It relies on a continuous flow of materials from suppliers to the manufacturing floor and finished products to customers. JIT eliminates waste by producing only what is needed, when it is needed. This can be analogized to social science concepts such as equilibrium and positive feedback loops. In both cases, things are kept in balance by ensuring that there is a constant flow of input and output.	just-in-time	Using a social science analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time (JIT) is a business strategy that aligns production with customer demand. Just-in-time is like a continuous flow of water. The supply (water) continually flows into the system and is used as needed (by plants, animals, and people). The system continuously recycles the water so that it is always available when it is needed.	just-in-time	Using a social science analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time (JIT) is a business strategy that aligns production with customer demand. Just-in-time can be thought of as a way to manage the flow of resources and finished products in an economy. Like other economic concepts, it seeks to optimize scarce resources by matching them with needs. In the case of JIT, this means producing only what is needed, when it is needed. Parents attempting to use a just-in-time approach to parenting may produce only the necessary amount of food, drink, and clothing for their children. They would also need to time this production precisely with their child's needs in order to decrease waste. In order to be successful, parents would need to closely monitor their child's daily habits and coordinate with other caregivers (e.g., grandparents).	just-in-time	Using a social science analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time (JIT) is an inventory management system that aims to decrease the cost of holding inventory and improve production efficiency. Just-in-time can be thought of as a production process that is analogous to social scientists' use of the term diffusion. Just as diffusion occurs when an innovation (e.g., a new product or idea) spreads from person to person in a population, JIT involves the gradual and continual spread of goods and materials throughout a manufacturing facility. Like diffusion, JIT progresses through successive stages until it reaches its final destination (the assembly line). The goal of both processes is to minimize waste by ensuring that only those goods and materials that are needed are produced and used.	just-in-time	Using a social science analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	social science	1	Just-in-time (JIT) is an inventory management system that aims to decrease the cost of holding inventory and improve production efficiency. The immune system can be thought of as a population of cells that "vote" on which infection to fight. The best defenders against a particular infection are remembered, and their genetic information is passed on to future generations of immune cells. This process allows the immune system to "learn" and become better equipped to fight off that infection.	adaptive immunity	Using a social science analogy, explain adaptive immunity.	ht	social science	1	In adaptive immunity, the body's immune system "learns" to recognize and fight specific infections. This happens through a process of natural selection: The body's best defenders against a particular infection are remembered, and their genetic information is passed on to future generations of immune cells. Over time, the population of immune cells becomes better equipped to fight off that infection.
The immune system can be thought of as a community of cells that work together to protect the body from infection. Just as different communities in society have evolved to specialize in different activities (such as farming, manufacturing, or government), the cells of the immune system have evolved to specialize in fighting specific infections. The best defenders against a particular infection are remembered, and their genetic information is passed on to future generations of immune cells. This process allows the immune system to "learn" how to fight off new infections.	adaptive immunity	Using a social science analogy, explain adaptive immunity.	ht	social science	1	In adaptive immunity, the body's immune system "learns" to recognize and fight specific infections. This happens through a process of natural selection: The body's best defenders against a particular infection are remembered, and their genetic information is passed on to future generations of immune cells. Over time, the population of immune cells becomes better equipped to fight off that infection.
In social sciences, one analogy for adaptive immunity is the process of natural selection. In both cases, the best defenders are remembered and their genetic information passed on to future generations. With adaptive immunity, this happens through a process of "learning" - the body's immune system becomes better equipped to fight off a particular infection. With natural selection, this happens through evolution - the population of organisms becomes better adapted to survive in their environment.	adaptive immunity	Using a social science analogy, explain adaptive immunity.	ht	social science	1	In adaptive immunity, the body's immune system "learns" to recognize and fight specific infections.
