An analogy for Kirchoff's Voltage Law could be as follows: Imagine you are walking through a city and at every intersection there is someone handing out flyers. As you walk, you take one flyer from each person. At the end of your journey, you have a stack of flyers that are all different heights. The height of each flyer represents the voltage at that particular point in the circuit. Just like in real life, if you added up all the voltages at every point in the circuit, they would sum to zero. This law ensures that this always happens – no matter what path the electricity takes through the circuit.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Kirchoff's Voltage Law states that the sum of all voltages in a circuit is zero. This means that the voltage at any point in a circuit is the result of applying Ohm's law to the individual resistances in series with it.
In a circuit, there are many different voltages. Kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of all these voltages is zero. This means that if you add up all the voltages in a circuit, they will cancel each other out. This is kind of like when you have a bunch of people in a room and they are all talking to each other. The overall noise level in the room is zero because the sound from each person cancelling out the sound from everyone else.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Kirchoff's Voltage Law states that the sum of all voltages in a circuit is zero.  Kirchoff's Voltage Law is similar to the way that pressure works in a system of interconnected pipes. Just as the total pressure in a system of pipes is the sum of all the pressures at each point, the total voltage in a circuit is the sum of all voltages at each point. This means that if you have two points in a circuit with different voltages, then electricity will flow from the higher voltage to the lower until they are both equal.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Kirchoff's Voltage Law states that the sum of all voltages in a circuit is zero. Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. Just as a machine can make it easier for us to do a task, enzymes help speed up biochemical reactions so our bodies can function properly.	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are proteins that catalyze (speed up) biochemical reactions.
Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are proteins that catalyze (speed up) biochemical reactions. Enzymes can be thought of as the worker bees of biochemistry, because they tirelessly speed up all sorts of biochemical transformations. Without enzymes, these biochemical reactions would occur much more slowly - or not at all!	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are proteins that catalyze (speed up) biochemical reactions.
Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. Just as a machine can help speed up a task, enzymes help to speed up biochemical reactions. Enzymes are proteins that catalyze (speed up) biochemical reactions. This means that they help substances interact with one another so that the desired reaction can take place.	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are proteins that catalyze (speed up) biochemical reactions.
Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are proteins that catalyze (speed up) biochemical reactions. Enzymes can be thought of as the workers in a factory. Just as a worker on an assembly line can make widgets faster than if one person tried to do it by hand, enzymes can make biochemical reactions happen faster than if they were not present. This is important because many biochemical reactions are necessary for life and must happen quickly in order to maintain homeostasis (balance).	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are proteins that catalyze (speed up) biochemical reactions.
Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are proteins that catalyze (speed up) biochemical reactions. Enzymes can be thought of as the "workhorses" of the body, because they play a role in almost every biological process.	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They are proteins that catalyze (speed up) biochemical reactions.
It is as if the reaction is a race, and the rate-determining step is the slowest runner. The other runners can start off quickly, but they will eventually catch up to the slowest runner. So, the faster runners may cross the finish line first, but the slowest runner determines how fast everyone else finishes.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The rate-determining step is the slowest step in a reaction. It determines how quickly a reaction will happen.
The rate-determining step is the slowest step in a reaction just as the tempo is the slowest part of a song. It determines how quickly a reaction will happen, similar to how the tempo determines how quickly a song will play.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The rate-determining step is the slowest step in a reaction. It determines how quickly a reaction will happen.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a reaction. It determines how quickly a reaction will happen. The analogy would be the speed at which an artist can paint. If the artist's hand is slow, then the painting will most likely be done slowly. If the artist's hand is fast, then the painting will most likely be done quickly.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The rate-determining step is the slowest step in a reaction. It determines how quickly a reaction will happen.
It is like the speed of a car. The rate-determining step is like the engine - it determines how quickly the car can go.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The rate-determining step is the slowest step in a reaction. It determines how quickly a reaction will happen.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a reaction. It determines how quickly a reaction will happen. The speed of an entire reaction can be influenced by changing the rate-determining step. For example, if you are trying to create a painting as fast as possible, you would want to start with the most time-consuming task, such as creating the background. This analogy can be helpful for understanding how reactions work: think about each colour (step) in your painting as representing one molecule or atom that has been added to the overall product (reaction). In order to make your painting come together as quickly as possible, you want all of these different molecules and atoms coming together at the same time – just like you want all of the reactants in a chemical reaction coming together at once. So what slows down this process? Just like having to mix paint on your palette before starting to paint, doing things like adding stabilizers or precursors can lengthen the time it takes for a chemical reaction to occur.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The rate-determining step is the slowest step in a reaction. It determines how quickly a reaction will happen.
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a chemical reaction. The rate-determining step can be thought of as the "slowest link in the chain" when it comes to a reaction. For example, if you're trying to break a chain (i.e. a necklace), the weakest link is going to be the one that breaks first. In chemistry, this translates to meaning that the slowest step in a reaction will dictate how fast everything else happens.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a chemical reaction. The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a chemical reaction. Just like how the pacing of an event can greatly affect how enjoyable it is for an audience, the rate-determining step determines how fast a reaction will take place. If the slowest step happens slowly, then the overall reaction will happen slowly. But if that same slowest step happens quickly, then the reaction as whole will happen more quickly.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a chemical reaction. Column chromatography can be thought of as a sorting machine. The different colors of paint are placed in a column and then water is added. The colors that dissolve in the water will move through the column faster than the colors that don't dissolve. This will allow for the separation of the colors.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The mixture is placed in a column and then a solvent is added. The components of the mixture will dissolve in the solvent, but at different rates. The more soluble components will move through the column faster than the less soluble components. This allows for the separation of the components of the mixture.
Column chromatography is a technique used to separate the different colors of paint in an art studio. The mixture is placed in a column and then paint thinner is added. The components of the mixture will dissolve in the paint thinner, but at different rates. The more soluble components will move through the column faster than the less soluble components. This allows for the separation of the different colors of paint.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to an arts student.	ht	arts	0	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. A proto-oncogene is a musician who has the potential to become a rockstar. An oncogene is a musician who can cause destruction. Proto-oncogenes are normal musicians who can be turned into rockstars by mutations.	proto-oncogenes	Using an analogy, explain proto-oncogenes to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A proto-oncogene is a gene that has the potential to become an oncogene. An oncogene is a gene that can cause cancer. Proto-oncogenes are normal genes that can be turned into oncogenes by mutations.
A proto-oncogene is like a normal, everyday houseplant. It has the potential to become an oncogene (a plant that can cause cancer) by mutations, but typically doesn't. An oncogene is like a mutated, dangerous houseplant that has been turned into a weed and can now cause cancer.	proto-oncogenes	Using an analogy, explain proto-oncogenes to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A proto-oncogene is a gene that has the potential to become an oncogene. Resonance hybrid is a term used in chemistry to describe the stabilization of certain types of molecules by means of resonance. In general, when two or more atoms or groups of atoms are combined together to form a molecule, they will usually be at different energy levels. However, if the combination of atoms forms a structure that can be described as two or more Lewis structures (resonant structures), then the energies of the individual atoms will cancel each other out, and the molecule will be stable.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to an arts student.	ht	arts	0	In the arts, resonance is often used to describe the effect of a sound or musical note that causes other sounds to vibrate sympathetically. In physics, resonance is a phenomenon in which a system forced to oscillate at one frequency responds by amplifying the oscillation at that same frequency while reducing oscillations at other frequencies.
A resonance hybrid is like a musician that can play one note on a violin and make other strings on the same instrument vibrate in sympathy. The physicist's version of this analogy would be to say that resonance is when a system forced to oscillate at one frequency responds by amplifying the oscillation at that same frequency while reducing oscillations at other frequencies.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	In the arts, resonance is often used to describe the effect of a sound or musical note that causes other sounds to vibrate sympathetically. In physics, resonance is a phenomenon in which a system forced to oscillate at one frequency responds by amplifying the oscillation at that same frequency while reducing oscillations at other frequencies.
Resonance hybrid can be thought of as a kind of "vibrational harmony." When two or more objects vibrate at the same frequency, they create a stronger vibration (or resonance) than if each object were vibrating separately. This is often seen in musical instruments, where multiple strings or pipes are tuned to the same pitch to create a fuller, richer sound.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	In the arts, resonance is often used to describe the effect of a sound or musical note that causes other sounds to vibrate sympathetically. In physics, resonance is a phenomenon in which a system forced to oscillate at one frequency responds by amplifying the oscillation at that same frequency while reducing oscillations at other frequencies.
Resonance hybrid can be thought of as a type of "vibrational harmony." The term is used in physics to describe a phenomenon in which a system forced to oscillate at one frequency responds by amplifying the oscillation at that same frequency while reducing oscillations at other frequencies. In essence, resonance hybrid occurs when two or more objects vibrate together in synchronization, creating a stronger and more resonant vibration than if any one object were vibrating on its own. This effect can be observed in physical objects like tuning forks, but also exists within sound waves themselves. When two sound waves with similar frequencies collide, their vibrations will merge and create a louder, more powerful wave.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	In the arts, resonance is often used to describe the effect of a sound or musical note that causes other sounds to vibrate sympathetically. Resonance hybrid can be thought of as a type of resonance in which more than one object is vibrating sympathetically. For example, if you were to strike a tuning fork and hold it next to another tuning fork, the second fork would begin to vibrate at the same frequency as the first.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	In the arts, resonance is often used to describe the effect of a sound or musical note that causes other sounds to vibrate sympathetically. EEG is a test that records the electrical activity of your brain. This can be thought of as capturing the patterns of sparks that light up when different neurons in your brain communicate with each other.	electroencephalogram	Using an analogy, explain electroencephalogram to an arts student.	ht	arts	0	An electroencephalogram (EEG) is a test that records the electrical activity of your brain. It uses small, sticky pads called electrodes that are placed on your head. The electrodes pick up the tiny amounts of electricity that are released when your brain cells send messages to each other.
An EEG is a bit like having your brain photographed. Tiny electrodes are placed on your head and they pick up the tiny amounts of electricity that are released when your brain cells send messages to each other. This information is then sent to a computer, which creates a graph that shows the different types of electrical activity taking place in your brain.	electroencephalogram	Using an analogy, explain electroencephalogram to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	An electroencephalogram (EEG) is a test that records the electrical activity of your brain. It uses small, sticky pads called electrodes that are placed on your head. The electrodes pick up the tiny amounts of electricity that are released when your brain cells send messages to each other.
The EEG is a test that records the electrical activity of your brain. This means that it will track any changes in the way electricity flows through your brain. When an action potential is generated in the neuron's dendrite, it travels down the axon to the soma. This can be thought of as akin to someone shouting a message down a long hallway - the message will travel faster and farther if more people are shouting it at once. The action potential then causes voltage-gated Na+ channels to open, and Na+ ions flood into the cell. This depolarizes the cell membrane, which triggers more voltage-gated Na+ channels to open. This process continues until all of the voltage-gated Na+ channels are opened and the cell reaches its threshold potential. At this point, an action potential is generated and transmitted down the axon like a wave of electricity.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	When an action potential is generated in the neuron's dendrite, it travels down the axon to the soma. The action potential then causes voltage-gated Na+ channels to open, and Na+ ions flood into the cell. This depolarizes the cell membrane, which triggers more voltage-gated Na+ channels to open. This process continues until all of the voltage-gated Na+ channels are opened and the cell reaches its threshold potential. At this point, an action potential is generated and transmitted down the axon.
When an action potential is generated in the neuron's dendrite, it travels down the axon like a wave. The action potential then causes voltage-gated Na+ channels to open, and Na+ ions flood into the cell. This depolarizes the cell membrane, which triggers more voltage-gated Na+ channels to open. This process continues until all of the voltage-gated Na+ channels are opened and the cell reaches its threshold potential. At this point, an action potential is generated and transmitted down the axon.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to an arts student.	ht	arts	0	When an action potential is generated in the neuron's dendrite, it travels down the axon to the soma. The action potential then causes voltage-gated Na+ channels to open, and Na+ ions flood into the cell. This depolarizes the cell membrane, which triggers more voltage-gated Na+ channels to open. This process continues until all of the voltage-gated Na+ channels are opened and the cell reaches its threshold potential. At this point, an action potential is generated and transmitted down the axon.
Propagation of an action potential down a neuron can be thought of as the spreading of waves through water. When a pebble is thrown into a still pond, it creates circular waves that spread out from the point of impact. These waves get larger and weaker as they move away from the center, until eventually they disappear altogether. An action potential behaves in much the same way. It starts at the dendrite, where it is strongest, and then spreads to the soma and axon. The farther away from the initial stimulus an area is, the weaker the signal becomes until it eventually disappears	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	When an action potential is generated in the neuron's dendrite, it travels down the axon to the soma. The action potential then causes voltage-gated Na+ channels to open, and Na+ ions flood into the cell. This depolarizes the cell membrane, which triggers more voltage-gated Na+ channels to open. This process continues until all of the voltage-gated Na+ channels are opened and the cell reaches its threshold potential. At this point, an action potential is generated and transmitted down the axon.
Imagine a line of people at an amusement park waiting to get on a ride. The person at the front of the line is excited and ready to go, while the person at the back of the line is bored and frustrated. An action potential works in a similar way. The neuron at the front of the line (the dendrite) is excited and ready to fire, while the neuron at the back of the line (the soma) is unexcited and unresponsive. An action potential travels down this "line" of neurons like a wave, exciting each one along its path until it reaches the soma.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	When an action potential is generated in the neuron's dendrite, it travels down the axon to the soma. The action potential then causes voltage-gated Na+ channels to open, and Na+ ions flood into the cell. This depolarizes the cell membrane, which triggers more voltage-gated Na+ channels to open. This process continues until all of the voltage-gated Na+ channels are opened and the cell reaches its threshold potential. At this point, an action potential is generated and transmitted down the axon.
 imagine a neuron as a long garden hose. When you turn on the water at the faucet, the initial force of the water causes the hose to bulge out in all directions. This is analogous to an action potential traveling down a neuron's axon. As more and more water pressure builds up (due to voltage-gated Na+ channels opening), eventually it overcomes the friction of the water flowing through the hose and causes a rapid flow of water (action potential) that travels down its length.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	When an action potential is generated in the neuron's dendrite, it travels down the axon to the soma. The action potential then causes voltage-gated Na+ channels to open, and Na+ ions flood into the cell. This depolarizes the cell membrane, which triggers more voltage-gated Na+ channels to open. This process continues until all of the voltage-gated Na+ channels are opened and the cell reaches its threshold potential. At this point, an action potential is generated and transmitted down the axon.
An action potential is a bit like an earthquake. It starts at one point (the dendrite), and then travels down the neuron until it reaches the end (the terminal buttons). This process causes calcium ions to flow into the synaptic vesicles, which triggers the release of neurotransmitters. These neurotransmitters cross the synaptic gap and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane. This initiates an electrical signal that travels along the neuron until it reaches another synapse.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	When an action potential is generated at the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. The action potential then causes calcium ions to flow into the synaptic vesicles. This process triggers the release of neurotransmitters, which cross the synaptic gap and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane. This initiates an electrical signal that travels along the neuron until it reaches another synapse.
Just as when traveling down an electrical wire, the action potential travels down the neuron in a wave. The voltage-gated sodium channels open and allow Na+ ions to flood into the cell, initiating the impulse. This propagates quickly (at around 250 mph) until it reaches the end of the axon, where there are specialized terminal buttons. These release neurotransmitters that cross the synaptic gap and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane of another neuron.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	When an action potential is generated at the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. The action potential then causes calcium ions to flow into the synaptic vesicles. This process triggers the release of neurotransmitters, which cross the synaptic gap and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane. This initiates an electrical signal that travels along the neuron until it reaches another synapse.
An action potential is a bit like an electric current. It travels down the neuron very quickly, like a bolt of lightning. This happens because the neuron is made up of lots of cells that are all connected together, and when one cell fires off an action potential, it triggers all the other cells to do the same.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	When an action potential is generated at the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. When an action potential is generated at the dendrite of a neuron, it can be thought of as someone ringing a bell. The sound (action potential) travels down the axon to the terminal buttons, where it causes calcium ions to flow into the synaptic vesicles. This process triggers the release of neurotransmitters, which cross the synaptic gap and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane. This initiates an electrical signal that travels along the neuron until it reaches another synapse. At each synapse, more neurotransmitters are released and continue traveling down the neuron until they reach its end.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	When an action potential is generated at the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the axon to the terminal buttons. The action potential then causes calcium ions to flow into the synaptic vesicles. This process triggers the release of neurotransmitters, which cross the synaptic gap and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane. This initiates an electrical signal that travels along the neuron until it reaches another synapse.
If two painters are working on a painting, the limiting reactant would be the amount of paint each one has. The excess reactant would be the extra paint that is not needed to complete the painting.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other reactant present in excess of the amount needed to form the desired product.
A limiting reactant is like a paintbrush that can only hold so much paint. The excess reactant is the other type of paint that can be poured on top of the brush to make more paintings.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other reactant present in excess of the amount needed to form the desired product.
If you are baking a cake, the flour is the limiting reactant. This means that no matter how much sugar and butter you add, you can only produce so much cake because of the limited amount of flour. The sugar and butter are excess reactants.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other reactant present in excess of the amount needed to form the desired product.
If you have a pot of paint and two brushes, the limiting reactant is the amount of paint. The excess reactant is the number of brush strokes.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other reactant present in excess of the amount needed to form the desired product.
A limiting reactant can be thought of as an artist's canvas. The amount of product that can be formed is limited by the size of the canvas - in this analogy, the amount of product that can be formed is limited by the amount of limiting reactant present. The excess reactant is what's left over after all the desired product has been formed - in this analogy, it would be like having paint left over after painting a picture on the canvas.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A limiting reactant is a substance that limits the amount of product that can be formed in a chemical reaction. The excess reactant is the other reactant present in excess of the amount needed to form the desired product.

Message encoding is similar to encrypting a message. It takes readable text and transforms it into an encoded format that can only be understood by the recipient if they have the corresponding decoding key.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Message encoding is a process of transforming readable text into an encoded format, which can only be understood by the recipient if they have the corresponding decoding key.
Message encoding is similar to encasing a message in a protective box. The text is written on a piece of paper and placed inside the box. The box is then sealed with wax or another type of adhesive. Only the person who has the key to open the box will be able to read the message.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Message encoding is a process of transforming readable text into an encoded format, which can only be understood by the recipient if they have the corresponding decoding key.
Message encoding can be thought of as a way to protect a message from prying eyes. By transforming readable text into an encoded format, the message becomes much harder to interpret without the corresponding decoding key. This can be useful for keeping sensitive information private, or for preventing unauthorized access to data stored in digital form.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Message encoding is a process of transforming readable text into an encoded format, which can only be understood by the recipient if they have the corresponding decoding key.

Message encoding is like putting a message into a bottle to send it across the ocean. You remove any unnecessary data from the message so that it takes up less space, encrypt it to make it harder for unauthorized parties to read, and then pack it into packets to send over the network. At the receiving end, the packets are unpacked and decrypted before being reassembled into the original message.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Message encoding is the process of transforming a message into a format that can be transmitted over a communication channel. The message is first compressed to remove any unnecessary data, and then encrypted to make it harder for unauthorized parties to read. Finally, the compressed and encrypted message is packetized and sent over the network. At the receiving end, the packets are unpacked and decrypted before being reassembled into the original message.
Message encoding is like creating a sculpture. First, you remove any unnecessary parts of the material to make it lighter and easier to work with. Then you sculpt the remaining material into the desired shape. Finally, you paint or finish the sculpture to protect it and give it a more pleasing appearance.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Message encoding is the process of transforming a message into a format that can be transmitted over a communication channel. Ram can be thought of as an artist's sketchbook. When an artist is working on a drawing, they are constantly accessing different parts of the sketchbook to get the materials they need. The more pages the sketchbook has, the more options the artist has and the faster they can work. Similarly, ram helps your computer to access data quickly so that programs run smoothly and you can multitask easily.	ram	Using an analogy, explain ram to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Ram is a type of software that helps computers to process information faster. Ram stands for Random Access Memory, which is the part of your computer's memory where data is stored while you are using it. This means that when you are working on a document or browsing the internet, the data is being accessed randomly from different parts of the ram. The more ram your computer has, the faster it can access this data, meaning that programs will run smoother and you'll be able to multitask more easily
Ram is like the space in your house where you store your belongings. When you need something, you can go to any room and get it. Your computer's ram works in a similar way. It stores data that you are currently using so that it can be accessed quickly. The more ram your computer has, the more data it can store at once, meaning that programs will run smoother and you'll be able to multitask more easily	ram	Using an analogy, explain ram to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Ram is a type of software that helps computers to process information faster. A power supply unit is a bit like the engine of a car. It takes the gasoline that's available and converts it into energy that can turn the wheels and make the car move. In the same way, a PSU takes alternating current from your wall outlet (like gasoline) and converts it into direct current for your electronic devices (the energy that makes them work).	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that supplies electric power to an electrical circuit. In most cases, it converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), which is the type of electricity required by electronic devices such as computers and televisions.
A power supply unit can be thought of as an artist's paint palette. Just as the palette provides a variety of colors for the artist to create their work, a PSU supplies a variety of electrical voltages and currents to allow electronic devices to function.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that supplies electric power to an electrical circuit. In most cases, it converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), which is the type of electricity required by electronic devices such as computers and televisions.
A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that supplies electric power to an electrical circuit. In most cases, it converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), which is the type of electricity required by electronic devices such as computers and televisions. A PSU can be thought of as an "electrical transformer" - it takes in one voltage level and outputs another.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that supplies electric power to an electrical circuit. In most cases, it converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), which is the type of electricity required by electronic devices such as computers and televisions.
A power supply unit is like the engine of a car. It converts the fuel (gasoline) into energy that powers the car. In the same way, a PSU converts AC into DC so that it can be used by electronic devices.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that supplies electric power to an electrical circuit. In most cases, it converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), which is the type of electricity required by electronic devices such as computers and televisions.
A power supply unit can be thought of as an electrician’s tool belt. Just as an electrician needs a variety of tools to do his job, a PSU needs a variety of connectors to provide power to different types of devices. The AC input connector converts the alternating current provided by the wall outlet into direct current that the device can use. The various DC output connectors provide power to the various devices in your system.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that supplies electric power to an electrical circuit. In most cases, it converts alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), which is the type of electricity required by electronic devices such as computers and televisions.

This sends signals to the computer which then move the cursor according to how the mouse was moved.

Glycolysis can be thought of as a "sugar refinery" inside cells. Glucose is the raw sugar that enters the glycolysis process, and two molecules of pyruvate are the "finished product." Pyruvate is then delivered to other parts of the cell where it is used for energy or converted into other substances.	glycolysis	Using an analogy, explain glycolysis to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (a type of sugar) into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and does not require oxygen.
Glycolysis can be thought of as the process of turning a lump of clay into two smaller pots. The lump of clay is like the glucose, and the two smaller pots are like the pyruvate.	glycolysis	Using an analogy, explain glycolysis to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (a type of sugar) into two molecules of pyruvate. Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They work by attaching to one molecule of a substance called the substrate, and then breaking it down into two smaller molecules. This process is called catalysis. The enzymes can only work if they have the correct shape, so scientists study their structure in order to better understand how they work.	enzyme mechanism	Using an analogy, explain enzyme mechanism to an arts student.	ht	arts	0	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. They work by attaching to one molecule of a substance called the substrate, and then breaking it down into two smaller molecules. This process is called catalysis. The enzymes can only work if they have the correct shape, so scientists study their structure in order to better understand how they work.

As with any machine, the way enzymes work can be best understood by analogy. Imagine an enzyme as a tiny robot that is programmed to break down a specific type of molecule. The robot is attached to the molecule it is programmed to break down, and then breaks it into two smaller pieces. This process is called catalysis, and it happens very quickly thanks to the robot's speed and precision. Like all robots, enzymes are designed with a certain structure that allows them to do their job effectively. By understanding this structure, scientists can learn more about how enzymes work and find ways to make them even more effective at breaking down molecules.	enzyme mechanism	Using an analogy, explain enzyme mechanism to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help chemical reactions happen in the body. Anova is a technique used in statistics to compare the means of two or more groups. It can be thought of as a way of measuring how different the means are from each other. For example, if you wanted to know whether there was a difference in the average score for males and females on an exam, you could use anova to find out.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to an arts student.	ht	arts	0	Anova is an acronym for "analysis of variance." It is a technique used in statistics to compare the means of two or more groups.
Anova is a technique used in statistics to compare the means of two or more groups. An analogy could be comparing the average score of males and females on a test.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Anova is an acronym for "analysis of variance." It is a technique used in statistics to compare the means of two or more groups.

It's used to compare the means of two or more groups, just as you might use a ruler to measure the length of two pieces of paper.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Anova is an acronym for "analysis of variance." If we imagine an art class with ten students, five of whom are girls and five of whom are boys, we could use anova to see if there is a difference in the average painting skills between the two groups. ANOVA is a way of comparing the averages (or means) of two or more groups. For example, let's say you wanted to know if there was a difference in the average grades between students who took art and students who didn't take art. You could use ANOVA to compare the averages and see if there was a significant difference.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to an arts student.	ht	arts	0	ANOVA is an acronym that stands for Analysis of Variance. It is a technique used in statistics to analyze the variation among groups of data. In particular, ANOVA can be used to determine whether there is a significant difference between the means of two or more groups.
ANOVA is a technique used in statistics to compare the average score of two or more groups. In other words, it tells us if the averages of different groups are significantly different from each other. To do this, ANOVA compares the variability (or spread) of the scores within each group with the variability between the groups. If there is more variability within groups than between them, then we can say that there is a significant difference between the means of those groups.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	ANOVA is an acronym that stands for Analysis of Variance. ANOVA is a technique used in statistics to analyze the variation among groups of data. In particular, ANOVA can be used to determine whether there is a significant difference between the means of two or more groups. For example, if you wanted to know whether there was a difference in how well different students could draw, you might give each student three tests: one on drawing people, one on drawing objects, and one on drawing plants. It does this by sensing the ambient air temperature and then activating or deactivating devices such as heaters or air conditioners in order to maintain the desired set point.

Just-in-time can be thought of as an artist only buying the necessary materials for their next project, rather than stocking up on a lot of supplies that might not be used. This helps to avoid waste and keep costs down.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Just-in-time is an inventory management system that aims to reduce the cost of holding stock by receiving goods only as they are needed in production. This means that a company does not order more components or materials than it needs for the next few days or weeks, which can help to avoid wastage and keep costs down.
Just-in-time is like having a theatre production where the actors only learn their lines and rehearse as they are needed for each performance. This way, the actors don't have to remember too many lines and can focus on giving a great performance. In the same way, just-in-time helps companies focus on producing what is needed when it is needed, without having to worry about storing large amounts of inventory.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Just-in-time is an inventory management system that aims to reduce the cost of holding stock by receiving goods only as they are needed in production. Just-in-time can be thought of as an artist only buying the paints they need for the next few days or weeks. This means that they are not wasting paint by buying more than they need, and it also keeps costs down.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Just-in-time is an inventory management system that aims to reduce the cost of holding stock by receiving goods only as they are needed in production. In an art class, a student might need just-in-time delivery of new brushes in order to complete their latest painting project. If the school ordered too many brushes and they sat unused in a supply closet, that would be considered a waste. However, if the school only ordered enough brushes for the next few days and they were delivered as soon as the student placed their request, then that would be considered using resources efficiently.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Just-in-time is an inventory management system that aims to reduce the cost of holding stock by receiving goods only as they are needed in production. If you have two painters, one with a small brush and one with a big brush, the painter with the big brush will paint a larger area than the painter with the small brush. This is because more paint can fit on the surface when it is spread out by a bigger brush. In the same way, if you have two wires with different resistances (diameters), then the wire with higher resistance (bigger diameter) will create a stronger magnetic field.	ohm's law	Using an analogy, explain ohm's law to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	When an electric current flows through a wire, it creates a magnetic field around the wire. The strength of this magnetic field is determined by how much current is flowing and how big the wire is. If you have two wires with the same amount of current running through them, but one has a bigger diameter than the other, then the wire with the bigger diameter will create a stronger magnetic field. This principle is called "ohm's law." It states that if you have two wires with different resistances (diameters), then the wire with the higher resistance (bigger diameter) will create a stronger magnetic field.
If you have two painters, one with a small brush and the other with a big brush, the painter with the bigger brush will create a larger painting. This principle is called "ohm's law." It states that if you have two wires with different resistances (diameters), then the wire with the higher resistance (bigger diameter) will create a stronger magnetic field.
Water droplets will bead up on a hydrophobic surface, because the water molecules are repelled by the hydrophobic surface. This is similar to how oil and water do not mix, because the oil molecules are repelled by the water molecules.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up on a hydrophobic surface, because the water molecules are repelled by the hydrophobic surface. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
One way to think of the hydrophobic effect is to imagine a group of people in a room. If everyone in the room were wearing wet clothes, they would all be sticking together and would be very uncomfortable. However, if some of the people in the room were wearing dry clothes, they would not be sticking together as much, because the dry clothes would repel the water on the other people's clothes. This is similar to how hydrophobic surfaces work - they repel water droplets and keep them from clinging together.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up on a hydrophobic surface, because the water molecules are repelled by the hydrophobic surface. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
Just as an artist's paints are attracted to each other and clump together, water droplets on a hydrophobic surface are also drawn together. The molecules at the surface of the droplet are repelled by the hydrophobic material, so they move inward and join forces with their neighboring molecules. This creates a strong bond that holds the droplet in place.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up on a hydrophobic surface, because the water molecules are repelled by the hydrophobic surface. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
Water droplets will bead up on a hydrophobic surface, because the water molecules are repelled by the hydrophobic surface. This is similar to how oil and water do not mix, because oil is hydrophobic and water is hydrophilic. The oil will bead up on top of the water, because it is repelled by the water's surface.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up on a hydrophobic surface, because the water molecules are repelled by the hydrophobic surface. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
The hydrophobic effect is similar to the way in which paint droplets repel one another. In both cases, the molecules are repelled by one another because they are not attracted to each other.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up on a hydrophobic surface, because the water molecules are repelled by the hydrophobic surface. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.
If you think of water as a bunch of people at a party, the polar molecules are the people who are sticking together and chatting in small groups. The nonpolar molecules are like the people who are standing by themselves, not talking to anyone. When it comes time to leave, the nonpolar molecules will naturally congregate together since they aren't attracted to any one group (the water).	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because polar molecules, which are attracted to water, interfere with the interaction between nonpolar molecules.
Imagine you are at a party and there are two groups of people, one group is chatting and the other is not. The group that is chatting is more spread out and the group that is not talking is closer together. This analogy represents the hydrophobic effect because when nonpolar molecules are in an aqueous environment (the party), they aggregate together because polar molecules (people who like to talk) interfere with their interaction.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because polar molecules, which are attracted to water, interfere with the interaction between nonpolar molecules.
If you think of water as a bunch of tiny magnets, the polar molecules are the ones that line up in straight rows and stick to one another. The nonpolar molecules can still clump together, but they get scattered all around since there's nothing to pull them together in an orderly way.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. As you sit down, you notice that the sand is very hot. This is because the sun's rays are interacting with the particles in the sand, causing them to heat up.When water molecules encounter nonpolar molecules, they try to orient themselves so that their polar ends face the nonpolar molecule. This disrupts the interaction between neighboring nonpolar molecules, preventing them from forming large clumps (as they would in an environment without any water). In other words, water acts as a lubricant, allowing nonpolar molecules to move past each other more easily.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. The hydrophobic effect can be thought of as similar to two magnets repelling each other. In an aqueous environment, the polar molecules (like water) act as magnets that attract the nonpolar molecules. This interaction disrupts the natural clustering of the nonpolar molecules and prevents them from forming stable structures.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. This occurs because polar molecules, which are attracted to water, interfere with the interaction between nonpolar molecules.
Imagine two people, Bill and Ted. Bill is very shy and doesn't like to be around other people, while Ted loves socializing. If you put them in a room full of people, Bill will try to stay as far away from the other people as possible, while Ted will move around and talk to everyone. The same thing happens with molecules: the hydrophobic ones want to stay away from the water (the other people), while the hydrophilic ones want to be close to it.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student.	ht	arts	1	Water molecules are polar, meaning that the oxygen atom has a partial negative charge and the hydrogen atoms have a partial positive charge. The polarity of water molecules causes them to be attracted to each other, which is why they form clusters and droplets. Nonpolar molecules, such as oil, are not attracted to water because they do not have any polar bonds. When two different types of molecules are mixed together, the nonpolar ones will try to push away from the polar ones in order to minimize their exposure to the water. This is known as the hydrophobic effect.

Chromatography is like a group of painters who are all working on a large canvas. The painters are all using different colors and the colors are all mixed together. The painters start at one end of the canvas and work their way to the other end. As they work, the colors start to separate and the different colors can be seen.	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using an arts analogy.	lt	arts	1	Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The components are dissolved in a solvent and then passed through a filter. The different components are then separated by their different rates of diffusion through the filter.
Stars are like people. They are born, they grow up, they get old, and then they die. The main-sequence lifetime of a star is the length of time it spends as a young adult. This means that a star spends most of its life burning hydrogen in its core. When it runs out of hydrogen, it dies.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using an arts analogy.	lt	arts	0	Stars are like people. They are born, they grow up, they get old, and then they die. The main-sequence lifetime of a star is the length of time it spends as a young adult.
Nucleus can be thought of as the central part of an atom, much like a director is the central part of a movie. The protons in the nucleus give it its positive charge, just as the actors in a movie give it its energy and excitement. The neutrons in the nucleus give it its mass, just as the set and props in a movie give it its weight. Without a nucleus, an atom would just be a collection of electrons floating around in space.	nucleus	Explain nucleus using an arts analogy.	lt	arts	1	Nucleus is the central part of an atom. It is made up of protons and neutrons. The protons give the nucleus its positive charge and the neutrons give the nucleus its mass.
The resonance hybrid is like a group of dancers who are all moving in unison. The different Lewis structures are like different groups of dancers who are all moving in their own way. The resonance hybrid is the most stable of the different groups, and it is the one that is most likely to exist in reality.	resonance hybrid	Explain resonance hybrid using an arts analogy.	lt	arts	1	A resonance hybrid is a model of a molecule that is made up of several different Lewis structures. The different Lewis structures are equivalent, and they all represent the same molecule. The resonance hybrid is the most stable of the different Lewis structures, and it is the one that is most likely to exist in reality.

A mouse is like a paintbrush. It is used to control the cursor on the screen, which is like the paint on the canvas.	mouse	Explain mouse using an arts analogy.	lt	arts	1	A mouse is a small rodent that is typically used as a computer input device. When light shines on a certain material, some of the light is reflected off the surface while some of the light is absorbed by the material. If the material is then hit with a second light beam, the light that was absorbed by the material will be re-emitted and will be travelling in a different direction than the original light beam. This is like when you hold a light up to a painting and the light that is absorbed by the painting is re-emitted and creates a glow around the painting.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an arts analogy.	lt	arts	1	When light shines on a certain material, some of the light is reflected off the surface while some of the light is absorbed by the material. If the material is then hit with a second light beam, the light that was absorbed by the material will be re-emitted and will be travelling in a different direction than the original light beam. This is called anti-stokes scattering.
The median lethal dose can be thought of as the "threshold" dose at which a substance becomes lethal. In other words, it is the dose of a substance that is expected to kill half of the people who are exposed to it. This can be illustrated with the example of a group of people who are standing in a line. If you were to randomly choose one person from the line and expose them to a lethal dose of a substance, there is a 50% chance that that person would die.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using an arts analogy.	lt	arts	1	The median lethal dose is the dose of a substance that is expected to kill half of the people who are exposed to it. It can be thought of as the "threshold" dose at which a substance becomes lethal.

The hydrophobic effect is similar to the way that oil and water do not mix. The oil is nonpolar and is repelled by the water's polar molecules. The oil is pushed to the center of the water droplet and away from the water's surface.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an arts analogy.	lt	arts	1	Water molecules are attracted to each other by hydrogen bonds. This attraction creates a network of water molecules that covers the surface of most objects. The water molecules are said to be hydrophilic, which means "water-loving." The hydrophobic effect is a phenomenon that occurs when nonpolar molecules are surrounded by water. The water molecules are attracted to the polar molecules in the water, and the nonpolar molecules are repelled. This creates a force that pushes the nonpolar molecules to the center of the water droplet and away from the water's surface.

For example, some proteins are involved in the structure of cells while others are responsible for chemical reactions.

Dna is like a blueprint. It tells the cells how to build everything that is needed in order for life to thrive.	dna	Explain dna using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	DNA is the blueprint of life. Chromatography is often used to separate different colors of paint. In this analogy, the strip of paper is like a canvas, and the solvent is like water. The different colors of paint will travel down the paper at different speeds, based on their chemical properties. By looking at which color has traveled the furthest down the strip of paper, it is possible to determine which components make up the mixture.	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. This can be done using different types of chromatography, such as gas chromatography or liquid chromatography. In general, the components of the mixture are placed on a strip of paper and then passed through a solvent. The different components will travel along the paper at different speeds, based on their chemical properties. By looking at which component has traveled the furthest down the strip of paper, it is possible to determine which components make up the mixture.
One way to think about chromatography is as an art gallery. The different colors of paint on a canvas can be thought of as the different components of a mixture. When you walk through an art gallery, the different colors will mix together and create new colors. This is similar to what happens when you pass a strip of paper through a solvent: the different components of the mixture will travel along the paper at different speeds, and they will eventually mix together.	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. The different components will travel along the paper at different speeds, based on their chemical properties. By looking at which component has traveled the furthest down the strip of paper, it is possible to determine which components make up the mixture.
One way to think of chromatography is as a giant coloring book. Each color in the book is a different component of the mixture. As the book is colored, each component will travel along the paper at different speeds, based on its chemical properties. By looking at which color has traveled the furthest down the page, it is possible to determine which components make up the mixture.	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture. Column chromatography can be thought of as an art gallery in which the paintings are placed on different walls, or "columns." The paintings (chemicals) will move through the gallery at different speeds, based on how much they attract to the walls. This will allow them to be separated into groups.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate chemicals in a mixture. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with material that selectively adsorbs (attracts) one chemical more than another. The different chemicals then move through the column at different speeds, allowing them to be separated.
Column chromatography can be thought of as an art gallery, with each chemical being a different painting. The paintings are hung on the walls of the gallery in a specific order, and as people walk down the corridor they will see them in order. However, if someone stands at one end of the gallery they will see all the paintings at once, while someone standing at the other end will see them in reverse order.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate chemicals in a mixture. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with material that selectively adsorbs (attracts) one chemical more than another. The different chemicals then move through the column at different speeds, allowing them to be separated.
Column chromatography can be thought of as an art gallery in which each painting is on a different row and each column is a different width. The paintings are hung so that the widest ones are at the bottom and the skinniest ones are at the top. If you walked down the aisle, you would see all of the wide paintings first, then all of the medium-sized ones, and finally all of the skinny ones.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate chemicals in a mixture. It works by passing the mixture through a column filled with material that selectively adsorbs (attracts) one chemical more than another. The different chemicals then move through the column at different speeds, allowing them to be separated.
Column chromatography is similar to separating colors in a rainbow. The different colors are separated by their attraction to different materials (violet is attracted to the most materials, red is attracted to the least). This allows each color to be pulled through the column at a different speed, creating a rainbow effect.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	Column chromatography is a technique used to separate chemicals in a mixture. The vacuole can be thought of as a small, sack-like organelle in the cytoplasm of a eukaryotic cell that is used for storage. Just like an artist might store their paint supplies in a small bag or container, the vacuole stores the nutrients and other materials that are necessary for the cell to function.	vacuole	Explain vacuole using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	A vacuole is a small, sack-like organelle in the cytoplasm of a eukaryotic cell. It is the primary site for intracellular digestion and storage. Vacuoles are formed during endocytosis when portions of the plasma membrane invaginate and pinch off to form vesicles.
A vacuole is a small, sack-like organelle in the cytoplasm of a eukaryotic cell. It is the primary site for intracellular digestion and storage. Helicase is a protein that works similarly to how a person would uncoil a ball of yarn. This allows for the DNA strands to be used in creating new proteins.	helicase	Explain helicase using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	1	Helicase is a protein that unwinds double-stranded DNA so that the DNA can be used to make new proteins. It's like a person who uncoils a ball of yarn so that it can be used to knit a sweater.
Helicase is a protein that unwinds double-stranded DNA so that the DNA can be used to make new proteins. It's like a person who uncoils a ball of yarn so that it can be used to knit a sweater. The helicase enzyme helps separate the two strands of the DNA molecule, and then other enzymes can come in and start making new proteins by reading the genetic code encoded within the DNA.	helicase	Explain helicase using an arts analogy.	ht	arts	0	Helicase is a protein that unwinds double-stranded DNA so that the DNA can be used to make new proteins. It's kind of like the hot glue gun of the cell, helping to quickly and securely attach pieces together.

Peroxysomes are like tiny recycling plants inside of cells. They take in old, damaged proteins and recycle them into new, healthy proteins. This is a bit like taking an old shirt and turning it into a new one. The old shirt is broken down into its component parts, and then new materials are used to create a new shirt. Peroxysomes work in a similar way, breaking down old proteins and rebuilding them into new ones.	peroxysome	Explain peroxysome using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for an arts student.	lt	arts	1	Peroxysomes are like tiny recycling plants inside of cells. They take in old, damaged proteins and recycle them into new, healthy proteins.
Enzymes are like tiny machines that help to speed up chemical reactions in the body. They are like tiny robots that help to make things happen quickly. Enzymes are important because they help to break down food so that the body can use it to create energy.	enzymes	Explain enzymes using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for an arts student.	lt	arts	1	Enzymes are like tiny machines that help to speed up chemical reactions in the body. They are like tiny robots that help to make things happen quickly.
The median lethal dose can be thought of as the amount of a substance that would kill half of the people who took it. This can be thought of as the dose of a drug that would be deadly for an arts student. For example, if you took a drug that had a median lethal dose of 10, it would mean that 10 out of every 100 people who took it would die.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for an arts student.	lt	arts	1	The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that is lethal to 50% of the population. It can be thought of as the dose of a drug that would kill half of the people who took it.
The hydrophobic effect is the force that causes water to form droplets and beads on hydrophobic surfaces. This is similar to how people are attracted to each other by social bonds. Just as people are drawn together by their social bonds, water molecules are drawn together by their hydrogen bonds. This creates a strong force that pulls the molecules close together. This force is called the hydrophobic effect.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for an arts student.	lt	arts	1	Water molecules are attracted to each other by hydrogen bonds. This attraction creates a strong force that pulls the molecules close together. This force is called the hydrophobic effect. The hydrophobic effect is the force that causes water to form droplets and beads on hydrophobic surfaces.

It is a viscous fluid that contains enzymes, proteins, and other molecules necessary for life.

In a cell, specialization is like an artist dividing up their work into different specialties. For example, the nucleus is responsible for controlling the cell's activities, while the mitochondria produce energy for the cell. Communication in a cell is the process by which different parts of the cell communicate with each other. This communication allows the different parts of the cell to work together to carry out the cell's functions.
Kirchoff's voltage law is similar to the law of conservation of energy. Just as energy can neither be created nor destroyed, the voltage around a closed loop in a circuit must be constant. This law allows us to calculate the voltage at any point in a circuit by tracing the path of the current.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an arts analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law.	lt	arts	1	Kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero. This law is important in electrical engineering because it allows us to calculate the voltage at any point in a circuit by tracing the path of the current.

The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This step is responsible for controlling the rate of the reaction. This step is responsible for controlling the overall rate of the painting.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an arts analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction.	lt	arts	1	The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This step is responsible for controlling the rate of the reaction.

When an artist creates a painting, they start with a blank canvas. They add color and detail to the canvas one brushstroke at a time. The painting starts with a small amount of color in the center and gradually spreads outwards.This is similar to how an action potential travels down a neuron. The neuron starts with a small amount of voltage in the center of the dendrite. This voltage gradually spreads outwards, until it reaches the neuron's terminal. There, it triggers the release of neurotransmitters, which travel across the synaptic cleft to the dendrite of the next neuron. This process repeats until the action potential reaches the brain or spinal cord.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an arts analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron.	lt	arts	1	When an action potential is generated at the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the neuron's axon to the neuron's terminal. There, the action potential triggers the release of neurotransmitters, which travel across the synaptic cleft to the dendrite of the next neuron. This process repeats until the action potential reaches the brain or spinal cord.
A limiting reactant is like a limited number of paint colors that a painter has to work with. The painter can only make so many paintings with the colors that are available. An excess reactant is like an unlimited number of paint colors that the painter has to work with. The painter can make as many paintings as desired with the colors that are available.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an arts analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant.	lt	arts	1	A limiting reactant is a reactant that is in short supply and limits the amount of product that can be formed. An excess reactant is a reactant that is in excess and is not used up in the reaction.
A limiting reactant is the reactant in a chemical reaction that is in shortest supply. The reaction will stop when the limiting reactant is used up.In an art class, the students are working on a project where they are making a mosaic. There are a limited number of tiles available, so the students have to be careful about how they use them. The students will run out of tiles before they run out of other materials, so the tiles are the limiting reactant in this project.	limiting reactant	Using an arts analogy, explain limiting reactant.	lt	arts	1	A limiting reactant is the reactant in a chemical reaction that is in shortest supply. The reaction will stop when the limiting reactant is used up.

Glycolysis can be thought of as the process of creating a work of art from a single sheet of paper. The artist begins by folding the paper in half, then folding it in half again. Next, the artist cuts the paper into four equal squares. Finally, the artist begins to create the work of art by folding and cutting the squares into smaller and smaller pieces.	glycolysis	Using an arts analogy, explain glycolysis.	lt	arts	1	Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of the cell and does not require oxygen.
Anti-stokes scattering is the scattering of light or other forms of electromagnetic radiation in the opposite direction to the direction of the incident radiation. It is the process by which energy is dissipated from a system, and is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the frequency of the radiation.In other words, anti-stokes scattering is the process of energy being dissipated from a system. This is done by scattering the radiation in the opposite direction to the direction of the incident radiation. This is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the frequency of the radiation.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	lt	arts	1	Anti-stokes scattering is the scattering of light or other forms of electromagnetic radiation in the opposite direction to the direction of the incident radiation. It is the process by which energy is dissipated from a system, and is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the frequency of the radiation.
Stokes scattering is like the scattering of light by small particles in the air. The scattering is caused by the collisions of the photons with the atoms or molecules of the medium. The scattering is in the forward direction, and the intensity of the scattered light decreases as the inverse square of the distance from the particle.	stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain stokes scattering.	lt	arts	1	Stokes scattering is the scattering of light or other electromagnetic radiation by small particles. The scattering is caused by the collisions of the photons or particles with the atoms or molecules of the medium. The scattering is in the forward direction, and the intensity of the scattered light decreases as the inverse square of the distance from the particle.

Just-in-time is like having a well-stocked tool box. You only put in new tools when you need them, and you always have the right tool for the job. This reduces the amount of clutter in your tool box and makes it easier to find what you need. It also means that you're not wasting time looking for tools that you don't have.	just-in-time	Using an arts analogy, explain just-in-time.	lt	arts	1	Just-in-time is a business strategy that aims to improve a company's efficiency by reducing the time between when a product is ordered and when it is delivered. This is done by having a just-in-time inventory, which is a stock of goods that is only replenished when it is needed. This reduces the amount of inventory that a company needs to keep on hand, which saves money on storage costs and minimizes the amount of time that a product is out of stock.
