Message encoding is similar to sending a message through the postal service. The sender must change the format of the original message so that it can be transmitted through the mail system. They may also need to add coding information so that the recipient can decode the message correctly.	message encoding	Using an arts analogy, explain message encoding.	ht	arts	1	Message encoding is the process of translating a message into a format that can be transmitted. This may involve changing the format of the original message, adding coding information to it, or both. The goal of encoding is to ensure that the message arrives intact and can be decoded properly.
Encoding a message can be thought of as like putting a painting into a protective frame. The frame keeps the painting from being damaged, and it also makes it easier to hang on a wall or move around. Ramming is the act of using a blunt object to forcefully collide with an object. In the arts, it can be used as a metaphor to describe when an artist or creator makes a powerful and deliberate impact on their field or community. For example, when an artist releases a new album that quickly becomes popular and influential, they may be said to have "rammed" their music into the mainstream.	ram	Using an arts analogy, explain ram.	ht	arts	0	Ramming is the act of using a blunt object to forcefully collide with an object.  The Golden Ratio is used in art to create aesthetically pleasing proportions. It can be found in the ratio of a tree's height to its width at its base. This ratio is usually around 1.6, which means that a tree is approximately one and a sixth times as old as it is wide.	tree's age calculation	Using an arts analogy, explain tree's age calculation.	ht	arts	0	Artists often use the Golden Ratio to calculate the age of a tree. When light or any electromagnetic radiation interacts with a molecule, the energy of the radiation can be either absorbed by the molecule or scattered. When it is scattered, some of the energy is transferred to nearby molecules, which then scatter more of the energy in all directions. This process continues until all of the energy has been dissipated. Anti-stokes scattering is a type of scattering that occurs when a molecule scatters more energy in the opposite direction than was originally absorbed. It occurs when the frequency of the radiation matches one of the resonant frequencies of	anti-stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	arts	0	When light or any electromagnetic radiation interacts with a molecule, the energy of the radiation can be either absorbed by the molecule or scattered. When it is scattered, some of the energy is transferred to nearby molecules, which then scatter more of the energy in all directions. This process continues until all of the energy has been dissipated. Anti-stokes scattering is a type of scattering that occurs when a molecule scatters more energy in the opposite direction than was originally absorbed. It occurs when the frequency of the radiation matches one of the resonant frequencies of the molecule and results in an exchange of energy between them.

It occurs when the frequency of the radiation matches one of the resonant frequencies of the molecule and results in an exchange of energy between them.
Anti-stokes scattering can be thought of as the musical equivalent of a feedback loop. When two instruments with similar frequencies are played together, they will create a reinforcement or multiplication of the sound. If one instrument is playing a higher frequency than the other, however, it will cause energy to be dissipated from the lower frequency instrument in the form of heat. This is analogous to anti-stokes scattering, where a molecule absorbs energy from radiation and then scatters more energy in all directions.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	arts	1	When light or any electromagnetic radiation interacts with a molecule, the energy of the radiation can be either absorbed by the molecule or scattered. When light waves encounter an obstruction, they scatter in all directions. This is known as Raleigh scattering. With anti-stokes scattering, the scattered light waves are directed in the opposite direction of the original wave. This occurs when there is a decrease in intensity of the light wave.Using an arts analogy, this can be compared to two people yelling at each other across a noisy room - their voices will be scattered in all direction, but if one person talks quietly into their cupped hand, their voice will be directed towards the person they are speaking too.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	arts	1	When light waves encounter an obstruction, they scatter in all directions. This occurs when there is a decrease in intensity of the light wave.
When light waves encounter an obstruction, they scatter in all directions. This is known as Raleigh scattering. With anti-stokes scattering, the scattered light waves are directed in the opposite direction of the original wave. This occurs when there is a decrease in intensity of the light wave.In arts analogy terms, think about what happens when you shine a flashlight on a wall: The beam spreads out and illuminates everything in its path. But if you hold your hand between the flashlight and wall, you'll see that most of the light is blocked and only a small amount shines through your fingers. In this example, your hand is obstructing or scattering the light rays from hitting the wall. Now imagine that instead of shining a regular flashlight on a wall, you're using one with a blue filter. The blue light will scatter more than other colors because it travels in smaller particles than other colors (this is why we see blue skies). So by using an anti-stokes scatter algorithm on data collected from space, scientists can isolate pockets of gas that emit blue light – which could be good indicators of new planets!	anti-stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	arts	1	When light waves encounter an obstruction, they scatter in all directions. Anti-stokes scattering can be thought of as the opposite of echoes. Echoes are created when sound waves encounter an obstruction and bounce back in the direction of the original wave. Anti-stokes scattering occurs when light waves encounter an obstruction and scatter in the opposite direction, away from the original wave. This decrease in intensity can be seen when looking at objects that are lit up by a bright light source. The edges of the object will appear darker than the center because anti-stokes scattering is taking place around the edge of the object.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering.	ht	arts	1	When light waves encounter an obstruction, they scatter in all directions. Stokes scattering is a bit like when you spray paint on a canvas. As the paint hits the surface, it scatters in all directions. Some of the paint will fall to the ground, but some will also bounce off and fly somewhere else. The end result is a lot of different colors all mixed together with no real pattern.	stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain stokes scattering.	ht	arts	1	Stokes scattering is the scattering of light (or any other type of electromagnetic radiation) by particles that are much smaller than the wavelength of the radiation. The photons impart a small amount of energy to the particles, which then recoil and emit new photons in all directions. This process happens repeatedly as the photons pass through the particle cloud, resulting in a diffusion or spreading out of the light.
Stokes scattering is similar to the way paint spreads out when it is mixed with water. The small pigment particles are scattered by the larger water molecules, and the energy from the photons causes the particles to recoil and emit new photons. This process happens repeatedly as the photons pass through the particle cloud, resulting in a diffusion or spreading out of the light.	stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain stokes scattering.	ht	arts	1	Stokes scattering is the scattering of light (or any other type of electromagnetic radiation) by particles that are much smaller than the wavelength of the radiation. The photons impart a small amount of energy to the particles, which then recoil and emit new photons in all directions. This process happens repeatedly as the photons pass through the particle cloud, resulting in a diffusion or spreading out of the light.
Stokes scattering is a bit like when you throw a rock into a pond. The ripples start off small in the center, but quickly spread out as they move to the edge of the pond. This is because each time a ripple hits the edge, it reflects off and starts traveling in the other direction. The same thing happens with photons that scatter off of particles; they create new photons that spread out in all directions.	stokes scattering	Using an arts analogy, explain stokes scattering.	ht	arts	1	Stokes scattering is the scattering of light (or any other type of electromagnetic radiation) by particles that are much smaller than the wavelength of the radiation. The median lethal dose is the dosage of a poisonous substance that kills 50% of the test population. It is calculated by administering different dosages to a group of animals and observing which dosage kills half of them. This information can then be used to help determine the toxicity level of a particular substance. In other words, it's what you would need to take in order to kill yourself (or someone else) if you were using it as poison.	median lethal dose	Using an arts analogy, explain median lethal dose.	ht	arts	1	The median lethal dose (LD) is the dosage of a poisonous substance that kills 50% of the test population. It is calculated by administering different dosages to a group of animals and observing which dosage kills half of them. This information can then be used to help determine the toxicity of a substance.
The median lethal dose is the amount of a poisonous substance that kills 50% of the test population. In other words, it's the amount of poison that will kill half of the animals in a given group. This information can then be used to help determine the toxicity of a substance.	median lethal dose	Using an arts analogy, explain median lethal dose.	ht	arts	1	The median lethal dose (LD) is the dosage of a poisonous substance that kills 50% of the test population. If you consider an art exhibition, there might be many different types of artwork on display. You might have paintings, drawings, sculptures, and so on. An ANOVA would help us understand which type of artwork is most popular amongst visitors to the exhibition. It could tell us whether people prefer paintings over drawings, or sculpture over photography.	anova	Using an arts analogy, explain anova.	ht	arts	1	An ANOVA, or analysis of variance, is a statistical test that examines the difference between two or more means. It does this by partitioning the variability in the data into components attributable to different factors (in our example, treatment and error). This helps us understand which factors are responsible for any differences we see in the data.
If you were to analyze the variation in colors between two paintings, an ANOVA would help identify which factors (paint brands, painting techniques, etc.) are responsible for any differences in color. This could help inform your decision on which paints to use for your next project, or how best to achieve the desired effect.	anova	Using an arts analogy, explain anova.	ht	arts	1	An ANOVA, or analysis of variance, is a statistical test that examines the difference between two or more means. This helps us understand which factors are responsible for any differences we see in the data.

An ANOVA helps us understand which factors (in our case, treatment and error) are responsible for any differences we see in the data. This can be helpful in understanding how different treatments or conditions might affect an outcome, as well as identifying potential sources of variation in our data.	anova	Using an arts analogy, explain anova.	ht	arts	1	An ANOVA, or analysis of variance, is a statistical test that examines the difference between two or more means. An anova is a statistical analysis tool that can be used to compare the means of three or more groups. It does this by breaking down the variability in the data into within-group and between-group components. This allows us to see if there is a significant difference in the means of the different groups, after accounting for any variability within each group.	anova	Using an arts analogy, explain anova.	ht	arts	0	An anova is a statistical analysis that tests the equality of three or more means. The anova statistic tests whether the means of three or more groups are statistically different from each other. It does this by partitioning the total variability in the data into within-group and between-group components. This tells us whether the differences we see in the averages are due to chance, or if they are actually real differences between groups.	anova	Using an arts analogy, explain anova.	ht	arts	0	An anova is a statistical analysis that tests the equality of three or more means. They are responsible for making sure that the temperature in a room or building is just right, by turning on and off the heating or cooling unit as needed. In the world of arts, just-in-time would be like a theater company that always has a fresh set of new props and never runs out of costumes. They rely on their suppliers to keep them stocked up with what they need, exactly when they need it. This way, they never have to worry about wasting resources or overspending on inventory.	just-in-time	Using an arts analogy, explain just-in-time.	ht	arts	1	Just-in-time is a business model that produces only what is needed, when it is needed. This eliminates waste and helps to keep costs low. It relies on a close relationship with suppliers who can provide the necessary materials just in time.

Adaptive immunity can be thought of as the immune system's ability to "learn." B cells and T cells are activated when they encounter a specific pathogen. This activation leads to the production of antibodies and lymphocytes that specifically target that pathogen. As a result, adaptive immunity provides long-term protection against infections by those pathogens.	adaptive immunity	Using an arts analogy, explain adaptive immunity.	ht	arts	1	Adaptive immunity is the process by which the immune system "learns" to recognize and respond to specific pathogens. This occurs through the activation of B cells and T cells, which leads to the production of antibodies and lymphocytes that specifically target those pathogens.
Just as an artist becomes better at painting over time by practicing and learning from their mistakes, the immune system becomes better at fighting pathogens over time through a process of adaptation. This occurs through the activation of B cells and T cells, which leads to the production of antibodies and lymphocytes that specifically target those pathogens.	adaptive immunity	Using an arts analogy, explain adaptive immunity.	ht	arts	1	Adaptive immunity is the process by which the immune system "learns" to recognize and respond to specific pathogens. Adaptive immunity can be thought of as an artist learning to paint a specific picture. The first time the artist paints the picture, they may not be very good at it. However, through practice and repetition, they will gradually get better and better at painting that picture until they can reproduce it perfectly. This is similar to how the immune system learns to recognize and respond to specific pathogens. B cells and T cells are activated when exposed to a pathogen, which leads to the production of antibodies and lymphocytes that specifically target that pathogen. Over time, this process allows the immune system to become more efficient in fighting off infections by those pathogens.	adaptive immunity	Using an arts analogy, explain adaptive immunity.	ht	arts	1	Adaptive immunity is the process by which the immune system "learns" to recognize and respond to specific pathogens. Transcription is the process of turning a work of art into a set of instructions that can be followed to create a copy of the original artwork. For example, imagine you want to make a painting of your favorite flower. You would first need to find a picture or drawing of the flower that you like. Next, you would need to carefully copy the image onto canvas using paints or pencils. The finished product would be an exact replica of the original picture.	transcription	Using an arts analogy, explain transcription.	ht	arts	1	Transcription is the process of turning a work of art into a set of instructions that can be followed to create a copy of the original artwork.

This would allow someone else to follow your instructions and create an exact duplicate of the painting.	transcription	Using an arts analogy, explain transcription.	ht	arts	0	Transcription is the process of turning a work of art into a set of instructions that can be followed to create a copy of the original artwork.

It takes the individual colors (ribonucleotides) and paints a picture (RNA).	rna polymerase	Using an arts analogy, explain rna polymerase.	ht	arts	1	RNA polymerase is the enzyme responsible for synthesizing RNA from ribonucleotides. It catalyzes the formation of a phosphodiester bond between the 3' end of one ribonucleotide and the 5' end of another, forming a strand of RNA.
RNA polymerase is the enzyme responsible for synthesizing RNA from ribonucleotides. It catalyzes the formation of a phosphodiester bond between the 3' end of one ribonucleotide and the 5' end of another, forming a strand of RNA. In other words, it helps create new strands of RNA by linking individual molecules together.	rna polymerase	Using an arts analogy, explain rna polymerase.	ht	arts	1	RNA polymerase is the enzyme responsible for synthesizing RNA from ribonucleotides. The hydrophobic effect can be thought of as the tendency of oil to form droplets in water. This occurs because polar molecules have a strong affinity for water and will orient themselves so that their polar ends are facing the water, while the nonpolar parts of the molecule are oriented away from the water. This leaves large areas of empty space surrounding the polar molecules, which can easily accommodate nonpolar molecules. The result is that nonpolar molecules tend to clump together, an effect known as self-assembly.	hydrophobic effect	Using an arts analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	arts	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in aqueous solutions. This occurs because polar molecules have a strong affinity for water and will orient themselves so that their polar ends are facing the water, while the nonpolar parts of the molecule are oriented away from the water. This leaves large areas of empty space surrounding the polar molecules, which can easily accommodate nonpolar molecules. The result is that nonpolar molecules tend to clump together, an effect known as self-assembly.
Think of the hydrophobic effect as a crowd of people at an outdoor concert. The people are all pushing and shoving to get close to the stage, while the areas around them are empty. This is because everyone is drawn to the center, where all the action is. In much the same way, polar molecules are attracted to water, while nonpolar molecules are repelled by it. This leaves large areas of empty space surrounding the polar molecules, which can easily accommodate nonpolar molecules. The result is that nonpolar molecules tend to clump together, an effect known as self-assembly.	hydrophobic effect	Using an arts analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	arts	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in aqueous solutions. This occurs because polar molecules have a strong affinity for water and will orient themselves so that their polar ends are facing the water, while the nonpolar parts of the molecule are oriented away from the water. This leaves large areas of empty space surrounding the polar molecules, which can easily accommodate nonpolar molecules. The result is that nonpolar molecules tend to clump together, an effect known as self-assembly.
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in aqueous solutions. This occurs because polar molecules have a strong affinity for water and will orient themselves so that their polar ends are facing the water, while the nonpolar parts of the molecule are oriented away from the water. This leaves large areas of empty space surrounding the polar molecules, which can easily accommodate nonpolar molecules. The result is that nonpolar molecules tend to clump together, an effect known as self-assembly	hydrophobic effect	Using an arts analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	arts	0	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in aqueous solutions. This occurs because polar molecules have a strong affinity for water and will orient themselves so that their polar ends are facing the water, while the nonpolar parts of the molecule are oriented away from the water. This leaves large areas of empty space surrounding the polar molecules, which can easily accommodate nonpolar molecules. The result is that nonpolar molecules tend to clump together, an effect known as self-assembly.
Think of the hydrophobic effect as like a group of kids at a water park. The polar molecules are like the kids who love going down the slides and playing in the pool. They are always surrounded by friends, having a great time. The nonpolar molecules are like the kids who would rather stay on the sidelines and play with their phones. They don't really want to be around all of that wetness, so they stick together on the edges of the group.	hydrophobic effect	Using an arts analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	arts	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in aqueous solutions. This occurs because polar molecules have a strong affinity for water and will orient themselves so that their polar ends are facing the water, while the nonpolar parts of the molecule are oriented away from the water. This leaves large areas of empty space surrounding the polar molecules, which can easily accommodate nonpolar molecules. The result is that nonpolar molecules tend to clump together, an effect known as self-assembly.
Think of the hydrophobic effect as an Artsy version of 'The Great Gatsby.' Just like in the book, nonpolar molecules are drawn to each other and clump together in a way that leaves large areas of empty space surrounding them. This creates a cohesive group that is separate from the rest of the solution.	hydrophobic effect	Using an arts analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	arts	1	The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in aqueous solutions. This occurs because polar molecules have a strong affinity for water and will orient themselves so that their polar ends are facing the water, while the nonpolar parts of the molecule are oriented away from the water. This leaves large areas of empty space surrounding the polar molecules, which can easily accommodate nonpolar molecules. The result is that nonpolar molecules tend to clump together, an effect known as self-assembly.
One way to think of the hydrophobic effect is to imagine a group of people in a room. The people are all packed together and there is very little space between them. Now, imagine that someone introduces a large water balloon into the room. The water will push its way through the gaps between the people, trying to get away from itself. In the same way, nonpolar molecules are pushed away from water by the hydrophobic effect.	hydrophobic effect	Using an arts analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	arts	1	Water molecules are polar, and thus they are attracted to one another. This attraction is called the hydrogen bond. Nonpolar molecules, such as oil, are not attracted to water because they do not have polarity. The hydrophobic effect occurs when nonpolar molecules are surrounded by water. The water tries to push the nonpolar molecules away from itself, but the strong hydrogen bonds between the water molecules hold them together.
When you try to mix oil and water, they do not easily combine. This is because the water molecules are polar and attracted to one another, while the oil molecules are nonpolar and do not have this attraction. The water tries to push the oil away from itself, but the strong hydrogen bonds between the water molecules hold them together.	hydrophobic effect	Using an arts analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	arts	1	Water molecules are polar, and thus they are attracted to one another. The water tries to push the nonpolar molecules away from itself, but the strong hydrogen bonds between the water molecules hold them together.
Paint is nonpolar because the pigment molecules are not attracted to water. When you try to wash paint off of your hands, the water pushes the paint away from itself, but the hydrogen bonds between the water molecules hold it together.	hydrophobic effect	Using an arts analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	ht	arts	1	Water molecules are polar, and thus they are attracted to one another. A median lethal dose can be thought of as the amount of a substance that is required to kill half of a group of animals or people. It can be thought of as the "middle" amount of a substance that is lethal to a group. This means that there are more doses that are lethal to a group than there are doses that are not lethal.	median lethal dose	What is a good analogy to explain median lethal dose to an arts student?	lt	arts	1	A median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that is lethal to 50% of a population.  think of voltage as analogous to musical notes. just as the pressure (voltage) of a note determines how loud it sounds, the voltage in an electrical circuit determines how much energy is available to flow through the circuit.	voltage	What is a good analogy to explain voltage to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Voltage is the pressure that pushes electrons through a circuit. It's like water pressure in a hose. The voltage (pressure) is what makes the electrons flow.
Imagine a hose filled with water. The higher the water pressure, or voltage, the faster the water will flow through the hose. Voltage is like that imaginary hose's water pressure – it makes electrons flow quickly (and powerfully!) through a circuit.	voltage	What is a good analogy to explain voltage to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Voltage is the pressure that pushes electrons through a circuit. Hydrophobic effect is the tendency of water molecules to be drawn together, and away from non-polar materials. This can be explained by using the analogy of two magnets. Water molecules are like the north poles of two magnets, and will be drawn together. The hydrophobic material is like a south pole, and will be pushed away.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up and roll off a hydrophobic surface, such as wax. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other more than they are attracted to the hydrophobic material.
One analogy to explain the hydrophobic effect to an arts student is that of two magnets. Water molecules are attracted to each other (like the north poles of two magnets), while the hydrophobic material is not as attracted to water (like the south pole of a magnet).	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up and roll off a hydrophobic surface, such as wax. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other more than they are attracted to the hydrophobic material.
Water droplets will bead up and roll off a hydrophobic surface, such as wax. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other more than they are attracted to the hydrophobic material. It is similar to how people tend to stick together in a crowd, while individuals on the outside of the group are loose.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up and roll off a hydrophobic surface, such as wax. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other more than they are attracted to the hydrophobic material.
A good analogy to explain the hydrophobic effect to an arts student is by using the example of two people shaking hands. If one person has sweaty hands, the other person's hand will become wet. This is because water molecules are attracted to each other and will adhere to any surface they come into contact with.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up and roll off a hydrophobic surface, such as wax. This is because the water molecules are attracted to each other more than they are attracted to the hydrophobic material.
One analogy to explain the hydrophobic effect to an arts student is that of two people shaking hands. The water molecules are like the people's hands, and the hydrophobic material is like the dry ground between them. The water molecules are attracted to each other and will stay together, while the ground between them will not be as attractive and the water will drip away.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water droplets will bead up and roll off a hydrophobic surface, such as wax. A good analogy to explain the hydrophobic effect to an arts student is that of two magnets. Water molecules are like the north poles of two magnets, and nonpolar molecules are like the south poles of two magnets. The water molecules will be drawn together, while the nonpolar molecules will be pushed away.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water molecules are polar, meaning that the oxygen atom has a partial negative charge and the hydrogen atoms have a partial positive charge. Nonpolar molecules lack this polarity. In general, water molecules are attracted to one another (due to their polarity) and are repelled by nonpolar molecules. This is why oil and water do not mix: Oil is made up of many nonpolar molecules, so it is not attracted to the polar water molecules.
One analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student is that of two magnets. Like-charged magnets (polar molecules) are repelled from each other, while opposite-charged magnets (nonpolar molecules) are attracted to each other. In the context of water and oil, this means that the polar water molecules are repelled by the nonpolar oil molecules, and vice versa.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water molecules are polar, meaning that the oxygen atom has a partial negative charge and the hydrogen atoms have a partial positive charge. Nonpolar molecules lack this polarity. In general, water molecules are attracted to one another (due to their polarity) and are repelled by nonpolar molecules. This is why oil and water do not mix: Oil is made up of many nonpolar molecules, so it is not attracted to the polar water molecules.
One analogy to explain the hydrophobic effect to an arts student is that of two magnets. Water molecules are like the north poles of two magnets, and nonpolar molecules are like the south pole of a magnet. The north poles repel each other, while the south poles attract each other.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water molecules are polar, meaning that the oxygen atom has a partial negative charge and the hydrogen atoms have a partial positive charge. Nonpolar molecules lack this polarity. In general, water molecules are attracted to one another (due to their polarity) and are repelled by nonpolar molecules. This is why oil and water do not mix: Oil is made up of many nonpolar molecules, so it is not attracted to the polar water molecules.
One way to think about the hydrophobic effect is by analogy to magnets. Like magnets, water molecules are attracted to each other (due to their polarity), and they are also repelled by nonpolar molecules. This is why oil and water do not mix: Oil is made up of many nonpolar molecules, so it is not attracted to the polar water molecules.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water molecules are polar, meaning that the oxygen atom has a partial negative charge and the hydrogen atoms have a partial positive charge. Nonpolar molecules lack this polarity. In general, water molecules are attracted to one another (due to their polarity) and are repelled by nonpolar molecules. This is why oil and water do not mix: Oil is made up of many nonpolar molecules, so it is not attracted to the polar water molecules.
A good analogy to explain the hydrophobic effect to an arts student is to think of two magnets. Polar molecules, like water, are attracted to one another and will stick together (this is what happens when you add soap to dirty water - the polar molecules in the soap attach themselves to the dirt particles and surround them, making them easier to wash away). Nonpolar molecules do not have a polarity, so they are not attracted to each other or water and will instead push away from each other. This is what happens when you try to mix oil and water - because oil is nonpolar, it pushes away from the polar water molecules, creating two separate layers.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to an arts student?	ht	arts	1	Water molecules are polar, meaning that the oxygen atom has a partial negative charge and the hydrogen atoms have a partial positive charge. Nonpolar molecules lack this polarity. In general, water molecules are attracted to one another (due to their polarity) and are repelled by nonpolar molecules. This is why oil and water do not mix: Oil is made up of many nonpolar molecules, so it is not attracted to the polar water molecules.
